PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW REFORM BILL 1994 [No. 2]FAMILY LAW REFORM (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1995

PROCTEXT.PARA: FAMILY LAW REFORM BILL 1994 [No. 2]

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 25 October.
Clause 31.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Childs)—Order! The committee is considering the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 [No. 2]. When the committee last considered the bill it was considering an amendment moved by Senator Vanstone to clause 31, proposed section 63D, lines 31 to 35, and three amendments moved by Senator Spindler to Senator Vanstone's amendment. The question is that Senator Spindler's amendments be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been an agreed amendment to this proposal supplanting all the other amendments that were floating around the chamber at the time. I would like some assistance from the clerk or my advisers as to whose name that is in.
—Has it been circulated?

—Maybe that is where the hitch is. Maybe the agreed one has not been circulated as yet. We all agreed on it but I suppose we have not agreed as to who is going to move it, so Senator Spindler might want to take over.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding was that in the chamber the various parties agreed to a conference to thrash out what was acceptable in terms of an amendment. I have drawn up a copy of an amendment that I believe was agreed between the parties. I will be happy to move it, if that is acceptable. I faxed it to the two offices, but the chamber would not be aware of the wording as yet. It reads:

PARA.TAB: Proposed section 63D, paragraph (2)(b), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: "(b)the application must be accompanied by a copy of the plan, the information required by the Rules of Court, and:

(i)a statement, in relation to each party, that is to the effect that the party has been provided with independent legal advice as to the meaning and effect of the plan and that is signed by the practitioner who provided that advice; or
(ii)a statement to the effect that the plan was developed after consultation with a family and child counsellor (as defined in section 4) and that is signed by the counsellor.".

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that Senator Harradine will suggest this anyway, but I wonder whether we could move from this particular part of the agenda to give people time to circulate the agreed amendment, to identify it and agree to the fact that it is the agreed amendment, and then we can come back to it. Though we have agreed to an amendment, there is some confusion as to what the actual words are before us at the moment. I suggest that we move on to the next amendment and maybe come back to this.

—I would be grateful for that because I was not involved in the discussions, though, no doubt, I could have been. I am not reflecting at all upon those who arranged the discussions. I think that would be the appropriate way to go.

PARA.TAB: Amendments postponed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 12.Clause 31, page 28, proposed section 62E, at the end, add the following subsection:

"(3) In considering the practicality of making facilities available under subsection (2), the Principal Director or the appropriate officer, as the case may be, must take the following matters into account:

TAB.TAB: (a)the degree of equality (or otherwise) in bargaining power of the parties;
(b)the risk of child abuse (if any);
(c)the risk of family violence (if any);
(d)the emotional and psychological state of the parties;
(e)whether one of the parties may be seeking to use a primary dispute resolution method to delay proceedings or for some other advantage;
(f)any other relevant matter.".

SPEECH.PARA: 13.Clause 31, page 28, after proposed subsection 62F(2) insert the following subsection:
"(2A) In considering whether to make an order under subsection (2), the court must take the following matters into account:

TAB.TAB: (a)the degree of equality (or otherwise) in bargaining power of the parties;
(b)the risk of child abuse (if any);
(c)the risk of family violence (if any);
(d)the emotional and psychological state of the parties;
(e)whether one of the parties may be seeking to use a primary dispute resolution method to delay proceedings or for some other advantage;
(f)any other relevant matter.".

SPEECH.PARA: In moving these amendments, I wish to draw to the attention of the chamber that in subject matter and in direction this amendment is similar to amendments 10 and 11, which I have moved previously. This amendment is intended to provide guidelines for the Director of Court Counselling and for the court when deciding when counselling is contemplated or when parties are to attend a conference that they should consider whether, in all the circumstances related to the parties, this procedure is appropriate. The procedure we are referring to is a primary dispute resolution in preference to court proceedings.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the same reasons that we have already spelt out in the previous part of the debate, the government opposes these amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 14.Clause 31, page 28, after proposed paragraph 62F(4)(b) add the following word and paragraph:
"or(c)give directions as to the conduct of the conference, including directions that the parties must not come into direct contact during the conference.".

This amendment provides a court with a power to give directions concerning the conduct of conferences between the parties and family and child counsellors or welfare officers. This will include the power to order that the parties must not come into direct contact during the conference process. This is particularly important because it may reduce the chance of a violent confrontation where the particular case before the court has a history of violence. It is my understanding that the coalition may consider supporting this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —There does appear to be some merit in amendment No. 14 moved by Senator Spindler. There may well be occasions when it is not appropriate for certain things to happen and the judge in question may well be aware of that and, presumably, should be able to give those directions. It is not necessarily to be seen as a judge assuming that they have the capacity to stand in the shoes of a counsellor and have all those skills. It is just that the judge may well be aware of certain matters that ought to be taken into account in the conduct of the parties as they proceed. Therefore, amendment 14 may well have some merit in it. I would be interested in the government view as to why it should not accept that amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that Senator Spindler's amendment gives the power to the court to make directions as to the conduct of a conference it orders under the proposed section. The section will allow the court to direct the parties to proceedings affecting children to attend a conference with a family and child counsellor or welfare officer to discuss the care, welfare and development of the child and to try to resolve differences between the parties. Counselling ordered under this section is confidential and a conference ordered under the section must be distinguished from a conference conducted for the purpose of preparing a report under proposed section 62G.

PARA.TAB: I am told this amendment asks the court to make decisions about how the counsellor or welfare officer should conduct that conference. Those decisions are, we believe, most appropriately made by the counsellor or the welfare officer who has the appropriate experience, training and capacity to determine what procedures are most appropriate to assist in successful counselling. We agree that counselling should not require a person who is in fear of another person to come into direct contact with that person. The issue here, however, is who is the appropriate person to make a decision about appropriate procedures. A conference will be ordered under the proposed section only if the court considers that discussion of the care, welfare and development of the child may be of assistance to the parties in reaching agreement. That is unlikely to occur in circumstances where the court considers it is inappropriate that the parties come into direct contact.

We are concerned that the insertion of the provision may well indicate to counsellors that the absence of a direction that the parties do not come into direct contact means that the court considers that a face-to-face conference is appropriate. That is of concern to us. This could, of course, lead to counsellors not feeling able to exercise their professional judgment about the appropriate procedures which could be used and this could lead to parties being placed in situations of risk which would not occur if the judgment was exercised by the person best placed to do so, the counsellor or the welfare officer. There is a concern that in the absence of a court order a counsellor may feel as if there is no impediment to such a meeting. Our concern is based on that. We would rather leave the discretion totally in the hands of the counsellors, without any indication—direct or indirect—that could lead to a situation where counsellors may feel as if there is a green light when in fact it should be up to their judgment to make a decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the concerns that the minister has expressed, it seems to me that it is perfectly in order in normal circumstances for the counsellor to make that decision. We are not making the court's intervention mandatory; we are simply providing the discretion and the power for the court to do so when it is brought to the court's notice that there are circumstances in a particular case where the parties should not be brought face to face. It is simply an additional safeguard that is introduced. I think the committee should think carefully before it decides not to provide that additional safeguard.

—I take on board what Senator Spindler is trying to achieve, but could the minister confirm that that could take place in any event—that there is no requirement that the parties need to come face to face for the purposes of a conference without this amendment to the legislation. If that is the case, with respect, I would think that Senator Spindler's amendment is somewhat otiose. Could the minister confirm that that is the case.
—I can give you that confirmation about the procedures and the capacity of those procedures to accommodate direct meetings.

—Just on that point, the argument that the minister brought forward before was that the counsellor should be left entirely to decide how the counselling conference should be conducted and that we should not give the court the power to intervene and to decide that there should not be face-to-face confrontation. That seems to me to confirm my point that, unless this amendment is passed, the court will simply leave it to the counsellor to decide. We are saying that in normal circumstances we are quite happy to do that, but there may be the odd case where the counsellor overlooks or disregards whatever evidence is available about previous violence in that situation, and in that case the court, when its attention is drawn to it, should have the power to make such an order.

—I think the minister's argument, on balance, is more persuasive than Senator Spindler's. There is something to be said for saying that once the opportunity is there for the court to give those directions when they are not given the assumption is that the matter has been considered and responsibility, if you like, the need to consider those factors by the counsellor, can be waived. That might be the risk you run, too. We just have to have some faith that counsellors know what they are doing.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move amendment No. 15:

SPEECH.PARA: 15.Clause 31, page 17, omit proposed subsection 60B(1), substitute the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "(1) The objects of this Part are:

TAB.TAB: (a)to promote the best interests of children and in particular to ensure that children receive adequate and proper parenting to help them achieve their full potential, and to ensure that parents fulfil their duties, and meet their responsibilities, concerning the care, welfare and development of their children; and
(b)to ensure safety from family violence.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment makes two amendments to part VII of the bill, dealing with children. The first restates the fundamental principle that the welfare of children is the paramount consideration. Presently, this section appears to suggest that parental responsibility is the paramount consideration. Insertion of the object concerning the need to ensure safety from family violence makes the object descriptive of the contents of the part. Part VII includes division 11, referring to family violence. This amendment obviously is directed again at making the objectives of the bill transparent for all parties dealing with the legislation. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some difficulty with the suggested amendment. I think we would all agree that to ensure safety from family violence is an absolutely important and essential element of any aspect of family law legislation. As I read the objects of the part `to promote the best interests of children and in particular to ensure that children receive adequate and proper parenting', I would have thought those words, as of necessity, would have meant that if family violence were to occur children would not be receiving adequate and proper parenting.

PARA.TAB: All that Senator Spindler is doing is adding an example of a type of behaviour that would indicate that children are not receiving proper parenting. Whilst I agree with that, why don't we also add in protection from child abuse or protection from a father who might gamble away all the income of the family, so that the children do not have to live in poverty, or ensure that the children are properly fed, that the children are properly clothed, or that the children's spiritual needs are met? A whole host of other examples could be raised.

Whilst I agree with the motive of Senator Spindler in moving the amendment, I think in a way it detracts from child welfare in total because there would be nearly the suggestion that if you want to promote the best interests of the child all you have to ensure is that there is no family violence. Sure, we do not want to see family violence, but I do not think we want to have a specific clause which, in effect, detracts from the generality and the importance of ensuring that a child's welfare in total is looked after. I would be interested to hear Senator Spindler's reason for only picking on family violence as opposed to all the other matters that I have referred to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motivation is simply to ensure that the bill as it stands pays sufficient regard to the dangers inherent in a situation where family violence has been part of the history. Certainly, we have received submissions from diverse women's organisations concerned about the aspects of family violence and concerned that they are not adequately covered in the bill as it stands. It is on that basis that the amendment is put forward. I think by emphasising that and ensuring that it is dealt with, one does not in any way devalue or exclude other considerations that are relevant to the child's welfare.

—I just wish to endorse the remarks made by Senator Abetz so that Senator Spindler understands that Senator Abetz is not alone in what he has to say. For those reasons, we will not be supporting the amendments. Also, I invite Senator Spindler to consider whether some of these amendments which go to the same areas could be moved as a block.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was conscious of the need to move some of these amendments in a block. However, I moved that one separately because I have had some indication that the coalition may consider supporting the next one, No. 16. For that reason I did not want to put it together with others. I move amendment No. 16:

SPEECH.PARA: 16.Clause 31, page 17, proposed subsection 60B(2), omit all words before paragraph (a), substitute:
"(2) The principles underlying these objects are that, except when it is or would be contrary to a child's best interests:".

This amendment ensures that the best interests of the child are taken into account and are considered when other matters are under discussion and are being decided. I commend this amendment to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the same reasons Senator Abetz spelt out before, the government opposes this amendment as well. I suggest to Senator Spindler that we do try to package some of these because we are talking, for instance in the last couple of amendments, about the rights of the child and they could have been brought together. My anticipation was that we would in fact be dealing with Democrat amendments 1 to 24 together. So if you could be a bit more lateral and maybe bring a bundle together, we would appreciate that.

—Minister, what substantive change would be made, if any? I know that you said that you oppose it for the same reasons I gave in relation to the last amendment but, with respect, the child's best interests, as I understand it, are a paramount consideration throughout the consideration of the Family Law Act. As I understand it, what Senator Spindler is saying is, `the principles underlying these objects are'—and then they are listed—`except when it is or would be contrary to the child's best interests'.

PARA.TAB: I am not sure that, legally, it would add anything to the legislation and it seems to me somewhat unnecessary, but I would not necessarily put it into the same category as the last amendment. At this stage, I am still in a state of flux as to whether or not to support the amendment. I would just be interested to hear the minister's explanation to ascertain whether or not this actually does make any legal or significant difference to the operation of this section.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My point was, as in respect of the previous amendment, that there are specific parts of the legislation already taking into account the sorts of factors Senator Spindler wants to raise. Of course, you are right in respect of everything but for maintenance, but the point is that much of what Senator Spindler does want to raise has been accommodated elsewhere.

—I put it to the minister: the nub of the Democrat amendment here is the insertion, which is being sought by the Democrats, of the proviso `except when it is or would be contrary to a child's best interests'. Does that detract from or have any nullifying effect on the principles stated in 2(a) to 2(d)? Alternatively, does it enhance the operation of those subsections by providing to the court some assistance, saying, `Look, these are the principles, but they are only the principles if they do not contradict the best interests of the child.' Where is the detriment in putting that in there?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I think you probably are aware of the background to this. The Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee did consider the principles outlined in the proposed legislation and did not recommend the change that Senator Spindler is recommending; it recommended a like amendment to subsection 60B(2)(b), which the government agreed to.

PARA.TAB: I think that amendment was the one which was more attractive to you as a committee. That amendment, moved and agreed to, I think reflects the proper balance in the structure of the objective section. What you are looking for in terms of the committee's recommendations is already reflected in 60B(2)(b).

TALK.START.PARA: —I would point out that the clause we are trying to amend, 60B(2)(a), says that children have the right to know and be cared for by both their parents. It is this edict which we are referring to. The amendment says `except when it is in the best interests of the child.' Former partners or separating partners could interpret it and say, `Well, it says here that the children are now to be cared for by both their parents.' It seemed to us, the Democrats, and to people who have made representations to us, that that needs to be qualified—that there can be situations where that is not in the best interests of the child. Certainly, a situation where there is a history of family violence would be one example of that.

PARA.TAB: This amendment seeks to simply open up for consideration this right to know and be cared for by both parents of the child. I trust that Senator Vanstone is taking in what I am saying: this unequivocal statement needs to be qualified; that sometimes it may not be in the interests of the child to be cared for and to know both their parents—to know in the sense that they have constant contact with them. I believe that it is yet another situation where a safeguard is necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to put on the public record the position of the Greens in relation to this. We support all of the Democrats amendments on the basis that they are putting in very valuable clauses that protect the interests of the child.

PARA.TAB: We have a particular concern, which we will raise in our own amendments later, that these points need to be made explicit in the legislation rather than to have parts of the bill ignore them, even though the minister has said he believes that they are implied or even stated in other parts. Just to ease the speed of the debate, I will not be rising to each of these amendments. But I would say that we support this amendment and all other amendments that the Democrats are putting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the government is not 100 per cent persuaded that this is a better amendment or that it is not harmless or whatever other description the minister chooses to put on it. But we think it has got some merit, that it is an improvement and that it does not cause any difficulty vis-a-vis the amendments we have moved thus far. On that basis, we will support Senator Spindler's amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Although we do not like it and we would prefer not to have it, we can live with this amendment. So we will agree to it as well.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 17.Clause 31, page 17, omit proposed paragraph 60B(2)(d), substitute:

PARA.TAB: "(d)it is desirable that parents agree, and where appropriate take steps to reach agreement, on the future parenting of their children.".

SPEECH.PARA: 18.Clause 31, page 21, proposed subsection 60D(1), definition of "family violence order", omit all words after "Territory".

Amendment No. 17 provides that parents should be encouraged to reach agreement only where it is appropriate in the circumstances. This recognises that in some situations—for example, as I have said before, where there is a history or a risk of family violence—pressure to reach agreement is unhelpful and in the worst situations could expose one or more of the parties to violence. Amendment No. 18 improves the definition of `family violence' by deleting the unnecessary words: `to protect a person from family violence'. I have been advised that this is advisable because the definition of `family violence' differs between state and Commonwealth law. The amendment will avoid confusion and reduce the chance that the operation will have limited effect.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In agreeing to the previous amendment of Senator Spindler, we should also now rescind our adoption of government amendment No. 10, which went to the same principle as Senator Spindler's amendment. Can I ask that I be given leave to recommit government amendment No. 10. In asking for it to be recommitted, I indicate that we will vote against that amendment.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
Government amendment No. 10 recommitted.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 19.Clause 31, page 26, omit proposed section 61B, substitute the following section:
"61B. In this Part, "parental responsibility" in relation to a child means:

TAB.TAB: (a)all the duties, powers and responsibilities associated with the day-to-day care, welfare and development of the child (`day-to-day parental responsibility'); and
(b)all the duties, powers and responsibilities associated with the long term care, welfare and development of the child (`long term parental responsibility').".

SPEECH.PARA: 20.Clause 31, page 26, proposed section 61C, line 11, omit the section heading, substitute the following section heading:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Each parent has parental responsibility (subject to court orders and any relevant provisions in a registered child agreement or a registered parenting plan)

SPEECH.PARA: 21.Clause 31, page 26, omit proposed subsection 61C(3), substitute:
"(3) Subsection (1) has effect subject to:

TAB.TAB: (a)any order of a court for the time being in force (whether or not made before or after the commencement of this section); or
(b)any provision in a registered child agreement (made prior to the commencement of this section); or
(c)any provision in a registered parenting plan.".

SPEECH.PARA: 22.Clause 31, page 26, omit proposed section 61D, substitute the following section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Parental responsibility orders and parental responsibility

SPEECH.PARA: "61D.(1) A parental responsibility order or the parental responsibility provisions of a registered child agreement or of a registered parenting plan, confers parental responsibility for a child only to the extent specifically stated in the order or provision.
"(2) Parental responsibility for a child continues except to the extent (if any):

TAB.TAB: (a)expressly provided for in the order, or a provision in a registered child agreement or a provision in a registered parenting plan; or
(b)necessary to give effect to the order or provision.".

SPEECH.PARA: In the view of the Democrats, these amendments describe what constitutes parental responsibility more clearly than the bill currently does. To simply state that each separating parent has parental responsibility is not enough. That may only encourage separating parents to assert their right to parental responsibility in ways that may not be in the best interests of the child. Therefore, these amendments set out what types of parental responsibilities there are.

PARA.TAB: Section 61B of the bill is deleted and replaced with a definition of parental responsibility which is more descriptive. It provides for day-to-day parental responsibility which comprises all the duties, powers and responsibilities associated with the day-to-day care, welfare and development of the child and long-term parental responsibility which deals with the duties, powers and responsibilities associated with the long-term care, welfare and development of the child. Amendment No. 21 provides that, in proposed subsection 61C(3), parental responsibility for the child continues only subject to a court order or any provision in a child agreement or a registered parenting plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having previously risen to say that we support all of the Democrats' amendments—and we had up to that point—I rise now to say that the Greens have a little difficulty with amendment Nos 19 to 22. We feel they are unnecessary and state something which possibly should be obvious or may need to be varied in some situations. The Greens will oppose these amendments unless we can be persuaded—and I would be glad to hear from Senator Spindler in this regard—that they add some protection or do not impose some kind of inflexibility that might work in a counter-productivity direction to that which you obviously would want.

—In answer to Senator Chamarette's concerns, I refer her to the actual wording of the amendment which we suggest is more clearly descriptive. I do not think it is detailed enough to be limiting, but it does clearly define the day-to-day as against the long-term parental responsibility and it provides that it is obviously subject to court orders and any relevant provisions in a registered child agreement or parenting plan. It leaves the way open for flexibility. I would think that it provides us with a more detailed definition rather than a general statement which could create in the minds of some parents rights which may not be in the best interests of the child.

—I disagree with the amendments that have been moved by Senator Spindler. In one substantive amendment, if I am reading it correctly, Senator Spindler will delete the word `authority' in proposed section 61B. It currently reads in part that parental responsibility in relation to a child means all the duties, powers, responsibilities and authorities which by law parents have in relation to children. If you look up the word `authority', I know it is bit old fashioned, you find it means the right to determine, adjudicate or otherwise settle issues of dispute.

PARA.TAB: I know that my wife, mainly, and I sometimes have to settle disputes when our two boys want to play with Thomas the Tank Engine at the same time. Somebody is called in to settle those disputes. It is appropriate to have somebody with authority to settle those disputes. Sure it is not the jackboots-type stuff that Senator Spindler is calling for, but, in order to get rid of some of the disputes that little children have, a degree of authority is required. I think it is appropriate to leave that in the legislation.

As I understand it—and the minister might be able to assist me on this—there are some common law rights attached to parental rights or responsibilities. As I understand Senator Spindler's amendment, they would then all be—I might be reading this incorrectly because I am just skimming through it—set out in proposed section 61B. I am not sure that that is necessarily a desirable course in relation to proposed subsection 61C(3). I really think it adds to the length of the legislation and does not really add anything more. I therefore will oppose it. They are the only comments I wish to make at this stage.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 23.Clause 31, page 30, proposed paragraph 63B(a), line 7 and 8, omit all words after "child", substitute "where agreement is possible and desirable; and".

This amends the clause which encourages parents to reach agreement. It simply seeks to add the words `where agreement is possible and desirable' to indicate that it may not always be possible to leave the power to agree simply with the separating partners without careful consideration of the interests of the child.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate agreement and support for this amendment. We believe it is needed on the basis of the cautionary principle. We think it is best to have some of those statements made in the legislation.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 24.Clause 31, page 30, proposed paragraph 63C(2)(c), line 19, at the end, add "without limiting or varying the operation of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989;".

The amendment seeks to ensure that the effect of the Child Support (Assessment) Act is not limited by the provisions of a parenting plan because in clause 31, page 30, line 19, we say that the parenting plan may provide for the maintenance of a child. The Democrats wanted to make sure that the provisions of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 are not limited in any way. Again I understand that the coalition is considering support for that, but I would be interested in hearing the minister's view. If the Child Support (Assessment) Act remains paramount in all cases, this amendment may not be necessary.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's position is close to your last point, Senator Spindler. Ensuring that parenting plans are not used to circumvent the provisions of the Child Support (Assessment) Act is, we believe, adequately dealt with in the bill. The amendment, for instance, does not take into account subsection 63F(5) which provides that a provision of a parenting plan which deals with child maintenance has no effect if an application for an assessment of child support could be made under the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989. This ensures that parenting plans cannot be used to limit or vary the operation of the act. So we would maintain that your amendment is unnecessary.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have now reached my amendment which was numbered 25 originally. It was discussed at great length by the parties. I have circulated and moved earlier today an amendment which I believe represents the agreement that the parties have reached. This might be a good point at which to deal with it.
—I am sorry, I do not have that amendment. I do not know when you moved it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I can assist. Senator Spindler read it out at the start of play today. My understanding is that Senator Vanstone has an amendment to which Senator Spindler will move a further amendment. My further understanding is that we have all agreed to accept Senator Vanstone's amendment with Senator Spindler's addendum. I suggest that we accept Senator Vanstone's amendment first and then accept Senator Spindler's amendment. Given the fact that we spoke about this for three hours on another occasion, we do not have to get into a big debate now.

—Senator Spindler may have a different version of events, but my version is very close to that which is offered by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), with one exception. This matter ought to be put on the record. We all know about it because we were party to the discussions, but those people reading Hansard might not. Following the last very lengthy discussion in this place, we asked whether there was some way we could resolve this matter without taking up the committee's time and then clearly put a position down. That is what we have, sort of, come to.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler will understand that, while I have understood and agreed, as I am sure the Hansard record shows, that it is appropriate for people to have some legal advice before they enter into an agreement which they want registered in the court—after all, parents of intact families and parents of separated families are entitled to make whatever arrangements they would like to with respect to their children—once they register one of those agreed arrangements and give it the imprimatur of a court, it is then appropriate for them to have at least some legal advice. I think Senator Spindler would agree with that.

I have a difference of opinion with respect to counsellors. I am not at all sure they are the appropriate people for this situation. I do not think they are badly motivated, but they are not legally trained and they do not have experience in looking at the range of orders that are accepted by the court or what variations someone might be successful in getting. For example, the weaker party—generally speaking, the female—may well need to be advised that, in the experience of the practitioner, she could have more holiday time, every other Christmas or something, with the children. A practitioner who is day after day churning through what we now call custody cases will have much more experience with that than a counsellor.

In order to make the record clear, consistent with the Hansard record—my having expressed that view on our part before—what I have asked to be done, and I believe it has been done, has been to take the amendment to the stage where we thought that it would end up. I am seeking to withdraw the amendment that we have moved, just get rid of it—we got into too much trouble; it was like a dark and murky swamp—and replace it with this amendment.

I understand that Senator Spindler will get up and say, `It is an outrage; counsellors should be included,' and I will mumble and say that they should not be. I think that there will be agreement over there that that should happen, and we will end up where we want to be. That is a fair description of what will happen. If Senator Spindler can give me an indication of whether he is happy with that or not, I will move this amendment.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Reynolds)—I understand that before we can consider the proposed amendment Senator Spindler needs to withdraw his original amendment No. 25 and Senator Vanstone needs to withdraw her amendment, and then Senator Vanstone can move on to the new agreed amendment. You each have to withdraw your original amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to withdraw my original amendment. However, earlier today I moved and read into the record an amendment which I believe reflects the agreement that we have reached, and that does include the provision for counselling. I suggest that if Senator Vanstone does not agree with that she can now move an amendment to seek to remove that. I believe it is the amendment that, after consultation, we have agreed upon. I have read it into the record.
—Senator Spindler, I am wondering whether you could assist us by simply withdrawing your original amendment and then Senator Vanstone can withdraw her amendment, and then we can come back to you.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not want Senator Spindler to withdraw the amendment he moved this morning. We want him to withdraw his previous amendment. Senator Vanstone had three previous amendments. If we can wipe the slate clean of those, Senator Spindler's amendment stays alive, Senator Vanstone's amendment—which I suppose is a carrying amendment—stays alive as well, and then Senator Spindler's amendment will be put to Senator Vanstone's amendment and we will all be happy, I hope.
—I am certainly happy to withdraw my original amendment. I am not happy to withdraw the amendment that I moved this morning.
—No, that is fine.

—Senator Spindler, I have just been advised that the amendment you moved this morning is different from what we had agreed to, which is what is in the Vanstone amendment. You can move what you want this morning; we agree with Senator Vanstone's amendment. You can do what you like with yours; we will support the Vanstone one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I can make this clear. Senator Spindler, I understand that we all have bright ideas at the last minute; but the whole purpose of the meetings we had when we moved out of this chamber was so as not to get into some dark, slimy swamp with things being done on the run at the last minute, because that is when you make mistakes that have serious consequences. I do not have a copy of what you read into the record this morning. I am sorry, it might have some shining light from Mars that is apparent to everyone else. It is not apparent to me. I am not happy to make amendments on the run. The only cogent reason you have offered—and it is not very cogent—is that you have simply read it out this morning. You participated in these meetings. We have gone to some effort. I have here what was faxed around. I presume it was faxed to you, too, by the Attorney-General's Department.
—I haven't got it.

—Didn't the department fax something to you following our meeting? I believe they did. They certainly faxed it to me on 26 October. The salutation is `Dear all'. One of the `alls', the inclusive, is Mr Townsend in your office. It says, `Attached is a copy of revised clause 63D consequent upon the discussions with the senators this morning.' That is the position we are trying to get to. This is what we will end up with. All I am saying is that I do not want to move it as a whole. But if you want to add in the counsellors, that is your business. I have a revised amendment here to 63D which reflects the agreement.
—He is happy.
—He is happy; okay.
—Senator Vanstone, could you withdraw your original amendment?
—I withdraw such that you wish me to withdraw.
—And then you can move the subsequent amendment.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 31, page 30, proposed section 63D, lines 31 to 35, omit the section, substitute the following section:

PARA.TAB: " `63D.(1) Subject to this section, a parenting plan may be registered in a court having jurisdiction under this Part.
'(2) To apply for registration of a parenting plan:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)an application for registration of the plan must be lodged in accordance with the Rules of Court; and
(b)the application must be accompanied by:
(i)a copy of the plan; and
(ii)the information required by the Rules of Court; and

(iii)a statement, in relation to each party, that is to the effect that the party has been provided with independent legal advice as to the meaning and effect of the plan and that is signed by the practitioner who provided that advice.

PARA.TAB: '(3) The court may register the plan if it considers it appropriate to do so having regard to the best interests of the child to which the plan relates. In determining whether it is appropriate to register the plan, the court:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)must have regard to the information accompanying the application for registration; and
(b)may, but is not required to, have regard to all or any of the matters set out in subsection 68F(2).

PARA.TAB: '(4) The Rules of Court:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)must prescribe what information is to accompany an application for registration of a parenting plan; and
(b)may prescribe other matters relating to the procedures for registration.".

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to have this perfectly clear as well. I have been trying to follow the debate. I have a two-page document in the name of Senator Vanstone.
—That's the one.
—That is the one. I then have another document which I was told by you, Minister, was going to be an amendment to Senator Vanstone's proposed amendment.
—I got it wrong.
—You got it wrong. So I can screw this bit of paper up. We are therefore dealing only with the Senator Vanstone amendment.
—Senator Spindler is happy with it as well, so we can put it to the vote.
—In other words, counsellors now will no longer be involved; is that right?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was right the first time.
—So I better unscrew this bit of paper.
—Unscrew that bit of paper. We will move Senator Vanstone's amendment. What I said earlier on was right: we do need Senator Spindler's amendment as well.
—Not necessarily the one he moved this morning.
—No.
—I seek to clarify this. Senator Vanstone moved this two-page amendment. I understand this single page was going to be moved by Senator Spindler as an amendment to Senator Vanstone's amendment.
—But it is currently in Senator Vanstone's name.
—No. It says, `Amendments to be moved by Senator ( ), to Senator Vanstone's amendment.' I thought we were going to insert Senator Spindler's name in there.
—Yes, we are. You are right.
—In that case, I think I may have cleared up some confusion there. Therefore we should be dealing with—
—Senator Vanstone's amendment is now before the chair. You were seeking to clarify the situation.
—Is Senator Spindler now moving his amendment?
—He might, if you sit down.
—Senator Spindler, I am advised that you referred to your amendment earlier this morning but you did not actually move it. I do not know whether that helps or hinders the situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I have moved it, I am happy to withdraw it to clean the slate. The problem I had was that I was not in receipt of this document which—following the two amendments: one by Senator Vanstone and one which I will move—will actually in substance produce what I have read into the record this morning.

PARA.TAB: My problem was simply that I did not have before me Senator Vanstone's amendment. Since Senator Vanstone has moved her amendment, I think it is probably appropriate that I move my amendment to her amendment and then the chamber can vote on the amended Vanstone amendment. Accordingly, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vanstone's proposed new section 63D, omit paragraph (2)(b), substitute:
"(b)the application must be accompanied by a copy of the plan, the information required by the Rules of Court, and:

(i)a statement, in relation to each party, that is to the effect that the party has been provided with independent legal advice as to the meaning and effect of the plan and that is signed by the practitioner who provided that advice; or
(ii)a statement to the effect that the plan was developed after consultation with a family and child counsellor (as defined in section 4) and that is signed by the counsellor.".

PARA.TAB: Amendment (Senator Spindler's) agreed to.
Amendment (Senator Vanstone's), as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a very brief comment in relation to this. I did not vote against the amendment, but I will just state my objection in principle to it. If parties can resolve their difficulties between themselves and come to the court, they should have the right to approach the court in person and obtain the benefit of court orders without the need to engage either lawyers or counsellors.

PARA.TAB: I know that there are arguments either side, but I happen to believe in the principle that people ought to have access to the justice system without the need to engage lawyers. I think they are stupid if they do not engage lawyers and I would encourage them to do so, but they ought to have the right to approach the court.

I know that in previous times people could do so in relation to custody and access matters. They could appear before the court in person and get orders from the court in person. I would have thought it only appropriate that that general regime be allowed to continue. I will not delay the chamber any further because I think I am in a minority group of one on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have arrived at the situation that we wanted to get to. I hope it is abundantly clear to all those who have insomnia and read Hansard that we did not agree with the inclusion of counsellors, but we simply chose not to waste the Senate's time with a division on what would have been inevitable. That is where we have ended up and now we can move on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 26.Clause 31, pages 32 to 54, proposed Divisions 5 and 6, omit "Parenting Orders" and "Parenting Order", wherever occurring, substitute "Parental Responsibility Orders" or "Parental Responsibility Order", as the case may be.
27.Clause 31, page 33, omit proposed subsection 64B(2), substitute:
"(2) The parental responsibility orders which may be made under this Part are:

TAB.TAB: (a)a long term parental responsibility order;
(b)a day to day parental responsibility order;
(c)a visiting parental responsibility order;
(d)a child maintenance order.".

SPEECH.PARA: 28.Clause 31, page 33, omit proposed subsections 64B(3), (4), (5), (6), (7) and (8), substitute:
"(3) Subject to such conditions or variations as may be ordered by the court, when the court makes an order for long term parental responsibility the order means that the relevant person or persons:

TAB.TAB: (a)is to undertake long term parental responsibility for the child; and
(b)has parental responsibility for decisions concerning the long term care, welfare and development of the child.

SPEECH.PARA: "(4) Subject to such conditions or variations as may be ordered by the court, when the court makes an order for day-to-day parental responsibility the order means that the relevant person or persons:

TAB.TAB: (a)is to undertake day-to-day parental responsibility for the child; and
(b)has parental responsibility for day-to-day decisions concerning the residence, care, welfare and development of the child.

SPEECH.PARA: "(5) Subject to such conditions or variations as may be ordered by the court, when the court makes an order for visiting parental responsibility the order means that the relevant person or persons:

TAB.TAB: (a)is to undertake day-to-day parental care for the child during the visiting period, or periods, specified; and
(b)that the person has responsibility for the day-to-day decisions concerning the care, welfare and development of the child during the visiting period or periods specified.".

SPEECH.PARA: 29.Clause 31, page 33, omit section 64C, substitute the following section:
"64C. The parental responsibility orders referred to in subsection 64B(2):

TAB.TAB: (a)may be made in relation to a parent of the child or some other person; and
(b)may be made in relation to any person or any two or more persons jointly (whether or not that person or any of those persons is a parent of the child).".

SPEECH.PARA: 30.Clause 31, page 58, proposed paragraph 67J(1)(a), line 13, after "the person has", insert "or has access to".
31.Clause 31, page 59, proposed paragraph 67M(2), line 3, after "is likely to have", insert "or be able to obtain".
These amendments relate to the definitions that I have previously offered on long-term, day-to-day and visiting parental responsibility orders. I commend them to the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 32.Clause 31, page 59, proposed subsection 67M(4), at the end, add "or such longer period as the court considers appropriate".

I have singled this amendment out because I understood that there was a view that the coalition may support this particular amendment. It adds the words `or such longer period as the court considers appropriate'. Amendment No. 32 provides the court with the ability to extend the length of time for which a location order may be effective when it is appropriate to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, there seems to be some merit in this amendment. We would be grateful if the minister would outline why he is reluctant to accept it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the amendment. We would like to have a situation where there is certainty in terms of the period of location orders. That is reflected in the legislation as it now is. Senator Spindler's amendment would provide a capacity for location orders to last for a longer time and for different periods, which in itself would give rise to confusion.

PARA.TAB: We also believe that, if a person has complied or has not been able to comply with the location order over a 12-month period, it is unlikely that they would do so over a longer period. If there is still reason to believe that information may come to them about the child's location, then another order can be obtained. In practice, orders requiring a person to do something over a period longer than 12 months are likely to be ineffective, as the time period is certainly too long for people to remain aware of the importance and the effect of such orders. As I have said, if there is a need for a continuation, then a further order can be obtained. That has a trigger effect of reminding people of the existence of the order after 12 months as opposed to having a longer period of application.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the minister for his comments; however, I am not convinced by them. I think the Democrat amendment provides for a court which is seized of sufficient evidence on the facts before it to make an order which could perhaps go longer than 12 months and save people having to come back to court and go through the process again. I understand the minister to have said that after 12 months you get the parties back again and the matter is considered again. I think it is desirable in all cases for there to be finality about matters as much as possible to save the parties having to come back after 12 months. I cannot see any prejudice in the location order staying in force for 12 months or such longer period as the court thinks fit.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the fact that the opposition is inclined to support this amendment, the government will not resist.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 33.Clause 31, page 59, proposed subsection 67N(4), line 36, omit all words after "considers", substitute "that it is necessary to do so in the best interests of the child".
This amendment is designed to bring the focus back to the best interests of the child.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 34.Clause 31, page 60, proposed subsection 67N(9), line 19, after "3 months", add "unless specifically so ordered by the court".

This particular amendment gives the court the ability to order a search more frequently than once every three months, especially in cases of grave concern for the welfare of the child. It is my understanding that the opposition is at least considering supporting this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler is very well informed. You have the opportunity, Minister, to indicate why this would be an inappropriate amendment because, on the face of it, it does not appear to be.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of this amendment, I will say what I said in respect of amendment No. 32: the government will try to make this amendment work.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 35.Clause 31, page 60, proposed subsection 67P(1), line 41, omit the Penalty.

This amendment removes the threat of criminal sanctions against registrars for the intentional or reckless disclosure of information. The Democrats are of the view that such behaviour certainly is highly undesirable and there must be sanctions. But we are not convinced of the need to threaten registrars with such draconian penalties. Once again, I am informed that the coalition may support this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a lot of these issues there are differences of opinion within the community and probably between that side of the chamber and this side, but on balance we have enough people who think that the government' proposal is an inappropriate move. Consequently, we will support Senator Spindler's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the chamber that the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, in its report handed down in March this year, recommended in recommendation 1 that this provision be deleted—that is, the provision for the imprisonment of registrars. I think the Australian Democrats amendment is a thoroughly sound one.

PARA.TAB: The Chief Justice of the Family Court, Mr Justice Nicholson, strongly criticised this proposal by the government. His Honour stated before the committee:

SPEECH.PARA: The penalty is both unnecessary and objectionable. The court objects strongly to it and points out that such a sanction is found nowhere else in the Family Law Act. The capacity in which registrars will often deal with this type of information is in the exercise of delegated judicial power, and it is particularly inappropriate that those with such power be liable to a criminal sanction arising out of its exercise. Under the court staff structure, registry managers and not registrars have line responsibility for registry staff and so for the recording and storage of court records. The registrar to whom this sanction would apply consequently has no capacity to direct the secure receipt, storage and handling of the information. Given the sensitive nature of the court's records, it is illogical that there be a criminal sanction in respect to the treatment of one type of information alone.
I think His Honour summed it up eloquently and succinctly. I take the matter no further other than to say that to provide for the imprisonment of judicial officers is indeed a very serious step.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is concerned that Senator Spindler's amendment might get up. We are concerned that we would then have a situation where the intentional reckless disclosure of sensitive information could go on without the possibility of imprisonment in the most serious cases. We think there is a need for a message to be given that, for instance, in terms of intentional or reckless disclosure of such information, the law sees such disclosures as criminal offences and wants to treat them with the response that would involve criminal action. We are concerned that, by your supporting the Spindler amendment, there will not be any such sanction in place.

PARA.TAB: I ask you, Senator Vanstone, to maybe reconsider your position, given the all-embracing nature of conduct which would escape from the operation of the law. I wonder whether you would consider, for instance, looking at Senator Chamarette's amendment, which, though not embracing criminal sanctions, does substitute fines for the penalty of imprisonment. That course of action is one that should be attractive to you, given that we are moving in such a way that, when you contemplate both intentional and reckless disclosure of sensitive information without sanction, I think goes a bit far down that route. So I wonder whether you would consider the Senator Chamarette midway option. It is one that the government would be prepared to consider as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just while I turn my mind further to that and have a discussion with my colleagues, perhaps you can outline for us the occasions on which registrars have intentionally or recklessly released information and what steps the court has taken. Here we are with a proposal being put to lock registrars up, and this is coming from the Labor Party. This is the sort of thing you would expect the Labor Party to say—that those people in my party who are of a more conservative persuasion than me would want to do that. This is what Labor always says about the conservative parties and the Liberal Party—that they always want to lock people up.

PARA.TAB: Here you are with a response to something to lock them up, lock them up, lock them up. Perhaps you might inform the chamber of what ill-behaviour you are aware of that occasions you to want to pass such an amendment. I understand about the need to protect privacy. With the greatest respect, there are numerous examples of where your government or the civil service that supports your government has not been successful.

No doubt no government can be 100 per cent successful, but the privacy of information held by the government, by government instrumentalities, by courts, is of course vital and has to be protected—particularly, one might say, in these sorts of matters. Before we rush in and say let us lock registrars up, perhaps we can have outlined some examples and what steps have been taken by the government and the court thus far against the flocks and flocks of registrars who, out of ignorance or bad faith, have let the side down.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us just look at what we are dealing with here. Proposed section 67P(1) deals with information with respect to location orders. Secondly, it covers not just the conduct of registrars. I can read out the relevant section to you. It refers to the conduct of a registrar or conduct of any other person who obtains information, whether directly or indirectly, and whether under this section or otherwise. So we are dealing with a group of people broader than that of registrars. We are dealing with a group of people which includes those who have the information, both legally and illegally, and we are talking essentially here about location orders.

PARA.TAB: You asked me to talk about circumstances in which family law information has been disclosed by people. I do not want to take up a free kick but yesterday afternoon we had in this place Senator Crichton-Browne complaining about family law information in his case being leaked. I place that on the record without going into that; otherwise he would probably come in and take up the next half-hour or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wasn't the Family Court at all.

—We are talking about family law information. While you were talking to your colleagues over there, Senator Vanstone, I made the point that what we are talking about here is, as opposed to the Crichton-Browne situation, information about location orders. We understand how important, critical and sensitive that information is. Secondly, not only are we talking about the registrar, but under proposed section 67P we are talking about any other person who obtains that information as well.

PARA.TAB: So you can accuse us of being quick to try to dump people in prison, but we are talking about information about the location of a child. Information about the location of a child, if it is released in contravention of this act, could very easily place at risk the child or the other parent. So we are talking about extremely sensitive information. To let that through to the keeper without a sanction is something which I do not think this chamber should be into. That is why I suggested that, while you may not like imprisonment, the Chamarette midway option of a fine should be attractive to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I did not hear everything you said but I did have one ear turned. I wonder whether you have some examples of where registrars of family courts have released information that they should not have. Perhaps while you are turning your mind to that you could also indicate what the penalties would be under the Public Service Act for release of such information should you have the will to pursue it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am obviously not in a position to be able to identify an individual case where this might have happened. I am advised that there have been cases. Without identifying them, I would rather leave it rest there.

PARA.TAB: I also place on record the fact that the Family Law Council has recommended the imposition of this sort of penalty. I acknowledge that there are provisions under the Public Service Act, but I think what we are trying to do in this legislation is to send a message that we just see it as an administrative type of offence. For instance, the Family Law Council has recommended the imposition of a penalty. In its report in relation to the power of the Family Court to require the provision of information for the recovery of children just a couple of years ago the council endorsed the proposal that a penalty of some $12,000 or two years imprisonment or both be imposed for the unauthorised disclosure of information obtained under the equivalent provision at the time.

In making its recommendation, the council's report noted acceptance of the proposal by the Family Court of WA, the New South Wales Bar Association and the Privacy Commissioner. Further, in its letter of advice on the operation of the UK Children's Act 1989, the council recommended that amendments to the act in relation to obtaining information should provide for a penalty for unauthorised disclosure. There is a body of opinion that would demand that we do respond with some sort of sanction under this act. That is why I asked you to reconsider particularly the fine as opposed to imprisonment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the minister: what is meant in 67P(1)(c), where it says `a process server engaged by or by an officer of the court or another court', by `or by an officer of'? That was one problem that the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee could not really come to terms with. It was something which I thought was not quite clear.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that that subclause refers to the administration of process serving by the court. Obviously, if a process is to be served, the information has to be made available to a process server or by an officer of the court. That is what we are talking about there; we are not talking about any wide dissemination for any reason other than the serving of process.

—Perhaps the minister can also assist with this. I do not have a copy of the Crimes Act with me. What is a penalty unit under the Crimes Act? Were we of a mind to look at the Greens' amendment, what would be the equivalent of 120 penalty units?
—It is $12,000. The penalty unit is $100.

—I have been out of the chamber, but I have had somebody following the debate. My understanding is that the minister is of a mind to support the Greens' amendment, which seeks to remove the penalty and substitute the penalty units, whereas Senator Spindler's amendment, which we are considering now, seeks to remove the penalty altogether. This leads me to wonder whether the Greens have got it wrong because it is so unusual. If there was some argument and support for removing the penalty altogether, I would have to reconsider that. My understanding was that that would be unlikely.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, it would be preferable to do what the Greens do routinely on all similar clauses—that is, we do not believe imprisonment should be put in legislation because it fosters the idea that prison is the penalty of first resort rather than of last resort and implies that it operates in some way as a deterrent. We are not opposed to penalties per se, but we are opposed to prison being thrown around and fostering in the minds of the community the feeling that somehow having a prison penalty will make people into law-abiding citizens when we know that to be untrue.

The point we got to in considering the Democrats' amendment was that the support for it was urged upon us by a member of the judiciary on the basis that it would be an affront to the staff of the court to have any penalties. We do not necessarily agree with that, but we think that to use prison as a penalty is inappropriate and that a fine structure would be preferable. I hope that explains to the opposition where we are coming from. I would not want them to not consider the merits of Senator Spindler's argument, even though we have a slight preference towards ours and we are very pleased to see that the government is indicating some openness to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was wondering whether I could ask the minister for some legal definition of the word `recklessly' for the purpose of this section. What sort of conduct would be caught by the term `intentionally'? You have to have the mental intent—in other words, to deliberately provide the information to somebody. There could be a circumstance where a registrar might inadvertently, but nevertheless recklessly, disclose some information. I was just wondering what the test would be for somebody to stand convicted of recklessly disclosing the information, the subject of this clause.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The definition of the term `reckless' has been the subject of thousands of court cases in its criminal meaning. For me to give you a dissertation on the term `reckless' would take hours. In fact, I can remember having lecture after lecture about the definition of `reckless' at criminal law. There is a definition of `recklessness' at criminal law; that definition would be applied here.
—It would be criminal recklessness?
—Yes.

—In formal discussion in the chamber, as well as the debate, there appears to be some support for the proposition that there should be some penalty in this situation. To some extent, I am persuaded by these arguments. If it will assist the process, I seek leave to withdraw my amendment to allow Senator Chamarette to move hers.

PARA.TAB: Amendment—by leave—withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was wondering whether the minister could assist us. If somebody is deliberately trading in Family Court information, clearly there ought to be a penalty. However, the chief judge indicated in his reasoning and rationale in opposing this amendment that there were other people below the registrar in the chain of responsibility who might be engaged in this behaviour over which the registrar himself or herself might not necessarily have any jurisdiction—actually, they do have jurisdiction but unbeknown to the registrar that may occur. What would the circumstance be if a court officer somewhere below the position of registrar discloses it, it having been disclosed by the registrar to that person? If we get that chain of events, what would be the liability of the registrar?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I imagine that the registrar's liability would be the same as any vicarious liability under criminal law. It would be separate from the course of action. If the registrar, for instance, did not do so knowingly or recklessly, I would expect that the registrar would be in the clear. I did say to you that the legislation covers not just activities of registrar but other people as individuals separate from their relationship with the court process or in conjunction with it. If the registrar has done nothing wrong but someone else has down the chain, the other person cops the rap if the registrar does not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little unclear as to exactly where we are in the course of the debate. My understanding is that Senator Spindler has withdrawn his amendment and that we are now going to consider Greens amendment No. 5. That amendment proposes that the penalty of imprisonment for two years be omitted and that instead we insert a penalty of 120 penalty units. The reason for this is that we believe that penalties should be used carefully. In this instance the penalty is being used to protect ordinary people who access the court. We do not see any reason why the same kinds of penalties should not be placed on registrars of the court or any officers of the court, in the interests of protecting ordinary citizens who access the court.

PARA.TAB: While we do not agree with the two years imprisonment—we believe it is utterly inappropriate—we believe that having a penalty which will cause the officers of the court to exercise caution in the way they fulfil their duties can be of benefit. I move Greens amendment No. 5:

SPEECH.PARA: 5.Clause 31, page 60, proposed subsection 67P(1), omit the penalty, substitute the following penalty:

PARA.TAB: "Penalty: 120 penalty units.
Note: For the value of a penalty unit, see subsection 4AA(1) of the Crimes Act 1914.".

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the amendment to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, I suggest to the minister that it is not really the registrar who has the responsibility for registry staff dealing with information, records and so on. The Chief Justice of the Family Court has said that, under the court staff structure, registry managers, and not registrars, have line responsibility for registry staff and the recording and storage of court records. Are we not chasing the wrong person?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —You missed my point earlier on. We are chasing any person who is in the web of people having that information and who releases it illegally and in a way which is in contravention of section 67. We are not talking only about the registrar; we are talking of the registrar or any other person. If information is provided to the registrar, of course the registrar has some responsibility, but we acknowledge that it is not just the registrar who is an important cog in this network; any other person may be as well. We are not out to get the registrar, but at the same time we do not want legislation that grabs everybody else but excludes the registrar.

PARA.TAB: The legislation is all encompassing in terms of those who have legitimate rights to information, and we impose on them an obligation to handle that information with care. That is why the registrar is there as well. He or she is the person to whom information is provided. To nab everybody else and exclude them would be a very inconsistent situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps you would be prepared to be of some assistance here. You indicated that there were some examples—that this has happened. Will you give an undertaking to the committee that by a particular time you will give us information with respect to those examples where it has happened?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice was that that had happened, and to the extent that I can get information I will, but I do not think it is all that critical. We are talking about ensuring a regime into the future, and to the extent that officers can provide me with information I will try and get it to you. I am told that we have to be careful about the operation of section 121, which prohibits the identification of matters. I will see what information can be provided. However, I make the point that, with or without that information, there is still a need for this provision.

—I understand the difficulties associated with this, but nonetheless, in the discussion in relation to this matter, you have said you have been advised by officers that this has happened. There must be some information you can give us to verify that. Otherwise we are in the position where, were we to have a bunch of officers of bad faith—which I see we do not have today, though it may happen in the future—someone could come in here and say whatever they liked in relation to the Family Law Act. We would all say, `It's shocking that that has happened,' and take everybody's word for it.

PARA.TAB: On the basis that there have been troubles in the past, you are asking for a law to be passed with serious consequences not just for registrars—though quite properly for registrars—but also for other people who get this information. I am seeking that information from you in the future, following the passage of this bill. This bill will probably be through by lunchtime. I am seeking not only to verify what we have been told but to ascertain what in the past the court has done when this has happened. Do these people still have their jobs? Do people release this information and everybody just says, `You shouldn't have done that.' There are opportunities for disciplinary proceedings under the Public Service Act?Have these been taken up? Have proceedings been pursued? That is the reason that I ask for that information.

My second question concerns my understanding that you have in your brief some information from the past vis-a-vis advice from the Family Law Council seeking such a penalty. I think you mentioned that you were offered that advice. I would be grateful if we could have copies of that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that advice from the Family Law Council was provided in 1992. It was tabled in the parliament and we can gladly get you a copy of that. I am also told in respect of your first request that it will take a bit of time to get the information together but that we will provide it to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was about to warn the minister that if he is providing that information he should be careful that he does not contravene the clause of the bill we are talking about now, which is 67P, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: Information provided to the Registrar of a court under a location order . . . must not, intentionally or recklessly, be disclosed by the Registrar, or by any other person who obtains the information . . .

We are really arguing—if there is any argument, and I am not assuming that the opposition has excluded supporting this amendment—that if we argue against having any penalty at all we are really arguing for privilege of officers of the court and saying that there can be no malicious or intentional errors in this regard because the court is such a safe place.

PARA.TAB: If there have been breaches and they have been followed up, I would be interested to receive any evidence of them.
