But I would be very concerned if the opposition felt that if none could be produced we would not need this clause or the penalty that goes with it. In my view, out in the community there is a suspicion and a fear of court proceedings. If people felt that somehow there were no safeguards on the information and that court officers, of whatever capacity, could act with impunity because there were no penalties, whether they did that or not, it would give apparent grounds for that concern in the community.

For that reason I urge people to support what I believe is a very reasonable amendment. It is removing the penalty of two years imprisonment, which I think could be an affront to the court, because I believe it is using imprisonment in a wrong way. On the other hand, to remove penalties altogether implies that we do not feel that the registrars and the officers within the court who might be associated with the disclosure of information should have any sanctions placed upon them should they breach the trust placed in them. It is a community trust we are talking about and I believe a penalty is worth while, whether it has been pursued in the past or not. Senator Vanstone, I hope you are not saying that you are going to stand back from supporting the amendment until the minister produces the evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—I feel that the amendment is worthy of support whether that evidence is forthcoming or not. In the absence of the evidence, I believe there may be a strong argument to include the penalty, and perhaps raising it in this place may alert people to their responsibilities under the law. Chief Justice Nicholson was the person urging us to do this because he felt it would be an affront to the court staff to imply that anybody would be engaged in that conduct. I am sure he would also want the community to perceive his officers and the officers of the court as being as susceptible to penalties as is anybody in the community; and, as we know very well, penalties of this kind are sprinkled right throughout our legislative system.

—Rereading 67P(1), it appears as though even a judge could potentially fall foul of this legislation if a judge were to become aware of the contents of a location order and then intentionally or recklessly pass that information on. Undoubtedly, the judge would fit into the description `or by any other person who obtains the information'. Chances are if it applies it ought to apply to everybody equally and judges should not be quarantined from that. I suppose that makes sense.

PARA.TAB: What does not make sense to me is that you cannot pass it on to anybody other than somebody who is a registrar of another court, an officer of the court or of another court whose responsibilities or duties include service or execution of process. The assistant to the registrar who might be sitting in court when the location order is made could well become aware of that information. Although he is an officer of the court, I would suggest that person would not necessarily be engaged in service or execution of process on behalf of the court. The typist who in fact would type up the location order would become aware of the information, courtesy of the registrar, but she or he, I would suggest, would not necessarily be involved in the service or execution of process but rather only be involved in the typing up of the order.

Technically, if the information is passed from the registrar to his associate or assistant in court and that assistant or associate is not engaged in the service or execution of the court orders, the registrar would fall foul of that. There is also the possibility that the person who types up the location order will become aware of that information and because the person typing up the process order is not involved in the service or execution of process by the court that person could also fall foul. I hope I have it absolutely wrong, but I would like to have that explained. Somebody is nodding that I have got it all wrong, so I would like to hear why.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Abetz is not trying to delay things. He has asked questions that he is genuinely seeking an answer to. Perhaps, Minister, we can speed things through if we can assist and give Senator Abetz an answer. It seems a little disrespectful, even though we are in the opposition, to just ignore questions put by us, Minister. That is the purpose of the committee stage, for people who might otherwise have concerns to have them ironed out.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the point was an obvious one in a sense, but I will go through it. What we are talking about is the location order once there is a location order. We are also talking about disclosure in a manner which is not part of the authorised legal process. If a person doing their job in preparing the location order is merely doing their job, then they have nothing to worry about. If, however, someone in the office decides to run off with a location order or type up another copy and disseminate it, then that is a bit of a problem.
—That is not what the legislation says, with respect.
—In essence, we are talking about the information which is provided because of the order. So we are talking about information itself which has to be kept secret or controlled.

—I understand that. Without being too laborious, I want to get this straight. A location order being made in the court would not disclose the address but simply would allow certain searches to be undertaken to ascertain where a certain child lived.

PARA.TAB: Having been involved in obtaining such orders, I know that an envelope is then given to the judge usually from the Department of Social Security. It seems to be the quickest way of finding out where kiddies are if they are with their mum. If it is suspected that the mother is on social security, you get an order for Social Security to reveal the information. That information is then given to the judge. It is held on the court file.

If that information is then given to the judge, who opens the envelope? Does the judge himself or herself have to personally open the envelope which reveals the address or can the judge's assistant open the envelope and put it on the judge's desk, for example? Or if afterwards the judge says, `Right, I now have the address; this will proceed appropriately' but he gets somebody else within the court registry simply to file everything, the person who does the filing and has actual physical possession of that location order may not—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order which may clarify Senator Abetz's question. The point of order is that he is not speaking to the amendment. The amendment is to remove the penalty, not to remove the clause. If he has a problem with the clause, he needs to move an entirely different amendment to remove the clause. The only thing we are debating is the removal of one sentence at the bottom of the clause which is the penalty, which is imprisonment, and substitute it with penalty units. If he really is talking to the point, which is the amendment to change the phrasing of the penalty, I think I do have a point or order. I do not make them very often. My point of order is relevance—that what Senator Abetz is saying does not actually apply to the amendment I have moved.

—On the point of order: what we are debating, and have had a wide ranging debate about, is whether the type of behaviour we are talking about is worthy of a criminal sanction. We are then arguing whether it ought be a period of imprisonment or potentially a $12,000 fine. I am just trying to ascertain the type of behaviour that could potentially fall foul of the section and as a result render somebody liable to a $12,000 fine. With respect, I would submit that I have been in order and relevant because the two are interlinked.
—On the point of order: the sort of situation Senator Abetz is referring to will not be captured by the legislation. He does not have to worry about those people.
—Why not?
—I say that in an attempt to circumvent the need for us to have a long debate over the point of order. I am trying to answer your question, if I can do that.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—On the point of order, whilst all three senators are seeking to be very helpful to us in procedure, it has been appropriate for Senator Abetz to speak in the way he has.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The process basically is that the information goes to the registrar and the registrar has responsibility to disseminate it through the court process as and when required. The sorts of situations you are talking about are very much the court processes. The registrar can then pass it on to a judge, judge's chambers or solicitors involved who might have an interest in it. People with a legitimate interest in it are not covered by this particular clause if they act in a way which is in accordance with their responsibilities. If they deviate from that, then you have problems.

—What the minister is trying to say as an answer is that it is for the same reason judges' associates and secretaries do not find themselves in gaol now because the associate told the secretary about the names of parties in a proceeding which the judge was hearing. The associate may have had to tell the judge's secretary about that because it was something to do with the listing order or whatever. That is, nonetheless, conveying to another person the names of parties in a Family Court matter. The reason they are not pursued is that it is a part of their duties and a part of the court process. For that reason an associate or a typist or whatever would not be covered by this, in my view.
—Where are they protected in the Family Law Act? I am happy to accept that as an explanation if somebody can point to the area that provides them with that protection.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will try to find more information, but it is inherent in the fact that the court needs to operate. Inherent in the capacity to operate is the capacity to operate in the way Senator Vanstone has just spelt out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, I do not accept that as an explanation at this stage. If you are simply relying on what has been the practice in the past, that is fine. But you are now trying to change what has happened in the past by a legislative regime and by imposing a criminal sanction. That, therefore, changes what used to be the inherent jurisdiction of the court. If you start fiddling with the common law and have legislative law which impacts on the common law applying to the jurisdiction of the courts, then you have to be aware of the potential consequences of that. This clause says:

SPEECH.PARA: Information provided to the Registrar of a court under a location order . . . must not, intentionally or recklessly, be disclosed by the Registrar, or by any other person who obtains the information . . .

That is very interesting because in some of the smaller registries around the place, I happen to know—I have done it myself—that information provided to the registrar of a court under a location order has in fact been provided to a judge. If the location order information is provided to a Family Court judge as opposed to a Family Court registrar, then one would assume that this whole regime in 67P would not apply, because that is the trigger for everything that follows—that the information had to be provided to the registrar.

PARA.TAB: If you do not have a judicial registrar in a particular registry but just a judge, or if the judicial registrar is off on leave and the judge is dealing with all judicial matters and he or she happens to then deal with a location order, the judge can go off willy-nilly and intentionally and recklessly disclose the information and not fall foul of this regime, whereas if a registrar were to do exactly the same thing under the government proposal they would go to gaol for two years, or under the Greens' proposal they would cop a fine of $12,000. So I am not sure that is necessarily where we want to go with this.

Keeping the judges quarantined out of the argument for the time being, the information provided to the registrar of a court under a location order must not intentionally or recklessly be disclosed by any other person who obtains the information, whether directly or indirectly, whether under this section or otherwise, because of the provision of the information to the registrar except to the registrar of another court, an officer of the court or of another court, whose responsibilities or duties include service or execution of process. There are a lot of people engaged in the Family Court who would become appraised of this information who do not necessarily have within their duty statements the servicing or executing of court process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just amazed at the degree of concurrence I have with some of Senator Abetz's points. I would be really happy if we could actually strike out all penalties, imprisonment and fines through all the legislation, because I believe they are there inappropriately. But I am not won over because I do not see why we should strike out this one, when it applies to what I believe is a place of privilege, but we will not strike it out in the Social Security Act, where I believe it has absolutely no place, and right through a lot of legislation where it is as inappropriate, as Senator Abetz has alluded to.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, I believe it should be in there—just from the point of making an equality between the way we deal with people who are in this position of extreme community trust and those people who have to provide information to, for example, the social security department and have equivalent penalties of imprisonment put underneath any breaches of information they provide. I think it is unjust to give such favouritism saying, `But we can trust people who work in the registrar of courts and we cannot trust disabled people to give us correct information about their address.' They, too, have a two-year prison penalty for providing information inaccurately. That is why I am trying to seek equivalence. I would be more than happy to drop all of them.

I have a question for Senator Abetz. He seems to be arguing for the position against the amendment, which I believe we have support for, so I really do not want to prolong the debate too much. It is a fascinating point. If we remove the penalty altogether, is he still comfortable for the clause to be in there? My concern with his argument is that he does not want even the clause in there and he does not want people to have to obey that clause. If that is the case, then he really should be moving another amendment to delete the entire clause, not speak against the simple change to the penalty for that behaviour. That was why I rose.

I think he was correct if he was saying that he was discussing it in order to assess the seriousness of the penalty that was needed. But now he seems to be arguing to the point that it is an unrealistic clause to keep in the act altogether. If he is happy for it to go in, I would suggest that he should also be happy that there is some kind of sanction that applies to it because without a sanction it becomes meaningless to include it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not going to come to an agreement here. I can give Senator Abetz an assurance that the sorts of cases he is concerned about will not be encompassed, but he can keep on arguing and raising different points and he will not be satisfied.

PARA.TAB: I agree with Senator Chamarette on this particular proposal. We have actually had a long, exhaustive discussion about this and it is about time we put it to a vote, recognising that any further discussion probably will not take the respective sides much further down the track. I suggest that maybe we can do that now as we have been going for some time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief and deal with Senator Chamarette's question. I do not oppose the legislation as such. If people intentionally or recklessly disclose information that should be disallowed under the legislation. What I am concerned about is the width and the possibilities that people who otherwise should not be caught may well be caught in the legislation and that might be an unforeseen consequence.

PARA.TAB: Whilst I am being told that I am possibly off target on this, I simply remind the Senate that the March 1995 report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee stated at paragraph 1.62 on page 45:

One of the difficulties with the drafting of the penalty is that it does not appear to contemplate that the Registrar may not personally store the relevant information. It would be unrealistic to make it unlawful for the Registrar to disclose it to officers of the Court whose duties are to assist the Registrar in the storage of such information.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the considered opinion of the total committee. That is, we had Labor, Liberal, National and—as I think Senator Spindler also agreed with that—Democrat senators all agreeing with this concern. Now being November 1995 and some eight months down the track, having had this concern noted as of March 1995, with respect, I would have thought the minister might have been able to come in here with a more detailed explanation as to why paragraph 1.62 of our report is so inherently wrong.

PARA.TAB: Further, I note that just before paragraph 1.62 we quote nobody less than the Chief Judge of the Family Court, Mr Justice Nicholson. In part, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Court's staff structure Registry managers and not Registrars have line responsibility for registry staff and so for the recording and storage of Court records. The Registrar to whom the sanction would apply consequently has no capacity to direct the secure receipt, storage and handling of the information. Given the sensitive nature of the Court's records it is illogical that there be a criminal sanction in respect of the treatment of one type of information alone.

So, whilst it might be nice for the minister to make certain comments, I am somewhat heartened that the Chief Judge of the Family Court and the totality of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee agrees with the propositions that I have been putting.

PARA.TAB: I would like to think we could be given a greater explanation, a more detailed explanation as to why the chief judge and the Senate committee are wrong. But if we are not going

SPEECH.PARA: to get that, undoubtedly we will move to the vote and see what happens.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I understand the view being put by the minister. Perhaps I should mention two things. For example, I invite Senator Abetz to consider that, when there is the making of suppression orders in criminal proceedings in relation to a victim's name or sometimes an alleged perpetrator's name—which more often than not is the case—there is no suggestion that, when the court orderly takes the transcript of the day's proceedings to be stored somewhere in the bowels of the court, or wherever, those persons to whom that information is passed in the course of their duties of maintaining court records are persons to whom the court orderly has inappropriately disclosed the information. I have never heard—
—But it is not governed by specific legislative regimes such as this.

—With respect, though, there is a criminal sanction in South Australia for breach of suppression orders. The firm I used to work for often used to act for newspapers which had inadvertently—naturally, you understand—breached those orders. I have never heard of a case of a suppression order prosecution being launched against a member of the court staff. But we can all be wrong.

PARA.TAB: Minister, would it hurt to make some amendment that indicated that any court staff acting in the normal course of their duties were not to be covered by this? That, I believe, would be an unnecessary amendment, but it is obviously something of particular concern to Senator Abetz.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the chief judge.
—Given that the amendment would be doing nothing more than reflecting what you and I say is the case in any event, what would be the harm, as frustrating as that might be?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —No harm. We could do it. While we are debating the next amendments, we could probably come up with a form of words to do that, without legislating on the run. If we can just defer this particular part, find some words to go in there and come back to it, hopefully we can all agree.

—I would just point out that it is common in legislation which deals with judicial officers to see a provision which says that there will be no civil or criminal liability for those who are acting in the normal course of their duty. That is not an unreasonable request.

PARA.TAB: Amendment postponed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having withdrawn previously amendments Nos 36 and 37, I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: 38.After clause 28, page 16, insert the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Principles to be applied by courts

SPEECH.PARA: "28A. Section 43 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting "and" at the end of paragraph (c) and inserting the following paragraph:
`(ca) the need to ensure safety from family violence; and'.".

This amendment adds in the principal act the following paragraph: that there is `the need to ensure safety from family violence'. This is, once again, to make sure that the direction and purpose of the legislation is clear. It is my understanding that both the coalition and the government are disposed to support it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to clarify the situation, my understanding is that the opposition is disposed to supporting this; the government's position is not to support it. But, in the light of the opposition supporting this amendment, we will not engage in a long, drawn out debate.

PARA.TAB: Our argument is that there are other aspects of the legislation which should have the primary carriage for the issue of and protection against family violence. But, if the opposition is inclined to support this, we will not engage in a long debate and obfuscation.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: 39.Clause 31, page 69, proposed section 68L, omit subsections (2) and (3), substitute the following subsections:

PARA.TAB: "(2) Where a child who is the subject of any proceedings under this Act is not represented, the court must appoint a person to represent the child in those proceedings and, if the court thinks desirable, for such other purposes (including any other proceedings under this Act or any other enactment) as the court may specify.

"(3) Where the court appoints a person under subsection (2), it must, so far as practicable, appoint a person who is, by reason of personality, cultural background, training and experience, suitably qualified to represent the child.

"(4) Even if the proceedings in respect of which any person was appointed under subsection (2) have been disposed of or if the appointment is no longer required for any other purpose specified by the court under that subsection, the court may, if satisfied that it is necessary or desirable in the interests of the child to do so:

TAB.TAB: (a)extend the person's appointment; or
(b)subject to subsection (3) appoint another person to represent the child;

PARA.TAB: for such purposes as the court may specify.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment seeks to make it mandatory on the court to provide separate representation for a child or children where the care, access or visitation rights—whatever the terms now are—of the child or children are in dispute. It is a provision that has been in force in New Zealand for some three years. On a number of occasions previously I have argued for that to be inserted also in the family law of Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is based on the simple principle that children are not chattels, and that they should not be treated as chattels. Where two parties are debating what should happen, we cannot always go behind the agreement that is made or behind the evidence that is provided to the court. Very often the interests of the adults, the separating partners, may well not reflect the interests of the child. The partners may make a deal or agreement that suits them. They may trade off financial advantages against factors that affect the welfare of the child or children. While the court has ordered separate representation a lot more frequently since the decision in re Kay, I believe that we should enshrine as a principle that children are entitled to separate representation.

The matter of costs is very often brought up as an argument. One could simply look at New Zealand and say, `Well, New Zealand hasn't gone broke.' In fact, New Zealand is doing rather better economically than Australia at the moment. So that, I believe, is not an argument. The argument really is: are we prepared to put some financial savings in the running of the Family Court ahead of the interests of the child; or do we say that a child is a person and is entitled to representation so that the child's interests can be impartially assessed and brought to the notice of the court?
I believe that this amendment is long overdue in Australia. As I have said, New Zealand has had it for over three years.

Mr O'Reilly, the child commissioner from New Zealand who was in Australia earlier this year, has stated publicly that it is working well and that he is supporting it totally. It is in line with our obligations under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, which we have signed and ratified. Yet there seems to be a certain reluctance to bite the bullet on this one—and very often it is on the basis of cost, putting dollars ahead of the welfare of the child. I commend this amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler, I think you have been a bit generous in the presentation of your own argument in this respect. I think I have said that as politely as possible. You mentioned that we have to endorse the principle that children are entitled to separate representation. You were trying to lead the inference that, if we do not accept your amendment, they are not entitled to separate representation, which you and I know is not the case. They are entitled to it now.
—I said `mandatory'.

—I understand, Senator Spindler. I did not interrupt you. They are entitled to that representation now. They have protection, in that the court has a discretionary power to order that representation. The court obviously has a responsibility to exercise that power in the best interests of the child. You are saying that you want the discretion taken away from the court and you want mandatory representation. That is entirely different from saying that you want a principle established that children are entitled to representation. That already is established. The court has got a responsibility to look at the interests of the child and ascertain whether the child needs representation and, if it does, to so order. So it is a bit rich to come in here and present an amendment when all you are doing is seeking to enshrine some principle that is already there.

PARA.TAB: The second point I make is it that is a dangerous thing to keep touting around these international treaties and conventions. I am a great supporter of the UN. I think there are problems with some of their committees that need to be fixed up. When we get into government, we will play a stronger role in doing that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh yeah?
—Yes.
—How will you do that?

—We will fix some of those committees. If the problems of government are insurmountable to you, Senator Bolkus, just walk away from government now and we will walk in and take up the responsibility willingly. If you cannot manage to engender reforms that are required in the UN and it is too much for you, walk away from the task. We will be happy to walk in and do that quite happily without any assistance from you.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler, you cited the Convention on the Rights of the Child, but you stopped there as if to say, `Well, there is this convention and it therefore follows that my amendment ought to be passed.' But it does not automatically follow from that convention that your amendment ought to be passed. That is a disingenuous argument for you to put. It is an argument that does encourage some people, whom I admit are less informed than yourself, into the blind thinking that, because there is a convention on this, anything that someone wants to propose that is vaguely attached to it somehow has to become a law. You are encouraging the argument that the presence of a convention diminishes the responsibility and right of this chamber and other parliaments to decide the best way for Australia to comply with its international responsibilities. A convention is not a magic wand that just somehow falls down and says, `This amendment is okay.' That is not the case at all. The responsibility is with us.

I note the very kind remarks you made about New Zealand. I look forward to you from wherever you are after the next election strongly coming out and supporting the coalition industrial relations reforms. Then maybe this country will be as well off as New Zealand, the country which we regarded in the fifties as being out of date and as eventually becoming the extra state of Australia. It is now steaming ahead, as you quite rightly pointed out. It is much more economically wealthy and healthy than we are. One of the key reasons for their success is their industrial relations reforms. I look forward to Senator Spindler—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support the New Zealand industrial reforms?

—I am just making the point that I look forward to Senator Spindler recognising the difficulties with industrial relations in this country and I look forward to him accepting such improvements as we choose to make when we form the government after winning a majority in the lower house. I look forward to him supporting those amendments. Let me deal with the amendment itself.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—That would be a good idea, I think.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that gratuitous piece of advice.
—I was about to give it, actually.
—The first two points were in fact on the amendment.
—They were.

—There was just one minor digression. Senator Spindler, I really do not think your amendment should be supported at this stage. The court has an obligation to look after the interests of the child. It will order separate representation when it is appropriate. There is quite possibly a down side in insisting whenever custody matters go before a court that there always being separate representation for the children. It in-builds the argument that might be going on between the parents. It somehow creates the image that that argument is also between the children when it need not be. I am happy to rely on the court and the court's discretion as to when it is appropriate that the children or the child be separately represented.

—With the indulgence of the committee, could I just ask whether, after we have dealt with clause 39, we could possibly revisit amendment 38. There was some confusion when Senator Spindler withdrew amendments 36 and 37. I was looking at the wrong amendments and trying to come to grips with them when they were carried. I think our carrying of amendment 38 might be inconsistent with our rejection of amendment 15. But I just flag that at this stage for the minister and advisers to possibly consider.

PARA.TAB: In addressing clause 39, I do not think there is any need for a child to be represented on each and every occasion, no matter what the circumstances. This will say that, even if consenting orders come before the court and even if mum and dad have agreed as to what ought to happen with the children, the children should somehow still be subjected to an unnecessary third party. It is bad enough for children to have to go through counselling and the difficulty of the parental split-up without requiring them to be interviewed by a solicitor, who is usually a complete and utter stranger with whom the children have no relationship, no trust and no shared values. Somebody who is appointed by the court is virtually foisted upon them. Clearly, where there are major disputes between mum and dad, and the children are of an age where they can give expression to their views and wishes, it would be appropriate to possibly have the child separately represented.

What usually happens, which I think is appropriate, is that, if a matter does blow up to a major battle in the court, the court can order a family report, which is prepared by the court counselling service which interviews family members and, if need be, the extended family. It talks to the children, et cetera, and then provides a report to the court which is then part of the material on which the judge relies to make his or her decision about the future of the children.

To say that the court must appoint I think imposes further legalisms into the system. It will undoubtedly add to the cost of justice for the parties concerned or, if the taxpayer has to pay for it, it will be an extra burden on the taxpayer. I say to Senator Spindler that, if there is no obvious reason at all as to why the child ought to be separately represented, why on earth should we incur that cost and impose that cost upon taxpayers, delay the legal system and cause unnecessary further dislocation to the children involved?

I note in clause 3 of the proposed amendment that the person to be appointed is to be by reason of personality, cultural background, training and experience suitably qualified to represent the child. Does that mean that if we have a bit of an arrogant child we ought to appoint an arrogant lawyer or if we have a bit of a deceitful child we ought to appoint a deceitful lawyer? What happens if the child is a girl? Does that mean as of necessity we need a female lawyer to represent that child?

What happens if an immigrant like me marries a fifth generation Tasmanian? How do we cater for the cultural background of those children? We can extend this list on and on and get into a situation where, quite frankly, we would have quite a ridiculous outcome. We need people who are appropriately qualified in the law and who have some training in relation to children to represent the children. In general terms, I think the legal aid commissions around Australia do that relatively well. I cannot see any need for there to be a change. If every case that comes before the court, even consent orders, has to involve a third lawyer I think that will increase the cost of justice and will be of no material benefit at all when we consider the best interests of the child.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow on from the remarks of Senator Vanstone and Senator Abetz and agree with the comments they have made in relation to Senator Spindler's proposed amendment. I think this would tend to open the floodgates on separate representation for children. Leaving aside applications for principal relief—namely, dissolution of marriage—we find that with ancillary applications the vast majority of cases involve children in one way or another. The vast majority of cases going to trial or involving disputations involve children. If they were to have separate representation there would be a cost problem and a problem which the legal profession itself, I venture to suggest, could not even meet.

PARA.TAB: I think that some of the problems one faces with separate representation for children is finding someone who is uniquely suited to represent the child. I note that Senator Spindler has included in his amendment personality, cultural background, training and experience and the fact that they must be suitably qualified. I can tell you that, in my experience with family law, if you applied that test to most family lawyers you would find them failing in one way or other on any one of those discrete grounds. It would be extremely difficult to come up with a lawyer who fitted the bill in all instances as mentioned in the proposal.

Leaving that aside, my experience with family law has revealed that there are only special instances where children need separate representation. In the vast majority of cases the matter is adequately dealt with by the two parties—that is, the mother and father, husband or wife—being represented. It is only during the course of the proceedings if something arises which indicates child abuse, some aspect of violence or something untoward that the court looks at separate representation.

In my opinion, the current situation is suitable. I have been appointed to represent children and I can tell you that it is a very difficult task indeed. It is rather unusual you might think to have a practitioner who has no children of his own representing children. That was something which was brought home to me.

The question of cultural background, training and experience alone offer fantastic scope for questions to be applied in these instances. I once dealt with a family dispute involving a family of ethnic origin. If you had a solicitor of similar background, the rights of the women and the rights of the child would have been very much subjugated because one of the problems with this break-up was the fact that the female child was restricted severely in her freedom. There was one particular case recently which dealt with a father who plotted the murder of his own daughter because she would not accept his demands to abide by the rules of the household which were deep seated in a cultural and ethnic background.

I think you could run into problems with the personality alone, as Senator Abetz has mentioned. Who is to say that someone has had sufficient training to represent children. I have seen practitioners who I would have thought would have been eminently suited to represent children by their very disposition, but not necessarily because of their training. This does open a Pandora's box.

I do not think this amendment is needed. I think that children are adequately protected within the framework of family law in this country. I think the courts are sufficiently vigilant in matters which touch on the welfare of children. I understand Senator Spindler's concern and I know that he has expressed on many occasions in this chamber a concern about the rights of children and the welfare of children, but I do not think that this proposal will work. I do not think it has the efficacy to succeed and therefore I oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to some of the comments that have been made. The arguments put forward by Senator Ellison that the court can handle it adequately rests on the assumption that the court will always know when there is a case that requires separate representation. I am not aware of any provisions which indicate that counsellors must always talk to children. We cannot assume that that will happen.

PARA.TAB: My understanding is that, in most cases, the counselling is carried out between the two separating partners rather than with the children. It is therefore rather facile to say that the court can handle it, the court has handled it, the court will know what to do and the court has the discretion. The point is that the court may not know. The system may fail the children and it is simply to ensure that it does not that a representative is suggested.

I think it is equally facile to quibble with the suggested qualifications for the representative of the children. One should try to pick a representative that is suited to the task. Certainly, it is going to be difficult. The coalition is really grasping at straws trying to criticise this amendment, with its intrinsic value, on the basis that some qualifications need to be present when a representative is appointed.

It seems to me that Senator Vanstone has got some difficulty with interpreting the term `entitle'. She says children are entitled now. To me entitle means that I have the right to something. Children have not got the right to a representative at the moment. They get a representative when the court decides they should have one. If the court decides they should not have one then they do not get one. That right is not there. It seems to me that entitle means that you have that right, but children do not have that right at the moment. It is mandatory on the court to determine that. It is simply wrong to suggest that children are entitled to that representation. They may get that representation if the court decides that.

Regarding the gratuitous reference to New Zealand, no, Senator Vanstone, we do not agree with the industrial relations legislation which has reduced minimum wages to a deplorably low level, almost to starvation levels. Seeing that the New Zealand provision for the representation of the child is there, I can only say that there have to be some compensations and this is one of them.

At the same time, I hope we will reach the position where we can guarantee that the child's views and interests will be represented in a dispute before the court. A consent order does not fall into that category, Senator Abetz. But where there is a dispute involving children before the court, at some stage we might have an insight that we possibly have the responsibility to provide someone to ensure that the child's voice is heard. I believe that day should not be too far away and I feel rather sad that the chamber on this occasion is not prepared to take this action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the Greens support the amendment moved by Senator Spindler. We believe it would be a useful safeguard to ensure the child's interests are properly presented before the court. We welcome particularly the inclusion of the phrase `cultural background' in proposed subsection (3) where it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where the court appoints a person under subsection (2), it must, so far as practicable, appoint a person who is, by reason of personality, cultural background, training and experience, suitably qualified to represent the child.
We are sad as well if there is not sufficient support for this amendment to have it included.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—Would it be appropriate to move back to Senator Chamarette's amendment that we had before?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has a further amendment to Senator Chamarette's amendment to cover the point raised by Senator Abetz and Senator Vanstone and to pick up Senator Vanstone's suggestion that we include officers acting within their responsibilities or duties. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Delete proposed section 67P(1)(b), insert:

PARA.TAB: (b) an officer of the court, or of another court, for the purpose of that officer's responsibilities or duties;
Amendment agreed to.
Amendment (Senator Chamarette's)—as amended—agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 31, page 27, proposed subsection 62C(2), line 26, after "welfare officer", insert "to assess whether counselling is appropriate in all the circumstances, and if it is:".

The amendment seeks to allow somebody to assess whether counselling is appropriate in all the circumstances. It is basically allowing a decision to be made by a counsellor. We believe that the cautionary principle in the provision under which a party to proceedings under the Family Law Act can seek a counselling session for the purposes of discussing child welfare, care and development should be asserted. The bill as it stands makes such a counselling session an absolute right upon application, which concerns me in that it allows for a vindictive party to create a confrontation with an unwilling former spouse.

PARA.TAB: While we believe that that can be misapplied and this cautionary amendment does not head off the counselling at the point of application, it does place an assessment component between the application and the substantive counselling session. This would allow the counsellor to determine whether counselling is appropriate in the circumstances rather than allowing a right which can then be instituted without the capacity to judge whether it really is in the most appropriate interests of the child at that point. I urge the chamber to support the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does support amendment No. 2 of the Greens.
—Likewise from the coalition.

—I fully agree with the intent of the proposed amendment. I am just wondering whether it adds anything because all the amendment says at the moment is `must arrange for parties to the proceedings . . . to be interviewed'. It does not say that they have to be interviewed together and thus create the confrontation that Senator Chamarette is talking about. I know that in the registry in which I practised for many years—and still put in an odd appearance—the counsellors quite often do interview parents separately rather than together and that occurs anyway where they think there is no use in having the parents in a confrontational situation. I do not oppose the amendment. All I am trying to do is point out that, as I understand the system, that is how it works already.

—It is taking the cautionary principle, for the same reason that you were concerned about the infringement of people in the operation of their duties. It is a way of stating what we believe should be obvious.
—The Australian Democrats support the amendment. It is in line with the concerns we have expressed on numerous occasions throughout this debate.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank my colleagues for their support for amendment No. 2. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 31, page 17, after proposed section 60B, insert the following section:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Convention gives rise to legitimate expectations

PARA.TAB: "60BA.(1) Unless and until this section is expressly repealed, the fact that Australia is a party to the Convention on the Rights of the Child gives rise to a legitimate expectation, on the part of any person, that to any extent that this Part does anything less than implement the requirements of the Convention:

TAB.TAB: (a)an administrative decision will be made in conformity with the requirements of the Convention; or

(b)if the decision were to be made contrary to any of those requirements, any person affected by the decision would be given notice and an adequate opportunity to present a case against the taking of such a course.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: "(2) In this section:
'administrative decision' means:

TAB.TAB: (a)a decision by or on behalf of the Commonwealth under this Part; or
(b)a decision by or on behalf of an authority of, or office holder of, the Commonwealth under this Part;

SPEECH.PARA: that is a decision of an administrative character and includes such a decision reviewing, or determining an appeal in respect of, a decision made before the commencement of this Part;".
3.Clause 31, page 66, proposed subsection 68B(1), after proposed (d), add the following paragraph:
" or(e)an injunction restraining a person from removing a child more than a specified distance from the place of residence of a parent who has a contact order in relation to the child.".
4.Clause 31, page 68, proposed subsection 68F(2), after paragraph (d), insert the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(da)the practical difficulty and expense of a parent having access to a child and whether that difficulty or expense will substantially affect the child's right to maintain personal relations and direct contact with both parents on a regular basis;"

SPEECH.PARA: I have moved the amendments together as a short cut to assist the process of the committee. They are not totally connected. Amendment No. 3 and Amendment No. 4 are associated with each other and they relate to the practical difficulties that arise when a parent who is providing accommodation moves interstate or overseas. While the Western Australian Family Court has taken this into account, recent case histories from the United Kingdom, where the distances are nothing like those in Western Australia, have made their way into decisions made by the court in other states. It is a trend for the court which stands in the way of the parent providing accommodation living wherever they wish, but it creates a very difficult balancing act between the freedom of parents to live where they choose and the rights of the child to have contact with both parents.

PARA.TAB: What we have done in amendment No. 3 is to relate the amendment to a parent as against a person in whose favour a contact order is in place, because it would be too great a limit on the other parent's freedom of movement if the provision extended to other people—for example, grandparents. The list could be endless as contact orders can be made in favour of any person concerned with a child's care, welfare and development.

Amendment No. 4 to clause 31, subsection 68F(2), is for the same reason. In many cases, a parent will move away from the other parent—that is a natural choice—but we believe that there should be some provisions which assist them. Therefore, we have inserted two clauses—amendments Nos 3 and 4. Amendment No. 3 says:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. Clause 31, page 66, proposed subsection 68B(1), after proposed (d), add the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "or (e)an injunction restraining a person from removing a child more than a specified distance from the place of residence of a parent who has a contact order in relation to the child."

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 4 says:
4. Clause 31, page 68, proposed subsection 68F(2), after paragraph (d), insert the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(da)the practical difficulty and expense of a parent having access to a child and whether that difficulty or expense will substantially affect the child's right to maintain personal relations and direct contact with both parents on a regular basis;"

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments allow those contact factors to be taken into consideration.

PARA.TAB: At this point, we probably would not need to have my amendment No. 1, but we will need it shortly so I will address it. The amendment incorporates the Convention on the Rights of the Child into the relevant part of the Family Law Act. The convention embodies three important principles: firstly, that children not be discriminated against, ensuring non-discrimination between children and between children and adults; secondly, that the best interests of the child should be a primary consideration in decision making; and, thirdly, that the choice of the child be heard and given due weight. Who in this chamber would disagree with those principles? I am sure that none of us would.

The Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill will remove the capacity for those principles to be considered within decision making that might be involved in the bill that we are considering for debate today. This amendment is being moved to simply affirm in law what the common law has been saying since 1969: Australian citizens have a legitimate expectation that if Australia becomes party to an international treaty then we will conform to its provisions. Where a decision maker does not act in conformity, they must give notice and provide an opportunity for a person affected to respond.

The doctrine of legitimate expectation is a very modest principle. It is very hard to fathom why the government wants to stamp it out. The only conclusion that we can draw is that the government wants to perpetrate the sham of being an upstanding international citizen in the Convention on the Rights of the Child, particularly in this instance, while failing to honour its obligations as a result of that except at the whim of administrators.

As the Greens, the coalition and Democrats have pointed out, our treaty process is fundamentally flawed. We may believe this for different reasons. What we need here is a comprehensive approach to the debate and not a piecemeal approach. The opposition, in supporting the government's Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill, is allowing the government to have unbridled capacity or licence to sign international treaties with total impunity. It does not have to take into consideration the principles enshrined in those international treaties. We believe that, while administrators obviously would not be bound or obliged to fulfil those treaties unless they were enshrined in domestic law, they should have some obligation to consider those responsibilities, even if they then decide against them. That is the reason why this amendment is being put in place.

The big picture is that the government has really failed to create an adequate system for working towards implementation of our international obligations. The area of family law, specifically with regard to children, is a clear example of this. I particularly urge our opposition colleagues to reconsider the decision that they will be able to make. I would be quite happy for them not to support these particular amendments if I thought they were not going to pass the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill, because this amendment would then not be necessary—I quite agree.

We would have a legitimate expectation that the international treaty obligations in connection with the rights of the child would have some sway in the decision making that would occur under the Family Law Reform Bill that we are discussing today. However, the community is becoming increasingly aware that the safety net that the international treaty has represented to all who are working in the area of the rights of children is going to be undermined.

I would like to read a copy of a letter which has been put out by Defence for Children International—Australia. It underlines the concern which has been expressed and is the reason for the amendment being brought to the chamber. It relates to the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill, the need for such an amendment and for those in the chamber to support it. The letter is to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and states:

SPEECH.PARA: I urge you to withdraw immediately the legislation to nullify the decision, known as the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill.

I consider that this Bill, and the executive statement issued by the Attorney-General and the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 10 May, are a betrayal of the promise Australia made to children when it ratified the Convention on the Rights of the Child in 1990 and signed the World Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children in 1991. I note that this promise was repeated in commitments made by you in the National Action Plan for Human Rights (1994) and the Report "Our Children, Our Future" (1994).
I fully support this commitment and believe that Australia's children urgently need the protection of the international standards contained in the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

The Bill is a disgrace in the eyes of the world community and brings shame on Australia's human rights record. No longer will our representatives at the UN be able to claim that Australia is fully committed to implementing human rights and children's rights in particular.

The High Court has clearly indicated that Australia's past position on international treaties is untenable. The proper response to this decision is not to nullify it but to develop legislation to implement it constructively and promptly . . .

That underlines the concern of many people in the community who had what is now being exposed as a false sense of security: that Australia's becoming a signatory to the Convention on the Rights of the Child would have some protective function in administrative decision making, not—and I stress `not'—an obligation that it will have a force of law, but simply a legitimate expectation that those factors would be taken into consideration. Amendment No. 1 states:

"60BA.(1) Unless and until this section is expressly repealed, the fact that Australia is a party to the Convention on the Rights of the Child gives rise to a legitimate expectation, on the part of any person, that to any extent that this Part does anything less than implement the requirements of the Convention:

PARA.TAB: (a)an administrative decision will be made in conformity with the requirements of the Convention; or

(b)if the decision were to be made contrary to any of those requirements, any person affected by the decision would be given notice and an adequate opportunity to present a case against the taking of such a course."

SPEECH.PARA: So it is simply giving a procedural right to people who feel that the spirit of the international treaty, to which Australia is a party, will be honoured in administrative decision making in the Family Law Reform Bill. That is not an unreasonable expectation whatsoever. In fact, I think the government is being utterly unreasonable in foreshadowing that it is not intending to take the natural consequence of its becoming a party to the treaty into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would appreciate it if the minister could indicate the reasons and rationale for his opposition to the Greens' amendments Nos 3 and 4. I confess that, sort of first flush, they seem to be—
—Eminently reasonable.

—I will reserve judgment on that, but I would like to hear what the minister has to say about that. Trying to incorporate the Convention on the Rights of the Child into the Family Law Act is inappropriate. Part of the problems with our international treaty making process is that we sign up on these treaties and then we are not fully aware of the consequences of them—how they might impact on our domestic law. Until we had had a full discussion as to the consequences of the impact of that treaty on the domestic law, quite properly they should not have been signed in the first place. However, they have been signed and—

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I do not say that, just because one mistake was made, we should then compound the mistake even further by incorporating that mistake into our domestic legislation. So I oppose the Greens' amendment. I think it was under the Convention on the Rights of the Child that one of those discredited UN bodies recently told us we had to abolish corporal punishment of children and to outlaw it. If corporal punishment became illegal, people could assert that corporal punishment was family violence and then you would have a complete mess within the Family Law Act and the domestic legislation.

PARA.TAB: I suppose I am one of those old-fashioned people who believe that a bit of corporal punishment delivered in a loving manner is of assistance to children. I would not want to see that, in effect, being denied in this legislation. It is one of those few occasions when I happen to agree with the Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch, who has indicated similar thoughts on the issue of corporal punishment.

I recall with some degree of humour that Gerry Bates, a Green member in the Tasmanian parliament, was very gung-ho about the Convention on the Rights of the Child and corporal punishment, until a journalist asked whether he had ever administered corporal punishment to his children. All of a sudden there was a non-response by him and, of course, the situation become very ludicrous indeed. I think the vast majority of middle road Australia—when I say `middle road', I think it would be 95-plus per cent of the population—would say that it is appropriate. Sure, we do not want to see children bruised and battered, but I think there is an appropriate role for corporal punishment.

I have to say to you, Senator Chamarette, that I doubt my children will ever lose sleep of a night because the UN convention has not been incorporated into the Family Law Act. I do not think it is something the children of this nation are concerned about. I think they are a very blessed group of children to be able to live in a society such as Australia, in comparison to a whole host of other countries which also are signatories to the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

When my children grow older, I think they may well become more concerned about unemployment, the international debt and things of that nature than the issue of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. In fact it was not a promise to the children of Australia; it was a promise to other countries. The children of Australia were not consulted before we signed the Convention on the Rights of the Child. The bureaucrats were consulted and certain lobby groups were consulted. Then we went around the cocktail circuit of international treaty making and we signed up. But the children were not consulted in establishing the convention. I therefore doubt they would have any real or genuine concerns that a promise to them had been broken.

Undoubtedly we will have a longer and more detailed debate in relation to the Teoh bill. I will raise the other matters I want to address on that occasion. I request the minister to address his mind to the reasons why the government is opposing amendments Nos 3 and 4.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is opposing all of Senator Chamarette's amendments in this basket. With respect to amendment No. 1, let me say in brief that we do have the Teoh bill coming up and we would rather embrace those issues in the context of that bill than in this particular one.

PARA.TAB: With respect to amendment No. 3, we understand the concern which underlies the proposed amendment. What we see here is an amendment which seeks to add to proposed subsection 68B(1) a new paragraph providing the court with, in effect, the power to circumscribe the freedom of movement of a person with whom the child lives—to restrain or to constrain that freedom of movement. We understand the underlying reasons for this particular proposal.

The issue of balance between parents is a difficult one. Balance between facilitating contact between the child and a non-resident parent and allowing the parent with whom the child lives to manage his or her life has always been difficult. The amendment, in the eyes of the government, will allow the court to issue an injunction which would constrain movement, for instance, of a parent fleeing violence. It would overtly place control over a place of residence of the parent. It would potentially restrain the parent from moving in order to obtain employment, to go on holidays, to visit relatives, et cetera.

We have to remember that if there is a contact order, and a parent then removes a child, that parent will be in breach of that order and the enforcement provisions of the act can be invoked. So there is some protection. There is also a need to allow for flexibility for parents to run their own lives. We see this as being too restrictive.

We acknowledge that the enforcement of the orders by the Family Court was a source of complaint to the joint select committee. We do not think this amendment is a way to address the concerns that people had when going to the joint select committee. For instance, we would rather pursue the course of action kicked off by the Australian Law Reform Commission in its report For the sake of the kids. That report deals specifically with complex contact cases in the Family Court. It has considered the issue in detail. We would rather proceed down that route.

We are now considering submissions that we have received in response to that Law Reform Commission report. We would rather treat the issue in a broader way in responding to that particular report—though we understand what Senator Chamarette wants to do—than go too far in potentially constraining people's movement. That is No. 3.

We have some problems with No. 4 as well. Once again I understand the motivation. To the extent that anything needs to be done here, we think this particular amendment is not necessary. The amendment refers to the child's right to maintain personal relations and direct contact with both parents on a regular basis. This description is somewhat inconsistent with the principle contained in paragraph 60B(2)(b). It would undermine the amendment to the principle recommended by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. That amendment qualified that right of the child by recognising that contact through the proviso `except if the contact is contrary to the child's best interest'.

We maintain that there needs to be flexibility to accommodate the child's best interests. Of course there will be some circumstances where a parent is violent or abusive and the child's best interests may be contrary to the impact of the amendment that Senator Chamarette wants us to adopt this afternoon.

We understand the motivation for the amendments, but we think they are excessive. For instance, amendment No. 4 is directed at the consideration of the practicalities and expense of contact by a child or parent. It is not quite clear what sort of result is intended from that consideration. If contact is difficult or expensive, should it therefore not be ordered?

We do think those amendments are too restrictive, and we would rather pursue balancing the rights of the child than just accept amendment No. 4. In respect of amendment No. 3, we think the holistic approach of responding to the Law Reform Commission's report is the more appropriate way to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the minister is in relation to a reconciliation of the principles expressed in 60B, in particular subclause (2), which deals with the principles underlying the object of part VII dealing with children. One principle is that children have a right of contact on a regular basis with both parents.

PARA.TAB: Clause 68F says how a court determines what is in a child's best interests. Subclause (2) lists various criteria: the wishes of the child, the relationship of the child with each of its parents and the likely effect of the separation, as well as other matters. But none of them specifically addresses the right of the child to have regular contact with either parent.

It would seem to me that the Greens' amendment (da) addresses this very important point, when it says that the court should be mindful of the practical difficulty that a parent might have in getting access to a child. That is the reciprocal of the right of the child to have regular contact with a parent. Regular contact would imply that the parent and child can get together regularly. Of course, if there is the tyranny of distance—which this country of ours knows only too well—there might be a problem in getting such regular contact. How does the minister reconcile that object in 60B(2)(b), and what is his argument for excluding the Greens' amendment No. 4?

TALK.START.PARA: —While the minister is gaining some advice, I would like to welcome the indications of support from members of the opposition for the amendment.
—We are still inquiring.

—I know you are still inquiring, but our hopes spring up very easily. If it were possible to persuade the chamber to support amendments 3 and 4, I would like to pursue that. I think the minister is quite correct: both the amendments do fit into (2)(k), which says `any other fact or circumstance that the court thinks is relevant'.

PARA.TAB: In one sense it is not needed, but that list of factors that the court must consider is very valuable and brings to mind the factors that will be in the best interests of the child. As people from Western Australia would know—and that includes Senator Ellison—the tyranny of distance is a major factor and it is something that could be overlooked, because a court may be considering the kinds of factors that they do in Great Britain, for example. The minister is indicating—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indicating a compromise.
—Fine; go for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am suggesting that, to make amendment No. 4 fit in with the language of the legislation, we should change the words `access to' to `contact with'—so it would read `parent having contact with a child', as opposed to `parent having access to a child'. I also suggest that it be brought under (ca) rather than (da). That would fit sequentially better. If we change it to (ca) and delete the words `access to' and replace them with `contact with', then we can live with this amendment.
—I welcome the minister's response. I am happy to accept that change to my amendment No. 4—that is, changing (da) to (ca) and changing the words `access to' to `contact with'.

—I am just trying to get the language right. Can we also change it to read `a child having contact with a parent', because that fits within the structure of the legislation. So the clause is now to read `the practical difficulty or expense of a child having contact with a parent' and so on. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit proposed paragraph 68F(2)(da), substitute the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(ca)the practical difficulty and expense of a child having contact with a parent and whether that difficulty or expense will substantially affect the child's right to maintain personal relations and direct contact with both parents on a regular basis;".

TALK.START.PARA: —So there is `parent contact with a child' and `whether that difficulty or expense will substantially affect the child's right to maintain personal relations'. I am more than happy to accept those changes.

—The Australian Democrats are pleased that amendment No. 4 of the Greens will probably be passed by the chamber. We certainly will support it. We also support amendment No. 3. Both of these amendments touch on areas of great difficulty with people that have gone through the traumatic experience of separating and having to achieve some sort of continuing contact with their children. In the three family law inquiries, of which I have been a part, many witnesses told quite horrendous stories about the difficulty that they have experienced in maintaining that contact. Therefore, I am very pleased to express the Democrats' support for amendment No. 3 and for amendment No. 4 as amended.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats also support strongly amendment No. 1, which relates to the Convention on the Rights of the Child that Australia has both signed and ratified. The convention contains a simple but, I would have thought, extremely principled statement suggesting that we are obliged to provide protection and support for our children, that we are obliged to ensure that they are not exposed to violence, that their material needs are adequately catered for and that they are given a voice.

I found it somewhat ironic when Senator Abetz said that the children have not been asked for their views before the government signed and ratified the Convention on the Rights of the Child. It did so after consultation with the state governments. At the same time, Senator Abetz does not think children should have a voice in family law proceedings before the Family Court. On the one hand, he says that we should consult children but, on the other hand, he is quite prepared to deny them separate representation which would give them an effective voice in court proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just wrong.

—That is what you said, Senator Abetz. You did not support separate representation for children, which would have given them a voice, yet you say that they should have been consulted. The obligation being placed upon us is the obligation to protect children and to give them support.

PARA.TAB: I remind Senator Abetz that at least 21,000 cases of physical and sexual abuse of children in Australia are substantiated every year. We should be conscious of that and should try to reduce that in whatever way we can. It is somewhat ironic that, when we have an international convention that we have signed and ratified which tries to establish adequate standards for the protection of Australian children as well as children across the world, this is causing such difficulty. I would have thought that, for a civilised society, one of the first principles that we should adhere to is that we look after, support and protect our children.

In the same vain—and without running through all the arguments again because, as the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) has said, there will be time to discuss that when the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill 1995, otherwise known as the anti-Teoh bill, is before the Senate—I find it ironic that, on the one hand, we are prepared to sign high-minded sounding commitments but, on the other hand, we say to our officials that they may not take them into account in the administrative decisions that they make and those commitments do not raise a reasonable expectation that the government and its officials will act in accordance with them. On that basis, the Australian Democrats strongly support amendment No. 1 and regret that neither the government nor the coalition is prepared to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I think it is a wise idea to take amendment No. 4 separately, and I support that suggestion by Senator Chamarette. I want to address the WA Greens' amendments in toto. The first amendment, which deals with the convention giving rise to a legitimate expectation, I do not feel is really needed with the Family Law Act as amended once we have passed these amendments today.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the Family Law Act 1975 with these amendments adequately sets out a comprehensive regime dealing with the welfare of children and what is considered to be the best interests of children. The people of Australia are sufficiently well served by this legislation without having to resort to the Convention on the Rights of the Child to achieve any further equality, justice or advancement of the welfare of children. As such, we will only complicate matters by referring to a convention which is not drafted with the particularity and clarity of the legislation that we have before us. In general terms, conventions and treaties by their very nature have to be so drafted because they are dealing with many parties coming from many different parts of the world. A good many treaties and conventions are stated in terms of general principle.

If you apply that to the internal workings of a country, to the domestic law of a country, you can run into all sorts of trouble, particularly where there is already comprehensive legislation dealing with a subject anyway. I believe it is more appropriate that the people of Australia decide through their elected representatives what is best for them rather than having the executive determine that by signing an international instrument. With the legislative process that we have, we have a very good system whereby the people of Australia can lobby their elected representatives, those representatives are subject to scrutiny and legislation is subject to scrutiny; that is, the people get what the people want.

That is not the case with conventions and international instruments. I do not see any prejudice at all in not adopting the Greens' amendment. I think it takes it no further. Any expectation which has to be created should be created in the legislation that we have before us and the bill as it will be passed—no more, no less. That is where the people of Australia have to look for their expectations, and I therefore oppose amendment No. 1.

As for amendment No. 4, I think with the amendment that the government proposes it is based on sound grounds. Of course, the language has to accord with the remainder of the legislation, and I think that the amendment is a good one.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can just briefly respond to the comments made by Senator Spindler, I would not want the record to remain as he had put it. The comments I made to Senator Chamarette were on the basis of her comment that not incorporating the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child was in effect a breach of promise to the children of this country. It was on that basis that I said that the children were not consulted, and I note with interest that Senator Spindler did not deny that assertion.

PARA.TAB: Taking it the step further and asserting that I oppose the representation of children in the Family Court was absolutely wrong. There was no justification for Senator Spindler to say that, given all the previous comments that I had made. Senator Spindler's proposed amendment would make it mandatory to have representation of children, whereas my view and the view of the government and the opposition is that it ought be done only when it is deemed appropriate. So it should not be mandatory.

I have been involved in cases where separate representatives have been appointed. I think they have been most helpful in coming to grips with some of the issues that were in dispute. In other cases, if they would have been appointed they would have been of no assistance, dragged out the case and added to the general cost.

Children do not have a right per se to speak for themselves in the Family Court. You appoint a separate representative to speak on their behalf in the court. That is something that Senator Spindler also has not come to grips with. But can I just set the record straight that I have no opposition at all to children being represented in Family Court matters when it is appropriate that they be so represented.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—As chair, I intend to divide the question, put the minister's amendment to amendment No. 4 and dispose of amendment No. 4, and then put the question for amendment Nos 1 and 3 together. Is that satisfactory?
