TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator McMullan will be overseas on official government business from 15 to 26 November and will therefore be absent from question time on 15 and 16 November and from 20 to 23 November. He will be participating in the APEC ministerial meeting from 15 to 18 November. He will then travel to Taiwan on an unofficial visit to promote trade and investment links, addressing the 11th joint meeting between the Australia-Taiwan Business Council and its counterpart.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan will be in Vancouver from 22 to 24 November to attend a meeting of trade ministers on the future of the World Trade Organisation. This meeting is one of the four international meetings aimed at setting the agenda for the first biennial ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organisation in Singapore in December 1996.

I will also be absent from question time on 15 and 16 November attending the APEC ministerial meeting in Osaka. On 15 and 16 November, Senator Ray will act as Leader of the Government in the Senate, represent the Prime Minister and take questions on foreign affairs; Senator Cook will take questions on trade; Senator Collins will represent the Minister for Communications and the Arts; and Senator Bolkus will represent the Minister for Administrative Services. In Senator McMullan's absence from question time from 20 November onwards, I will take questions on trade, Senator Collins will represent the Minister for Communications and the Arts and Senator Bolkus will represent the Minister for Administrative Services.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This is really becoming ridiculous. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) has been in the place two sitting days in the last three sitting weeks or something like that. He has an additional responsibility as leader of this place. Major industrial confrontation is now taking place under the government's regime. He should be in here answering questions in relation to those important matters. Why can't he go there with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)? Why does he have to go there earlier?
—A trade minister going to APEC?

—I understand. We are told that the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) has to do some negotiating. But what about Senator Evans? Why is it necessary for him to go tonight and miss yet another patch of the parliament?

PARA.TAB: We know the attitude of the Prime Minister to this parliament. We know his attitude to the Senate, which he sees as totally irrelevant except for nuisance value, but we we think that we have responsibilities and one responsibility is that ministers should be here to answer questions. If this was happening occasionally, it would be okay. When Senator Evans was foreign minister early in his career, he was here most of the time and we thought that was the correct and proper process, but in recent months he has hardly ever been here. We are entitled to protest that. He ought to give us an explanation as to why he needs to go tonight and miss yet another sitting period of the parliament.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—What the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) is saying would be slightly more credible if the opposition took advantage of my presence here to ask me some questions. The last time we had a little fulmination on this subject was on 16 October, when there was a similar exchange across the table. I sat here for the duration of the following question time. The first question that came to me from the opposition was 55 minutes into question time. It was the only question for that day. Yesterday, in the very week that you are getting so excited about the need for my presence, I sat here for an hour and not one single question was directed towards me; not one. If I am such an indispensable presence for the morale of the opposition or for the information needs of a sadly depleted opposition, they have shown an utter incapacity to demonstrate that need by their performance over recent days.

PARA.TAB: I will have been absent from 17 days of parliament this year out of something over 80 sitting days at this stage. I will tell you what they were. For three days in June, I was in Paris for the previously unexpected but absolutely unavoidable delegation made to the French government on the nuclear testing issue. I spent two days in September at the World Economic Forum meeting in Singapore, which was the forerunner for the Asia-Europe meeting next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Big deal!

—Senator Alston says, `Big deal'. That is a spectacular demonstration of your ignorance, indifference, incompetence and irrelevance to the government of this country, because this was the most important single meeting of the year bringing together business people and government leaders from Europe and Asia. It was highly desirable and necessary for me to be there, and I was. Three days in September at the United Nations General Assembly: was that irrelevant? Was that a waste of time? One day of that was devoted in Madrid to a dialogue with the current Chairman of the European Union. Even with your utter indifference to matters Asian, you would at least, I think, acknowledge the continued relevance of that particular dialogue framework being maintained.
—Back to New York.

—Yes. Then there was a week at Cartagena to the non-aligned movement; back in New York for the general session of the 50th special commemoration session of the UN; and in the Hague arguing the case for the illegality of nuclear weapons, pursuing the case, among other things, for Australia's membership of the security council, which you have acknowledged is an utterly worthy, relevant and sensible thing for this government to be doing. And, finally, two days this week at APEC. That is it.

PARA.TAB: That is a larger proportion away than was the case last year when there were only 10 visits. In 1993 there were 10 visits too, It is more consonant with the number of parliamentary days I have missed in previous years. There were only two days away last year; there were eight the year before; and seven the year before. It has been more than that this year, but for the reasons that I have described. You asked me, finally, why I am going when we have the admirable capacity of Senator McMullan to represent us at APEC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why can't you just send him this year?

—For the reason that every other one of the 17 countries represented, except for Taiwan, the circumstances of which are special, are represented by their foreign minister, because—your ignorance would not allow you to appreciate this—each one of these participating economies has from the outset been represented by a combination of foreign minister and trade minister. That is the way it is done. That is the program of meetings that I have to attend, the course of negotiations that I have to be involved in with my colleague Senator McMullan.

PARA.TAB: I appreciate it would be a huge asset for any future Australian administration if the foreign minister—if there were to be a change of government—were kept away from these meetings. I understand entirely your desire to create a precedent to keep your putative foreign minister away from these meetings. That is a very sensible thing to do, given the contribution we know he would make. But in all the circumstances of the meetings in which I have been involved, there is absolutely no doubt but that my attendance is relevant, it is necessary and I make no bones about doing it.

I apologise to other members of the Senate for not being around to answer your questions. The Australian Democrats, the Greens(WA) and the Independents have been much more interested in asking questions during the time that I have been here. That has not been true of the opposition. It is crocodile tears that you are shedding for the umpteenth time, and you do not persuade anybody.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I made my comments last time, saying I regretted the increasing absences from this place of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans); but he has mounted a defence this time that he did not have at his disposal last time. There is an even more serious thing for us to consider: we really need all of them to stay here to save us from the last paragraph in this letter which reads to me like a John Cleese script. In other words, we have to find our way through this chain of communication:

SPEECH.PARA: In Senator McMullan's absence—
Senator Evans will take questions on trade—
Senator Collins will represent the Minister for Communications and the Arts and Senator Bolkus will represent the Minister for Administrative Services.
It also states:

On 15 and 16 November, Senator Ray will act as Leader of the Government in the Senate, represent the Prime Minister, take questions on foreign affairs; Senator Cook will take questions on trade; Senator Collins will represent the Minister for Communications and the Arts; and Senator Bolkus will represent the Minister for Administrative Services.
Can't you all stay here and save us from working out who we have to address our questions to? Can't we really have plenty of opportunities to ask the appropriate minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you were a cricket umpire; can't you make the appropriate decisions?
—Yes, I can, Senator Ray. I just think it would be good if you could all stay here so we could ask the appropriate minister the appropriate questions.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I might say, Mr President, after the diatribe from Senator Gareth Evans, he might like to return to the real world. Noting the mining unions involved in the Weipa dispute having defied the orders of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the ACTU backing them in this illegal act, I ask: does the government condone the trade union bosses' defiance of the Industrial Relations Commission? Does the government support the ACTU's threat to mount a campaign of intimidation, blackmail and secondary boycotts? What does the government intend to do to ensure the parties in the dispute comply with the government's Industrial Relation Act?

—As honourable senators will be aware, award employees have been on strike since 13 October over the use of individual contracts at Comalco's Weipa bauxite and kaolin operations. Reports indicate that there is a discrepancy of up to $20,000 between the wages of those on individual contracts and award employees. We are aware of claims that the company is actively de-unionising its work force and requiring every worker to sign away his or her rights of collective bargaining in order to achieve a wage increase. We would be concerned if those claims are true. We are concerned that the principles of collective bargaining, which underpin our industrial system, be preserved. We are also concerned that individual contracts not be used to de-unionise or to discriminate against unions members. They are the principles that we are concerned about; they are the issues that we are concerned about in this case. As this dispute unfolds and takes its course we will govern our response accordingly.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact, Minister, that the CRA company has done everything in accordance with the Industrial Relations Act—which is your act? If so, I repeat my questions: do you intend to condone the trade union bosses' defiance of an order of the Industrial Relations Commission and do you support the ACTU's threat to mount a campaign of intimidation and blackmail against a company which has done everything in accordance with the Industrial Relations Act?

—I can only repeat: our concern would be if there were an exercise going on to actively de-unionise a work force, if there were pressure being mounted to sign away rights of collective bargaining. We are concerned that the principles of collective bargaining be maintained. They have traditionally underpinnned our industrial relations system. We do not want to see them undermined in the future. We do not want to see individual contracts being used to de-unionise or discriminate against union members. It is a matter for judgment, obviously, whether or not those principles are in issue or are seriously at risk in this case. I am just indicating very clearly what is the nature of our concern and the way in which we will respond to this situation as it unfolds.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Over the last few months there has been a great deal of discussion on the wool market situation, particularly in relation to the importance of China in the market. Whilst there has been a firming of the market over recent weeks, can you indicate to the Senate the latest developments that should bring or could bring more confidence to the market and to the agricultural sector in general?

—I am very pleased with the positive response from the industry to the government's decision to allow Wool International to conduct a limited two-year program to develop and evaluate the forward marketing of wool. The industry must develop the commercial tools to manage risk. An acceptance of this by industry is fundamental to its future. In this regard I was pleased to see that the Commonwealth Bank announced yesterday its intention to establish a $330 million credit facility for China to purchase Australian wool. The Commonwealth Bank is already involved in financing the wool trade with China. This is a very welcome initiative, coupled with the predicted falls in wool production to the lowest levels since 1982-83 and industry evidence that I have been given in the last two weeks that wool stocks in Chinese bond stores have now fallen significantly and the fact that Wool International has less than 20,000 bales to sell by the end of this year to meet its fixed disposal schedule. This financing initiative may give some added impetus to the current market.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to say that the Australian agricultural sector in general is now beginning to recover from the drought affected situation of 1994-95. Given the market fundamentals, wool should again take its place in that recovery. My latest advice from ABARE is that net value of farm production is forecast to rise by 81 per cent to $4 billion in 1995-96. This will be the highest level in real terms since the late 1980s. The value of farm exports is forecast to rise by around $1.3 billion to $19 billion in 1995-1996. Again, this is the highest since the late 1980s.

ABARE expects the most significant improvement in the cropping sector. This season, total winter grain production is forecast to be 27 million tonnes, some 88 per cent up on 1994-95. Wheat production is forecast to rebound to 16.7 million tonnes in 1995-96, 85 per cent higher than the severely drought affected 1994-95 crop. At the same time, importantly, with these significant production improvements, the world prices for grain remain favourable due to falling world grain stocks, which suggest that Australians growers will obtain a good return for this larger crop.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I apologise for troubling you again. Is it a fact that Comalco and its 600 contract employees are not only behaving in accordance with the law but totally in compliance with your own Industrial Relations Act? Aren't the kind of productivity based rises of $20,000 a year now being achieved at Weipa exactly what you were after when you said you wanted workplace reform? Why won't you stand up to your own Industrial Relations Act by endorsing the IRC's return to work recommendation and pointing out to the ACTU that secondary boycotts are illegal and will not be tolerated by this government?

—Of course I am aware of the claims being made by the CRA in this respect. I am also aware of the industrial relations principles by which we will testing those claims. I have spelt them out and have nothing further to add.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I know you might be jet-lagged and I know it is a real pain to have to address domestic issues but I did not ask you about claims. I asked you simple questions: whether Comalco was acting in accordance with the law and whether their action was in compliance with the Industrial Relations Act. They are very simple questions. You ought to be able to answer those questions. I also asked you whether the productivity increases of $20,000 a year are the sort of increases that you envisaged when you espoused workplace reform. They are very simple questions. Could you please explain whether or not you are committed to upholding the Industrial Relations Act—not whether someone might have made a claim to you somewhere, but whether or not, in your judgment, CRA and Comalco are acting in accordance with the law and exercising their rights?

—The claim in issue is that union members are not being required effectively to sign away their rights of collective bargaining in order to achieve a wage increase; the claim in issue by the company that we want to test against the principles of collective bargaining is that this is not an exercise involving the de-unionisation of the work force. The claim we are concerned about is that there not be discrimination against union members. We are concerned about any state of affairs which effectively demonstrates against union members, which effectively undermines the principles of collective bargaining and which effectively undermines the principles of union membership which has sustained this country through many long decades and will continue to in the future.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer the minister to comments in recent days regarding government support for Australian families. I ask the minister if the government is committed to continuing to ensure Australian families have access to the best health, education, housing and child care?

—I am aware of commitment to families and statements that, indeed, there should be public government support for families. Curiously enough, that comment about the importance of public support for families was made by Senator Hill who said, `A key part of our program will be to demonstrate that there should be public government support for families.' This is no doubt in contrast to what Mrs Bishop said, when she said, `It is not the taxpayers' responsibility'—to paraphrase—`to pick up after families when they break down.' It is quite clear that there is a distinction in the opposition between family policy as defined by Senator Hill and family policy as defined by Mrs Bishop.

PARA.TAB: The opposition have made it clear in this place that most of their family policy is hypothetical. It is quite clear that there is any number of people having a run at it. It is unlike this government. We are absolutely committed to providing support for families. What is more, we provide that support to families whether they are two-parent families or single parent families. We do not attack families if they are single parent families, as the opposition and the Lyons Forum do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, we do not. What a load of nonsense.

—I will get you the quotes, Senator. I will even get you the quotes of the Young Liberal President, who wrote a stinging letter condemning some of your party colleagues for their attack against single parent families.
—What are you talking about?

—I have a longer memory than you, Senator. We also ensure that our policies help families and support them in the choices they make. Whether they choose to have a parent at home with their children, particularly when they are little, or whether they choose to have parents in the work force or studying or training, our government policies support them in doing that, particularly through our significant family payments of over $12 billion. Most of those payments go to single income families.

PARA.TAB: We intend to continue with our targeted program to support families, unlike the opposition where I can quote Mr Howard saying, `Of course, if we got into government, we would have to introduce expenditure cuts. And guess where they'd come from?'

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said, `Guess where they'd come from?' You said that.

—Mr Howard in the same article went on to say that you would be still favouring an introduction of some form of income splitting. Senator, if you want to know what discriminates against single parent families, think of income splitting. That is of absolutely no benefit at all to single parent families. That is one of the points that no doubt you are grappling with, as you said in this place by way of interjection, Senator Hill—`That depends on what model of income splitting you are looking at.' You are condemned out of your own mouth, to be examining income splitting, and we know that is entirely consistent with your policies.
—What have I done?
—You are trying to formulate policy on the run.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly, thank you. This government is also concerned to ensure, as a priority, that we assist families in balancing their work and family obligations. One of the best ways we do that is with our child-care program, including making child care affordable through the introduction of, amongst other things, the child-care cash rebate.

PARA.TAB: I note in the Courier-Mail last week that the opposition have decided `to drop the means tested proposal for the cash rebate', which must come as a great surprise to Senator Minchin because he has still got a notice of motion on the books in this place saying he opposes the cash rebate being non-means tested and promotes the introduction of a means test.

What you have from the opposition is a grab bag of all sorts of bits and pieces of family policy as compared with this government's coherent program of family support which is targeted to assisting families, particularly low income families, with family payments and also our great child-care program, our Medicare and our education policies. The opposition is divided and is scrabbling. We are clear. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Gareth Evans as the Leader of the Government in the Senate.
—We just noticed the reorganisation going on; well done, Whip!

—I am actually recognising the minister's position. I refer the minister to a recent analysis by the Centre for International Economics which shows that the proposed AMH reforms for the meat industry will lead to increases in beef production of $62 million, add 640 people to aggregate employment, improve beef exports and increase Australia's GDP by $26 million per year; and all this if applied to AMH alone. Why is your government intervening to stop workers obtaining the benefits recently detailed by the Industry Commission—gains of $1 billion annually, of which 50 per cent would go to producers, 25 per cent to processors and, significantly, 25 per cent to workers?
—I don't have a brief on that particular subject matter, as must be perfectly self-evident to Senator Troeth. If Senator Collins is willing to volunteer, I am happy to put him in the firing line.
—Senator Troeth may not be aware of what is happening in some of those Queensland abattoirs. I have just come back from a visit to the Rockhampton area of Queensland.

—Top Springs is as far as I get. I was in Rockhampton last week and I visited the meat operations of Consolidated Meat Holdings. At that establishment a very active production schedule is currently being undertaken. Over the last 12 months I have had a number of conversations with the management. That company is about to proceed with a major recapitalisation of the works to increase the throughput from 950 animals a day to something like 1,200. It is going to involve the expenditure of some millions of dollars by the company. I make the obvious point that the company would not be making this significant investment if it was not absolutely satisfied with the industrial relations situation it has within the meatworks.
—Supplementary question, Senator Troeth—sorry, point of order.

—If Senator Evans had passed the correct message to Senator Collins, Senator Collins would know that the question I asked concerned the proposed AMH reforms. That is what I am asking about. I am asking Senator Collins why his government is intervening to stop workers. Senator Collins has had 2 1/2 minutes and he is concentrating on another meat processor. Where is the answer?
—I do not think there is a point of order. I assumed he was being relevant to the question.
—The whole point of the question, Mr President—

—Mr President, when Senator Troeth got up you were unaware whether she was on a point of order or a supplementary question which indicates, with great respect to you, that you were not listening to what was going on in the chamber. It is therefore inappropriate, I would suggest to you, to rule against Senator Troeth's very proper point of order.
—I was concentrating on what was being said and that is why I did not see Senator Troeth.

—The whole point of the question—as we all know, having had the same question asked a dozen times over the last few weeks—is the coalition's assertion that industrial relations problems are the unique fault of the workers and are causing the current problems in the meatworks.

PARA.TAB: What I am telling Senator Troeth, which should be of great relevance to her if she has a genuine interest in the meat industry in Queensland, is that I have just visited a meatworks in the same city as the one that she is talking about. This meatworks is producing an excellent throughput rate. The relationship between the staff and management is excellent. I met with representatives of the union, representatives of management, and all the AQIS meat inspectors on duty that day and great satisfaction was expressed in that works in Rockhampton. I will get to AMH which is in the same city. CMH is putting 950 animals a day through the meatworks. It is currently in the final stages of negotiating the second generation enterprise agreement to the great satisfaction of both management and workers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: Senator Collins has one minute left out of his four minutes. He has not yet got to the nub of my question.
—He said he was getting to it. Senator Collins, I would ask you to get to it.
—In respect of the AMH works—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Well done!

TALK.START.PARA: —The interesting thing about this debate is that everyone in Rockhampton knows the relevance of what I have just said to this issue. The issue is that if the same union can operate in another major meatworks in the same town, wherein lies the problem? We have not intervened to attack the management of AMH. We have intervened to express the Commonwealth's view that the sooner this matter is resolved in the AMH works, and the sooner the AMH works can operate on exactly the same satisfactory basis as Consolidated Meat Holdings, the better for all parties concerned.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Has the minister seen the Financial Review editorial of 13 November urging the introduction of full fees for all university courses and promoting devices such as associate degrees? Since the government's Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill proposes variations to the HECS which financially burden students more and earlier and openly discriminate against some Australian citizens and taxpayers, I ask: what is the government's view of the trend to associate degrees for which students pay full fees? Is not the proposal to require certain New Zealand and Australian citizens and taxpayers to pay their HECS contribution up front discriminatory and in contravention of our obligations under international covenants? Will the government give a categorical assurance now that we are not witnessing a creep towards full university fees?

—Yes, I have seen the editorial in yesterday's Financial Review which called for full fees needed for universities and made a number of comments obviously in support of their view. They can say that that is certainly not the view supported by this government and by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, who on many occasions in the public domain has made it quite clear we do not support the introduction of full fees for graduate courses, which is what the Financial Review editorial was calling for. We have made that very clear on many occasions. We do have policies to ensure equitable access to higher education without the introduction of full fees in Australia. It remains government policy that compulsory up-front tuition fees are not to be charged to Australian students undertaking undergraduate programs at publicly funded universities.

PARA.TAB: Contrary to the assertions in the Australian Financial Review editorial yesterday, universities are not charging fees for compulsory parts of courses or for associate degrees. All students have been enrolled within Commonwealth funded load with students being subject to HECS in the normal way.

Under the Labor government an individual's capacity to pay is not, and will not be, the determinant of access to an undergraduate degree. The government will not be altering its policy of no fees for the Australian undergraduate students. Access must be on merit and academic ability not on an individual's capacity or their parents' capacity to pay, which of course is the opposition's policy and always has been.

Since the white paper reforms of 1988 we have expanded Commonwealth funded places by nearly one-third from 323,000 in 1989 to nearly 425,000 in 1997. We have supported this expansion with a number of equity and access programs targeting the needs of specific groups whose rate of participation in higher education has traditionally been relatively low. We have developed a fair and equitable mechanism under HECS for students to contribute to their own education and to the future provision of education.

The government has drawn a line in the sand and has detailed the broader parameters within which higher education institutions may charge tuition fees for postgraduate students, overseas students and non-award students. Universities cannot charge compulsory fees for materials or the use of equipment or where at the obtaining of such services and materials are compulsory for the completion of a course of study. Senator Bell, I am not aware that any of these measures are contrary to any international obligation that you implied in your question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for the answer such as it was, but I find it hard to see this line in the sand, and I think a lot of Australians do too. It has been covered by a tide of entrepreneurial activities. Minister, the clarity with which you depict that line is not obvious to all. We need to know whether that line in the sand will deal with these associate degrees. They exist. It is your government which has caused them to exist. What are you going to do about stopping them spreading?

—As I have said before in this place on behalf of Mr Crean, we have made it quite clear that an associate degree is not the same as an undergraduate degree and cannot be used as a way of charging a full fee. Where it is provided as some form of limited vocational training, therefore we believe that it is not contrary to the position we have outlined about undergraduate degrees. We have made that very clear. We have made that clear to the universities concerned.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, I refer you to the BIE report, Overview 1995: international benchmarking, and remind you that the government has spent $420 million of taxpayers' money in an attempt to gain improvements in Australia's waterfront productivity. Is the BIE right when it states that in the area of handling of containers Australian productivity has actually stepped backwards while most overseas ports have moved ahead? Is the BIE also correct when it claims that higher loading costs for break bulk reflect the combination of low productivity and relatively high wages in the industry? Judged by productivity improvements, is it not true that the government's waterfront reform process has been a monumental failure and a waste of taxpayers' money? What exactly is the government doing to make the urgent improvements to waterfront productivity which the BIE states are necessary? (Time expired)

—I am indebted to the senator's confidence in my capacity to answer these detailed questions outside my immediate portfolio, but I have no doubt that he originally intended that question to go to Senator Collins. I am happy to ask him to table the question with the notation on it to that effect which, I am sure, he will be willing to do if I am wrong about that. I do not like to undervalue question time so, in the circumstances, I will give the question to someone who can answer it directly on the basis of the brief in front of him.
—I commend this report—
—He should read the full report.

—Correct, Senator Schacht. I commend the BIE report to honourable senators. I also commend, along with reading the report, what I thought was an extremely well-balanced and thoughtful article the other day by, I think, Ross Gittins. In fact, it laid it out very fairly. In addition to the things that Mr Gittins had to say about world's best practice and whom we actually trade with, I do want to add for the correction of the record that the extraordinary assertion that the BIE report carried in its summary—which was unsupported by a single line of analysis in the report itself—about the Sydney airport has since been corrected. I take the opportunity in terms of that question to correct the record in that regard.

PARA.TAB: The actual summary of the report made a reference to the lack of efficiency or the decline in efficiency at the Sydney airport. I am just pointing out that if the senator has an interest in the BIE report and an accurate analysis of it, he should have regard to the correction that has now been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the waterfront?

—In regard to the waterfront, and I am happy to conclude on this point, no more substantive evidence can be given to the substantial improvement in the performance of the Australian waterfront in terms of the coal handling and the wheat handling—all of which has conveniently, of course, been ignored by the coalition in their analysis.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the container rates and the performance of this waterfront, no more substantive evidence can be given of the improvement than the fact that it has already been announced by the two major stevedoring companies in Australia that they are about to invest $350 million in new capitalisation in equipment in Australian ports. That capital improvement will correct a much needed improvement in the efficiency of those ports by correcting what is acknowledged and ignored by the coalition as a problem; that is, the lack of capitalisation in new equipment in our ports and the fact that, as a result of the success of the program and the improvement in productivity, the companies are now going to put substantial sums of money into improving the capital equipment in our ports, which will lead—
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Correct. That is what the report identified was needed. That is what the companies have now formally announced they are going to provide.

—I have a supplementary question for Senator Collins. The report points out that in break bulk, which, for senators' information, is general freight consisting of cargoes which generally defy containerisation, the port of Melbourne average charge per visit is $37,000 and for the port of Taronga in New Zealand about $17,000, and the other Australian ports are the same. We are not talking about investment required there; we are talking about the productivity of everyone. What is the government doing about labour productivity on the waterfront?

—Thanks for the full toss, Senator. You obviously have not bothered to read the report. At least read the Ross Gittins article. It will take you only five minutes. Ports in Australia are owned by state governments. The responsibility for running them and producing those charges rests with state governments.

PARA.TAB: I have to say to you, Senator, that one of the very frustrating things I found when I was transport minister in terms of the port charges which are too high in Australia was when efficiencies that were created in the ports by restructuring and, I might add, the dismissal of workers were then not passed on to the users in lower charges but were paid into the consolidated revenue of the state.

I recall when I was transport minister seeing a photograph in the Sydney Morning Herald of a cheque for $65 million being handed over by the Chairman of the Sydney Port Authority to the Treasurer of New South Wales instead of being passed on to the users in lower port charges. The people who paid the price for that of course were the workers in the port who got sacked to provide the efficiencies and all of that went back to consolidated revenue instead of being capitalised in lower charges to the port users. So take it up with Jeff Kennett, Senator. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Can the minister explain why delays are occurring in the approval and financing processes for HIV-AIDS drug treatments? If these drugs have already been approved by respected drug regulatory authorities in other countries, as is the case with saquinavir and 3TC, why can't the approval process be expedited? When will the internal review by the Department of Human Services and Health on the listing of drugs on the pharmaceutical benefits schedule be completed? Will the report of the review be released publicly? Will the minister issue a ministerial directive that approved anti-viral therapies can be used in combination for HIV treatment and that the cost of this be met by government subsidy? If not, what is the government going to do about approving combination therapies?

—Senator, I will assist you as much as I can with some of those questions. In particular, I can certainly answer the first part about the approval process through the Australian TGA, ADEC and PBAC requirements.

PARA.TAB: It is important to know that we have a process since the Baume inquiry that requires us through the Therapeutic Goods Authority to accept an application for approval of drugs, and that is usually in confirmation with the European format. But we make it clear that Australia retains the responsibility to do its own assurances by examining the data, and so on. We do not take the approval in other countries for medications without very close appraisal of our own. This is, I think, a very important matter for Australian sovereignty in this area, the reputation we have established, and also to be able to assure people that if it is approved in Australia it has been rigorously examined.

We certainly take account of approval in other countries, but it is not the process or the practice to accept carte blanche that if it is approved somewhere else Australia will approve it. We will not resile from that. We have that concern to make sure that Australian processes stand the test, stand rigorous appraisal.

As for the drugs saquinavir and 3TC, I have some detail here, Senator. The usual time from application for approval until finalisation of approval within the TGA is about 255 days. That is the time that people aim for, but in fact the usual time is about 160 days. In other words, we have speeded up the process, sometimes even to 125 days. Drugs of the sort that you have mentioned that demonstrate potential for effectively treating serious or life threatening conditions indeed take priority through the TGA process and sometimes can be turned around in 125 days.

I have been advised that the application for 3TC, which was not lodged until late July this year, is likely to be considered by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee at its first meeting next year, which means the total time for review will be in the order of six to seven months. The application for saquinavir was only lodged with the TGA late last month. Again, it has been under review by the FDA for several months prior to being lodged in Australia. The pharmaceutical benefits branch of the department has been informed that TGA has assigned priority to both 3TC and saquinavir applications so that it can anticipate a speedy referral to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee once it has gone through the TGA and the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee process.

We do take these very seriously, Senator. We have to balance the timeliness of the release of such medications and approval for use, et cetera, with the requirement to make sure that they are thoroughly tested through the Australian system. As to the review of the listing process and when that will be made public, I will certainly take that question on notice and provide the information for you as soon as I can. As to the policy about the use together of antiviral therapies, again I will take that on notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister will appreciate that people with a life threatening illness do not take great comfort in a shortening of the assessment process to 125 days. I think the two delays, both for Australia's reassessment of tests overseas and then to go on to the pharmaceutical benefits list, is a very severe concern. So, given the criticism of this process and of the internal review by community organisations, will the government conduct a high level independent review into HIV-AIDS drug financing, as was recommended by the Baume report and called for by community groups? If not, why not?

—As to the first point, Senator, about the process, it would be of no comfort to you or to anybody else in this country if drugs were hastened through the process, not properly examined, and then found to be either neutral or of no benefit or dangerous to people suffering these sorts of illnesses. At the same time, Senator, it is very proper that, as well as making sure the medications are safe and appropriate, we also look at some kind of cost benefit. Many of these medications are inordinately expensive and it is very important that we do look to the best outcome. I think there is absolutely no doubt about this government's commitment to assisting people with HIV-AIDS. That has been part of this government's concern all along. As to the question about AIDS drug financing and anything further on that matter, I will see if I can get an answer as soon as possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The leader would be aware that the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia yesterday commended the coalition's comprehensive policy directions on tax, banks and superannuation, with COSBOA's chief executive, in yesterday's Herald Sun, stating:

QUESTION.PARA: The Liberals' . . . approach . . . has greater potential for small business than government policies such as pooled development funds and export incentives.
. . . the Liberals are easing the strings in a broader fashion more beneficial to every small business than specifically targeted policies—
. . . will have greater appeal to small businesses . . . than many

Given COSBOA's support for the coalition's policy direction for small businesses and the implied criticism that your policies have failed to address issues of concern to small businesses, why has Labor ignored the plight of small business with its enormous employment consequences? Isn't it a fact that, after 13 years in government, you have simply run out of ideas? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The best possible thing this government could do for small business is to create an economic climate in which small business can flourish—a climate of sustained growth, which we are managing to do with three and three quarters of a per cent growth this year; a low inflation environment; an interest rate environment that is extremely modest by any previous comparison; an environment that is, in fact, generating a very high level of investment and activity because business is profitable at the moment. Business confidence is high at the moment and consumer confidence is high.

PARA.TAB: That is the kind of economy that we have at the moment. It is the kind of economy that we could reasonably be expected to sustain into the foreseeable future.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: I do not know whether the minister has been out of Australia for too long, but I think he has turned up in an economy and he has forgotten what country it is.
—Are you taking a point of order?

—The point of order is that he is either not answering the question or reading the wrong brief, because he said that Australia has a low inflation rate, when we have a high inflation rate; and that we have low interest rates when we have high interest rates. He is in the wrong country. He has got it all wrong.
—There is no point of order. Resume your seat. You have made a nice statement.

—The environment we want to see for small business is one in which bank lending policy is showing a healthy regard for the needs of small business and is making available cash to meet the investment needs of small business. That is happening at the moment. The credit environment is very healthy, and all the figures demonstrate that.

PARA.TAB: You have an environment, on every one of the traditional indicators that have been used to assess the health of the Australian economy, which is conducive to adventurous, creative employment generating activity by small business. We fully and reasonably expect that to continue into the future. Obviously we will continue to have regard to particular policy strategies that may be particularly conducive or helpful to particular kinds of small business in particular sectors. We will keep that under constant review.
If Senator Schacht has anything he would specifically like to add in that respect, please feel free to do so in the remaining time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that we are sharing questions out among ministers, Senator Evans. I call Senator Chapman on a supplementary question.

—It is now patently clear that the Leader of the Government in the Senate has been out of this country much too often and for much too long a period of time, because in the answer he has just given he has given a picture of an economy that, as far as Australia is concerned, is a complete fiction. What he has described simply does not exist in the Australian economy. It is very clear that small business recognises that it does not exist and that small business recognises that the coalition policies offer a better alternative. I ask again: why has the government so failed small business, a sector of the economy which has such tremendous potential for generating employment, as the government clearly has failed, with small business clearly regarding the government as having failed?

—When I am out of the country, as I often am, one of the things I like to do is to compare the performance of the Australian economy with those economies against whom we have traditionally been compared. As far as our growth performance is concerned, of the other 23 members of the OECD, we are doing remarkably well. We are right at the top of that table.

PARA.TAB: When you compare our competitiveness performance, which is increasingly something of acute relevance to small business because of their increasing capacity to compete not only against imports but also in markets overseas, our ranking again is remarkably high and increasingly going up the ranks with each passing year. We are doing very well indeed.
When we compare our employment performance against that of comparable developed countries, for a whole variety of reasons, based on the wages strategy and the social—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order as to relevance: we know Senator Evans likes to compare Australia's performance with that of other countries and we know he has just returned from Latin America, but could he please answer the supplementary question. He is refusing to do so.
—There is no point of order.

—If Senator Campbell had any sense at all he would know that some of the Latin American economies are eminently worth comparing ourselves with these days because they are burgeoning and doing remarkably well. We are making a number of very good contacts with them, not least of all Chile. We are doing all right. We are doing all right by any one of these standards, and that is the best guarantee of an environment that will work best for small business. We are very conscious of the employment generating role played by small business and we will continue to be in the future. (Time expired)

—My question is on a trade matter, so I will break with practice and ask it of Senator McMullan, the Minister for Trade. There are numerous success stories of Australian small business winning export contracts. However, those companies still represent only a small percentage of total business firms. What can be done to encourage the development of a stronger export culture among our business community?
—If Senator Evans does not want to answer this question, I am quite prepared to answer it.
—We export everything from the Northern Territory; 1.5 tonnes of bulls' penises to China.

—It is true that, while the government can do a lot to facilitate market access to generate opportunities and to provide assistance to firms which wish to export, it is not the government which does the exporting; it is the small businesses—the businesses to which Senator Evans referred. There are about 4,500 Australian small businesses regularly engaged in export, but this represents, as he said, a very small percentage of all small to medium enterprises—only about seven per cent of all small to medium enterprises in manufacturing and only about one per cent in services.

PARA.TAB: There is a very large untapped export potential and, therefore, we need to set ourselves an objective of increasing industry and community awareness about export and lifting export as a factor in the business plans of more small to medium enterprises. Austrade and the government have set themselves a goal of 1,000 new exporters over the next year. That would be, as you can tell from the previous figures, a substantial percentage increase. One of the things we want to do to raise the awareness of exporting is highlight the achievements and efforts of our exporters—the sorts of successes that Senator Evans—

TALK.START.PARA: —And Senator Collins.

—and my good colleague Senator Collins so helpfully referred to in his interjection. That is why we have state export awards and national export awards, which Senator Evans will be presenting shortly. We have found that, notwithstanding the benefit and importance of those, they are not comprehensive enough. There are many small companies, particularly out in regional Australia but in the suburbs also, which are not catching the headlines but which are promoting Australian goods and services around the world and increasing job opportunities in their regions. We wanted to do something over and above the central export awards which we have, which are our mainstream recognition, to assist small to medium enterprises around the regions.

PARA.TAB: Recently I wrote to all federal members of the House of Representatives, advising them of an initiative called the export achievement citation to provide recognition to small business in their electorates which might not yet be ready to receive state or national recognition—they might not think they are—but which should be acknowledged and encouraged to continue in their export efforts. The citation will acknowledge those companies as a contributor to economic growth in their region and give the local federal members and Austrade an opportunity to highlight the efforts of local small business.

I am pleased to say that we have had an encouraging bipartisan response. We made the first presentation with my colleague Mary Easson, the member for Lowe, to Aldridge Electrical in the suburb of Rhodes. We made the second here in Canberra with the member for Canberra to Milsearch in Tuggeranong. The third will be made in the electorate of the member for Bennelong shortly. I want to emphasise and encourage all members to participate in this program. I thank those who have already responded. I hope that local media will give these initiatives extensive coverage.

The export achievement citation is designed to acknowledge the export efforts of companies which are giving it a go internationally, to give them some recognition within their local community and to set a benchmark for other businesses that they might aspire to so that we can have more companies exporting as one of the elements to increase export culture in Australia and export performance by Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator McMullan, the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Now that the Chief Executive of Telstra, Mr Frank Blount, has circulated to his senior executives a confidential memo, which has been leaked to me, outlining a shortfall of $534 million in its earnings before interest and tax commitment for 1995-96 and a shortfall of its cash flow by $1.1 billion, will the government give an unequivocal assurance that the severe spending cuts Mr Blount is now introducing will not bring any reduction or deferment whatsoever in Telstra's already slow-moving programs to upgrade inadequate and relatively inefficient Australian services, particularly to so much of rural Australia?

—I do not accept the senator's description of the very good effort that so many Australians have made working for Telecom and Telstra over the years to provide Australia with the high quality telecommunications service which we all enjoy. Denigrating the effort of all those Australians over so many years does not do him any credit, but it does not surprise me. It is another good attempt to win the battlers' vote by pretending that all those people who have been working for so long have not done a very good job. That is a very easy way to score points here, but it does not resonate very well in the community.

PARA.TAB: Australia is well served internationally, as I am aware in my capacity as Minister for Trade, by the activities of Telstra and is being increasingly well served by the improvement in telecommunications services, which is driven by the competition that has been introduced and by the improvements in service that are flowing from it. With regard to the details of Senator Baume's question, I will refer it to the Minister for Communications and the Arts for a response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked a specific question: will the government give an unequivocal commitment to resolve the problem that Telstra admits exists in many areas of rural Australia resulting from these enormous cuts in forecast earnings so shortly after the end of the financial year? Why did Telstra not recognise this problem when spending a fortune on overseas activities? Or when it helped the government with its budget problems this year by paying almost $1 billion—a higher proportion of its profits than usual—in dividends at what is now clearly seen to be the expense of upgrading rural services. I ask the minister for a commitment, and he will not give it, that Telstra will continue in its own program to upgrade particularly those rural services which are grossly inadequate. There is no insult aimed at the workers of Telstra; it is aimed at getting the commitment from this government.

—I undertook to refer the question to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, and I will. But I do not understand how anybody would think that selling Telstra will improve any of the issues which Senator Baume has just raised. It seems to me that the flawed policy position that Senator Alston keeps teasing out, in the hope that they can pretend it is a magic pudding and keep increasing the amount of money they think they will get for it so they can pretend to fund their election promises without having to make cuts elsewhere, will not help telecommunications services in Australia, particularly in rural areas.

PARA.TAB: It is a fundamentally flawed construct which should not be adopted. It will not help to resolve the issues which Senator Baume is crying crocodile tears about. Their policy prescription flies exactly in the face of the position which he is purporting to be concerned about but which we all know he actually does not care a fig about, because otherwise he would not be putting forward the policy which his party is putting forward. I will refer his second question to the minister as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, even though I am sure that the Leader of the Government in the Senate is keenly interested in this topic and will remain so even from overseas. I refer the minister to the Victorian Equal Opportunity Act 1995 and ask: is the minister aware of concerns expressed earlier this year by the then Acting Human Rights Commissioner Kevin O'Connor that several provisions of this legislation could perpetuate discrimination against gay and lesbian people and that these concerns should be examined in the light of Australia's obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights? Did the minister raise these concerns with his Victorian counterpart, the Hon. Attorney-General Mrs Wade? What were the results of those consultations? In general, what does the government intend to do about these concerns?

—The Attorney-General is aware of these concerns. The legislation to which Senator Spindler refers is the Victorian equal opportunity legislation. It was enacted earlier this year. It was criticised by gay organisations as being discriminatory. I also understand that there has been some criticism of exemptions relating to religious beliefs, standards of dress and behaviour and so on, which is a separate issue. Those criticisms are also on the table.

PARA.TAB: Kevin O'Connor, when Acting Human Rights Commissioner, expressed the view that some of these provisions in the legislation could give rise to unfounded and unjustifiable discrimination against gay men and lesbians. That is the concern that I think you are referring to, Senator Spindler. The concerns raised by Mr O'Connor are currently under consideration by the Attorney-General's Department. The Attorney-General informs me that it is and remains the government's policy to raise with state and territory authorities as appropriate concerns over possible breaches of Australia's human rights obligations.

In this particular case, my advice is that the legal and constitutional issues surrounding the Commonwealth's power in relation to discrimination on the grounds of sexual preference are difficult and they are also complex. The issues include, for instance, ICCPR's coverage of sexual preference discrimination.

These legal issues are being considered by the government and they are being assessed by the Attorney-General's Department. There are some pretty basic and fundamental issues which go to the definition of sex discrimination and the relevance of sexual preference within the ICCPR. Once these legal issues have been fully reviewed, the Attorney-General will consider whether these matters should be raised; whether there is legal capacity in fact for the federal government to pursue these matters; and whether these matters do fall within the ambit of the ICCPR. But once these matters have been reviewed, the Attorney-General will raise them with the Victorian Attorney-General, Mrs Wade.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his encouraging answer. Could he give me any indication as to when that review might be completed and when we could expect some action?

—I did not say it was a review, Senator Spindler; I said these matters are being examined. I cannot give you any time line for that, but I will give you an undertaking that I will try to seek one for you.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to the `down payment' offers for free trade being made by Australia at this week's APEC meeting in Japan to accelerate reductions in bound tariff rates. Which Australian industries will be affected by accelerated tariff reductions and what will be their new tariff levels? What are the corresponding down payment offers being made by other APEC countries? Considering the recent increases in US protection that have adversely affected our wheat and dairy exports to Asia, what reductions are being offered by the United States?

—It is remarkable that such a question should come from the representative of a coalition which has been advocating that we should go full speed ahead on tariff reduction. I think they were calling themselves Captain Zero. I think you were a candidate in that election weren't you, Ron, when you were advocating zero tariffs? Weren't you running in that election? I think you were running.

PARA.TAB: Their only demur from our position on APEC has been that they think it should be MFN. Maybe you do not, but Mr Fischer advocates that whatever we offer should be on an MFN basis to everybody. That is the only criticism I can remember hearing from the opposition about our position: not that we were proceeding too quickly, but that we were not making our offers comprehensive enough; that we were not proposing that it should be MFN. We were saying, `Perhaps not'—although it is actually our preferred position. But that has been your criticism—not that we were proceeding too quickly. I suppose I should have realised that you would not have the same policy as Mr Fischer, but I was not aware that you were so publicly part of the conspiracy to undermine him.

Can I deal with the rumour that has been perpetuated by some initially inaccurate reporting of what I said in briefing journalists and which led to a misunderstanding by one industry association, that Australia was going to offer some reduction in the effective rates of tariff at Osaka. Although I am not going to give all the details of what we intend to do—because it is all part of a balanced package that we are seeking to achieve in Osaka and I do not intend to weaken our capacity to get the best outcome by disclosing our hand too early—I can tell you that what we are proposing to do will relate to the bound tariff, that is the bindings that we offer, not the effective rates, and that they will therefore not affect the operative rates of tariff in any area of Australian industry and certainly not even the bound rates in the more sensitive areas.

As to what the other countries will offer, I have a fairly broad understanding of what is likely and so far it looks encouraging, though it is not for me to announce their offers before they put them on the table in Osaka. I will wait for them to do that. But I think you will see that it is a useful, balanced package which will be a clear indication of progress towards trade liberalisation in the region. Australia will do all right out of it, Senator. You do not need to be concerned about that.

I am pleased to say that the one industry association that misunderstood the report and put out a statement criticising our offer, when they had explained to them what we were actually proposing to do, put out a revised press statement accepting our assurances and indicating their satisfaction with the proposal we were intending to put. They are quite right. They should be satisfied with it. It will be good, it will be in our interest and it will attract a balanced response from the other 17 members. It will be a good package in Australia's interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question.

—Do you always have to behave like a clown, Senator Collins? Mr President, I asked a specific question about new tariff levels and the minister did not answer that. I ask again: what will the new tariff levels be and what industries will be affected? Minister, obviously you have had some discussions with industries. You must have made those facts available. Will you make them available to the Senate?

—With respect to Senator Boswell, to make our position transparent before we finish the process of negotiation would not strengthen Australia's bargaining position with the other 17 members and I do not intend to do it.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Parer this day, relating to an industrial dispute in Weipa, Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure whether Senator Evans actually did provide an answer to Senator Parer's question, but I have moved that we take note of the answer anyway. This government is beholden to the ACTU and the trade union movement. That is why the government during question time today failed to refuse to condone the trade unions' defiance of the Industrial Relations Court. If the government wants to tell us that its system of industrial relations in this country is so good—the system that it has implemented—it should have the courage to stand up and say that the decisions of that court ought be abided by by the trade union movement.

PARA.TAB: But the ALP is the wholly owned subsidiary of the ACTU. The ACTU funds the ALP.

SPEECH.PARA: It endorses most of the members because the trade unions have the bloc votes, and it directs the policy direction. We had no clearer example of that than in today's Examiner in my home state of Tasmania. The new Tasmanian union chief, Lyn Fitzgerald, flexed her political muscle and told a very small gathering—I must say it was an embarrassingly small gathering—of Labor Party supporters in the text of her address of `the detailed union priorities for women in work and what the Labor Party would do in this area if it wins office'.

PARA.TAB: So we had the President of the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council announcing on behalf of the Australian Labor Party what Labor would do if it were to win office. That is why the government is unable today to come out and say that it does not condone the behaviour of the trade union movement, that it will call upon the trade union movement to behave in a responsible way. For it to do so would be to defy the funders of the trade union movement and to defy the people who endorsed most of the Labor people on the other side of the chamber.

Mr Kelty is reported in today's Canberra Times as taking off the gloves and saying, `To be beaten on this one is for the union movement to lose its heart, soul and purpose.' Well, that is a great surprise to the vast majority of workers in this country, because the trade union movement has never had a heart, has never had a soul and has lost its purpose a long time ago. That is why the workers of this country are leaving the trade union movement in absolute droves.

When the workers are given a choice they leave the trade union movement. That is why the Labor Party senators over there are so concerned with our policy of giving workers choice. By giving the workers choice, do you know what we are in fact doing? If they no longer had to pay their compulsory trade union fee, in rough terms that would be equivalent to a $6 a week pay increase to each one of those workers.

Here the government talks about an $8 a week safety net wage increase. They could deliver that to the workers of this country by simply saying, `We will no longer allow compulsory trade unionism.' But the Labor Party is scared of giving choice to the workers because they know what the workers will do. The workers will leave the trade union movement because they get better deals under enterprise bargaining than they do under the centralised award system. The workers know that. That is why they are moving in that direction.

Now the Labor Party and the trade union movement are desperately trying to regain the confidence of the workers. That is why they got rid of Martin Ferguson—told him to go into the parliament—to get Jennie George to assist. But I have to say that Jennie George was able to attract only about 200 people to a rally in Western Australia, which is hardly the sort of inspiring confidence that the trade union movement needs. If they want to get the confidence of the workers again, if they want to get support from the workers, I suggest that they make unionism voluntary, stop being henchmen for the ALP and in bed with the ALP and look after the interests of the workers rather than the interests of the ALP.

When that culture changes, then I believe the economy will be a lot better off. People will have greater choice, people will have greater incomes, and there will be more jobs within the community. The government's failure to condemn the trade unions' activities in relation to this dispute that is currently on foot is a condemnation of the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, Senator Abetz has demonstrated his absolute lack of any understanding of industrial relations in this country and in particular any understanding of the history of the Weipa dispute. The position is that, for a number of years now, the CRA company and a number of its subsidiaries have set out on a deliberate course to de-unionise their work sites. They took that action not as a result of any industrial disputation or any problems with the unions but simply because they hate unions. The management of CRA has set out to get rid of trade unions off their sites.

PARA.TAB: Senator Abetz talks about complying with decisions and orders of the Industrial Relations Court and about enterprise bargaining. For a number of years now, the CRA company has ignored decisions of the Industrial Relations Commission of this country. It has deliberately flouted decisions of the Industrial Relations Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us an example.

—I will give you an instance. In 1990, one of the subsidiaries of the CRA company, Peak Hill goldmine, negotiated a consent award with the Australian Workers Union for one of its goldmines in New South Wales near Cobar. In fact, its general manager praised that award as being one of the most forward thinking modern awards under the new industrial relations provisions. But within 12 months, what did the CRA subsidiary company do? It went around and convinced its employees, after holding three or four secret ballots with no advice to the union whatsoever, that they should resign from the union. On what basis? They offered them a bribe. The bribe was to give them huge pay increases in return for giving up any right to collective bargaining or any right to unionisation.

PARA.TAB: That is what the CRA company has set out to do. It has not been about productivity. It has not been about enterprise bargaining. The individual contracts that have been imposed upon workers through the CRA company by virtue of basic blackmail are not in any way, shape or form enterprise bargaining. If you hold to that view, Senator Abetz, it demonstrates your total lack of any understanding of what enterprise bargaining is in this country, what collective bargaining is in this country and how the award system operates.

There were longstanding awards in place covering the operations of Comalco at Weipa and at each of the other CRA sites. But what was the CRA's view about those awards? Ignore them. Forget the fact that they existed. Forget that there were processes through the Industrial Relations Commission in order to negotiate enterprise agreements and in order to negotiate or, indeed, have arbitrated changes to the awards. No, the CRA company said, `We will buy off the workers with huge pay increases. But, more importantly, we will discriminate against those workers who will not take the bait.'

Over a long period of time, CRA wore down quite a lot of workers. But there is a group of workers at Weipa who have refused to buckle under and who have refused to accept those draconian conditions that if you want a wage increase you can't have a union represent you and if you accept that wage increase you hand over for all time to the company the right to set your wages and working conditions. That is the sort of attitude you are supporting in this country today by the actions of CRA. There is a group of workers up there who are fighting with the only weapon they have left—that is, their labour—to stand up for a fundamental democratic principle that they will not be discriminated against and that they will not be forced to do the same work but accept $20,000 a year less simply because they want to remain members of a trade union and to be represented by a trade union.

The actions of CRA throughout this entire dispute—which did not start yesterday as Senator Abetz seems to think but which started two years ago—have been an affront and an attack upon the fundamental democratic principles of this country. They are the sorts of principles that unions like Solidarity in Poland and COSATU in South Africa fought for and people gave their lives to protect. That is a fundamental principle of democracy—that organised labour and workers can have access to organisations such as trade unions to protect their rights. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a wonderful speech and it would be a wonderful speech at a union rally if only it were backed up by the tiniest little portion of fact. I know Senator Forshaw has a lot of difficulty with fact. I know he has a special regard for it—he saves it for special occasions—but I think it is appropriate that we get to the facts of this matter. Unlike Senator Forshaw, I spent last weekend in Weipa. I was there. Instead of talking to the company, I was talking to the workers and the shop stewards, and this is what they had to say about the matter.
—The shop stewards?
—Yes, the shop stewards. Senator Burns is shocked. The National Party is happy to talk to the workers, Senator Burns. You don't have a monopoly—

PARA.TAB: Senator Burns interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Burns, stop interjecting please.

—Madam Deputy President, if I could just have the tiniest bit of courtesy and silence from the other side, I might educate the ignorants that sit over there. The facts are that the workers there are not on strike because they are fighting for collective bargaining, as the ACTU and the Labor Party would have you believe. The truth is that there was very little separating the workers from the management the other weekend. The difference was simply a question of representation in negotiations. It was not on the basis that the workers wanted collective bargaining; they wanted somebody to have a chance to represent them.

PARA.TAB: I can understand the concerns that the workers have. These are the issues that you will sort out amicably in a situation where you have proper enterprise bargaining. But, on that very same weekend, Mr Pallas from the ACTU came in and told the workers, `No, this isn't a fight about who is going to represent you in negotiations with the company. This is a fight, brothers, for collective bargaining. This is a fight for everything that people fought for, died for and shed their blood for in South Africa.'

That is what we hear from Senator Forshaw. What a lot of garbage! It had nothing to do with that at all: it was simply about who was going to represent them. These are the facts. The workers at Comalco at Weipa are quite happy to sign the staff agreement. They want to sign the staff agreement because signing the staff agreement—

TALK.START.PARA: —The unions will not let them.

—Senator Abetz is right—the unions will not let them. Signing the staff agreement will give them between $10,000 and $20,000 a year more than the award will give them. That is fact one. Fact number two is that the company was quite happy to have those people come back to work. There was no problem there. Fact number three is that the company was quite happy to have those people belong to a union. This is not a battle where the company is trying to drive people out of unions. The union official that I spoke to said that the company had made it perfectly clear that the workers were perfectly welcome to remain in a union, should they so desire, with no financial penalty.

PARA.TAB: The only issue that was separating the company and the workers the previous weekend was whether the workers had the right to have an advocate represent them in future negotiations with the company. I understand the concern that the workers may have in that regard. If it had not been for the intervention of Mr Pallas perhaps this situation would have been sorted out. Instead, what happened was the ACTU—Senator Murphy's mates and Senator Forshaw's mates; all the vested interests on the other side of the chamber—came in and said, `Brothers, this is a fight for collective bargaining. This is a fight to preserve the integrity of the union movement. This is a fight for what people shed their blood for in South Africa.' That is what Senator Forshaw would have us believe.

It is none of those things. It could have been sorted out but for the intervention of the ACTU. Now the government will not even answer simple questions about the facts of this dispute. We had Senator Forshaw giving us another five minutes of his prejudice, five minutes of his ignorance, and five minutes of his obfuscation. I believe the Australian public deserves far better than Senator Forshaw, far better than Senator Murphy and, indeed, far better than the ALP sitting on the treasury bench.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that it would be very nice if people on the opposition benches really understood the issue. If they did, they would not talk such rubbish. Those opposite talk about the history of the trade union movement as if they know why it came into existence, as if they know what people in the leadership and the rank and file think, and as if they know what it is all about.

PARA.TAB: I, as the president of the metalworkers union in Queensland for many years, had responsibilities in areas of construction. On many occasions I successfully negotiated two-year contracts and agreements to ensure that both sides received the advantages of reasonable industrial peace while the contract was in existence. They were collective contracts.

Back in the 1960s and the 1970s when the mother lode was found and Weipa first came into existence it was recognised that there was a need to do something about establishing an award. The company at that time was quite happy to sit down and put forward some of its demands as to what should be contained in that document. The unions did likewise. A construction agreement came into being.
