For many years it worked quite well. There were some small disputes as a result of, for instance, 1,000 workers on the job and no doctor being available. A sister had to take care of the workers' health and deal with accidents that might occur. There were really no arguments about wages and conditions. With the commencement of production of aluminium and the beneficiation of the bauxite another award was necessary. That award contained an area which catered for construction workers. For many years there was not much construction work carried out in that area. As I mentioned earlier, a lot of other agreements were negotiated in Queensland in areas such as coalmine construction.

On the odd occasion of their finding some kaolin they had to then carry out some construction and build a small refinery. People were required to go there from other sites. Comalco, which is the company that has now been able to bring into being contract arrangements with individuals of some hundreds, even though they have not done it for everyone, had an award in an area for construction which was miles behind everyone else. Then they had a strike on their hands because when people worked in other areas they found themselves to be $50 and $60 a week behind everyone else.

I spoke with the company and we set out to try to do something within the award to give those people some wage justice, even though we might not have been able to give them everything they had been getting everywhere else. As a result of that, I journeyed up there and talked for a long time with the people whom I represented, including a number of other unions, and with the company. We both agreed to go into that area and vary the award in a very modest way.

After that, there were always periodic negotiations, about every two years, on areas of production in relation to aluminium and refineries around Australia. There had been no real hassles but all of a sudden we found that Comalco, through the agency of CRA, and others decided they wanted to have people on individual contracts.

People said this new idea of individual contracts was trying to take us back 100 years. The Tolpuddle Martyrs back in the 1800s were sent out here because they dared to get together and ask their farmer employers collectively for a wage increase from about tenpence to a shilling a day. They got sent out here for 15 years. It might have been more pleasant to live out here except they were away from their families, but they were sent out here because they dared to bargain collectively.

From that time onwards, from the 1900s, the trade union movement grew and was able to collectively bargain and to put in place arbitrated awards. Now the company sees an opportunity to make an offer of some $20,000 a year to more people if they will make individual agreements. Senator O'Chee talked about talking to the shop steward who represented them. When you make a collective agreement you do it one on one, you do not need a shop steward. All your problems will be attended to by you and by the company. It is an effort to destroy the trade union movement and disadvantage workers. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to take note of the answer given by Senator Gareth Evans in response to a question from Senator Parer. It is important that we look quite rationally and from a factual point of view at the issue raised in the question. With regard to the Weipa situation and CRA you have to look back at history in my own state where the company CRA sought to implement individual contracts. It did so in a way that I do not think any Australian person, even those on the other side of the chamber, would support.

PARA.TAB: For three years the unions representing workers at that site sought to negotiate with the employer for wage increases that were consistent with the accord agreement. For three years those workers at that site did not get a wage increase. The company then turned around and offered wage increases of between $8,000 and $13,000 per employee but it did so on the basis that they would sign up on an individual contract, that they would not be a member of a union and that they would basically remove all their rights with regard to any national wage increases that may come on. There were no rights to that. They had an individual contract and nothing else.

There was a ballot. I know the opposition has a position as to how ballots ought to be conducted—that is, they ought to be secret ballots. It was a secret ballot, and 80 per cent of the people rejected the offer.

It was against that background that the company thought about it and said, `Okay, we will go about this another way.' They came up with a different offer and basically told people that if they did not like or accept it, the company would seek other people to do the job. In such times of high unemployment, that scared people—nobody would disagree with that; we have to acknowledge it. I do not think that is the Australian way of negotiating employment. We ought to have a fairer system, the one the government has sought to implement. It is one on which the government has a very proud record. We have sought to have an industrial relations system that allows people in small business to negotiate individually and, more importantly, it guarantees people the right to be able to be represented collectively.

What CRA have done at Weipa is choose a course of action that seeks to exclude that right. Even the opposition leader, Mr Howard, has said on many occasions that he supports the right of people to choose to be represented collectively. So it is fundamentally wrong for you to come in here and question the government on its position.

Can I say that essentially this matter ought to be resolved by the Industrial Relations Commission. They have sought to do that and there is a process in place. It is my understanding that if the Industrial Relations Commission makes a finding a certain way, the government may well intervene in the dispute. With regard to compliance with the Industrial Relations Commission's decisions, I have had some personal experience with another company, namely North Broken Hill Peko. I took two cases to the Industrial Relations Commission as the secretary of the timber workers union. I won both those cases against the company fairly and squarely. They were caught with the underpayment of workers whom they had stood down illegally.

The company refused to pay them and said it would fight the matter in the court. It was only a very small state branch of the union that I was representing. We did not have the financial capacity to pursue that claim. To this day, that decision has not been honoured and the company has never paid those workers. It is very clear, in terms of Australian workers, that this is the very reason we have to have an industrial relations system that has fairness and equity in it for all sides. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been quite a while since we have had such a degree of disinformation and obfuscation from the government on a simple basic point. The facts of the matter are that the dispute at Weipa has arisen as a consequence—
—Tell us your experience about all these things; your personal experience.

—My personal experience is that under the horrendous laws in Queensland when I first graduated, to get a job as a resident at the Townsville General Hospital I had to join a union—and I refused. But I could not get paid until I joined the union so, in the end, I said, `Very well, I will go to your union meetings.' They said, `You can't come to our union meetings,; they were run by a communist. I will take you through that, Senator Burns, in great detail some time. Regrettably, I have first hand experience of people like you in the union movement, so I speak with some authority.

PARA.TAB: What we have here is a law which is being wilfully broken by a rebel union. The government brought in the Industrial Relations Act. The company concerned has complied meticulously with the act; it has not broken the law in any way. It has offered under the act the opportunity for individual work agreements. As a consequence of these individual agreements, it has had increased productivity; it has been able to pay those employees more. The lazy, loafing bully boys in the union movement do not like it. It was quite wrong for Senator Forshaw to get up and say that the company had penalised the workers who did not join the enterprise agreement. That was not true. They are paid at the level that the union negotiated for them. They are paid their award; the law is being complied with.

The opposition has no part in this at all. We are just bystanders. We are not pushing a case one way or the other, other than pressing that the government has a moral obligation and a legal obligation to see that its laws are complied with, and the laws are not being complied with at present.

The only person who has defended the law has been, strangely enough, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton. Mr Brereton has said, much to the great anguish of Senator Burns, Senator Forshaw, Senator Evans and the rest of them, `I don't see anything wrong with it. The law is the law and the law has not been broken'.

But the union movement complies with the law only when it suits them or when it wants to advantage itself in a way that suits its narrow ends at the time. It is time the union movement grew up and recognised that in this day and age we all have a corporate interest in working together, that the old class warfare basis, the narrow sectional interests which are still the hallmark of the Keltys and the Jenny Georges of this world, disappeared 50 or 60 years ago and that to persist with those attitudes costs all of us a great deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to reflect on the comments contributed by Senator Abetz during the debate on this matter. Firstly, he used his opportunity today simply to add fairly typical Liberal rhetoric with respect to the Australian Labor Party and the role of trade unions and also in relation to the concept of choice.

PARA.TAB: On previous occasions I have dealt with the concept of choice. The view offered to us by the opposition is an extremely naive view that the parties come to the table on an equal basis. I know from my experience in the trade union movement that that is far from the real case. Tell a shop assistant working for a large Australian company that they are in the position to negotiate their position unrepresented against their manager or against the director of the company.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have no problem with union representation.

—The problem with representation is that reflected on by Senator O'Chee. He does not understand that the issue of representation relates to the ability for people to choose to be represented collectively. That is the connection between collective representation and bargaining and representation, which he himself highlighted was a fundamental issue in the Weipa dispute—representation and collective bargaining. The two are intimately connected and fundamentally important to workers of the Australian community. Collective bargaining and representation, Senator O'Chee, are fundamentally connected, and you displayed your ignorance or naivety in suggesting otherwise earlier.
—Order! The time for the debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to explain a matter of a personal nature in accordance with standing order 190.
—Is leave granted?
—I need to know what it is about before I give leave. Does the senator claim to have been misrepresented?
—He has not said so.
—I am asking before I give leave.
—Senator Hill is asking whether or not you are claiming to be misrepresented.

—That will be part of my personal statement. My personal statement goes to matters which affect me, Senator Hill. I am asking for leave in accordance with standing order 190, and I have read the words out as they are provided for in the standing orders.
—Is leave granted?
—Yes. Give him leave to make his comment, if you wish.
—You might find this amusing, Senator McMullan. Madam Deputy President, I am not prepared to give leave unless I know the nature of the matter and for how long the senator wishes to speak.
—Do you wish to comment on that, Senator Crichton-Browne?

—Yes. I have about four hours and 128 pages to go. Seriously, Madam Deputy President, the matters essentially relate to an article in today's West Australian. They also touch upon an interview given by Senator Knowles on 6PR and an interview she gave on the ABC Utting program in Western Australia. The comments are based around those statements and those interviews, by and large.
—Is leave granted?
—No, I do not give leave for that.

—Madam Deputy President, the interpretation of standing order 190 in the 17 years I have been in this chamber has always been on a very narrow focus that a senator claims to have been misrepresented, and that narrow point is the point for which the senator is granted leave. Leave is always granted but for only that narrow point that the senator has been misrepresented on. It is not a general licence to conduct a four-hour debate or even a 40-minute debate.
—The wording of standing order 190 does not specify in that fashion, Senator. Is leave granted?
—The custom that we have accepted is to allow senators the opportunity under—
—Give him leave to make his statement if you wish.
—Thank you.
—I think that is what you are doing.
—I seek leave to contribute to this discussion.
—I could say no.

—You could say no if you like. The custom in this place has been to give a senator leave to make a personal explanation under standing order 190 when a senator claims to have been misrepresented. That has meant that there have been certain limitations upon the debate, and they are for sensible and obvious reasons.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crichton-Browne has not sought to avail himself of the usual custom and the courtesy that flows from that custom, but rather has sought to contribute to an unended contribution on matters that he describes as personal. If we were to give leave in those circumstances, that, in effect, would enable him to speak for as long as he likes on any subject that he likes. It is a good try, Senator, but you would know that is not a circumstance in which leave is normally given.

If he claims to have been misrepresented and seeks to make a personal explanation under standing order 190 and if he gives us an indication that it is for a reasonable period of time, then obviously we would accord with the normal custom in this place and give leave. But he has not so sought as of now and, in those circumstances, in the terms in which he has sought leave, we would not be prepared to give it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps a further explanation might overwhelm Senator Hill with a sense of decency and he will reconsider. May I, for the benefit of Senator Hill and the chamber, read advice I received from the clerk as a result of a disagreement, where I found myself very much out of step with Senator Hill's judgment about the provisions of standing order 190, and also your rulings, Madam Deputy President?
—Senator Crichton-Browne, I do not think that is appropriate at this stage.

—I am sorry. I am just trying to explain to Senator Hill what my intention is and perhaps to enlighten him a little more on standing order 190. I am sure he will find it a decent and sensible way to accommodate me.
—Standing order 190 is basically quite clear and Senator Hill and Senator MacGibbon have spelled out the convention that usually operates under which leave may be granted for you to proceed.
—Can I do what Senator Hill did, and seek leave for a couple of minutes to explain what I am seeking to cover?
—Is leave granted?
—For a couple of minutes.
—May I repeat the words of the clerk:

SPEECH.PARA: A request for leave to make a personal explanation under standing order 190 does not have to be based on a claim to have been misrepresented. The standing order specifies only that a senator may request leave to explain matters of a personal nature and such matters may not be debated. Senators habitually ask for leave under standing order 190 on the basis that they have been misrepresented and the leave is granted on that basis. If you seek to make a personal explanation under standing order 190 in the future, I suggest that you indicate the nature of the explanation that you seek to make.

In accordance with what I judge to be very sound advice, I have sought leave within those terms. I have said there was an article in today's West Australian which visited upon my speech yesterday and I have said that there were matters raised in two interviews which also visited upon me.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill, if you had granted me leave when I asked for it, I would be sitting down now. It will probably be five or six minutes. I think they are all matters that, if your name was Senator Crichton-Browne, you would be on your feet about. If I breach standing order 190, Senator Hill, I am sure you will be on your feet. I am sure the Deputy President is able to made a judgment about whether I am in breach or not.
It is not a try on. It is within the proper provisions of the standing orders which I seek, as best I can, to conform with in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne is seeking leave to make an explanation under standing order 190. Is leave granted?

—I do not understand why the honourable senator wants to do it in this way. If there was an article in the paper in which he thinks his position has been misrepresented, I can understand his wish to put the record straight. We would give him leave to do so. If there were some radio interview in which his position has been misrepresented, I would take a similar view.

PARA.TAB: If it remains as open ended as it is at the moment, what is being asked of us is too much. I do not know the nature of this radio interview. I have no idea what it is about. I have no idea what Senator Crichton-Browne will say. He said he is sure the matter will take only five or six minutes. There is no obligation on him to sit down then.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a man of principle and of my word.
—You just said you wanted to finish off reading 130 pages of a document. If it is a personal explanation I will give leave. If it is not I will not.

—I wish to support Senator Hill's point of view. There is a lot of give and take in this chamber. We are guided by what we have done in the past. We simply cannot have a situation where the program for the day, the government's program, can be set aside by a capricious act. In the absence of good reason, this must be viewed as a capricious act. I have an enormous respect for the clerk's opinion, but it is just an opinion. I am not aware that it is of a higher standing than mine. I say that with the greatest respect to the clerk.

PARA.TAB: We had a review of the standing orders. It gave us the current wording of the present standing order 190. The previous standing orders specifically said that a senator who believed he had been misrepresented could seek leave to make a statement in the Senate.

It was in light of past practice that the present standing order was written as a guide to reasonable men. Any occupant of the chair must be guided by precedent. The precedent has been that leave is granted to break into the program only when there has been a misrepresentation of a senator's position.

Madam Deputy President, you suggested that we could look at this new standing order 190 and place a literal interpretation on it. I can see an administrative minefield in this chamber if we go through all the standing orders. They have been largely rewritten not once but probably twice or three times in the period I have been a senator. They have been rewritten in light of a reasonable approach by reasonable senators. If we go through this relatively new set of standing orders and apply a literal interpretation to all 210 standing orders we are in for a great deal of confusion and lack of goodwill in this chamber, which is entirely unnecessary. Let us be guided by precedent.

If Senator Crichton-Browne has a specific point or a number of specific points where he has been represented, let him seek leave and we will grant it quite freely. We are not in the business of granting unlimited licence to speak for as long as he likes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The standing order has not changed since 1903. It is only in comparatively recent times that people have sought to make an explanation by claiming to have been misrepresented. It is a comparatively new development.
—Madam Deputy President, I am not sure that in the course of this discussion I would describe you as `a reasonable man', but I am sure this is a circumstance that we can pursue reasonably.

PARA.TAB: I appreciate the new found concern for the government's program and the objective assessment of opinions offered from various sources. Both of the views expressed by Senator MacGibbon I share. While there might be some expediency in the government giving Senator Crichton-Browne licence to pursue this matter at the moment, we do not want to open up circumstances where precedents are set and could be used continuously to disrupt the government's program.

As I understood it from Senator Crichton-Browne, he is talking about five minutes, which is a very long explanation under this particular standing order and pushing the outer limits of what I think is reasonable.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, Senator McMullan, you do not know to what extent the comments have been made to my response. It is two pages of typing.

—In my view, on the basis of the precedents that I have seen, if you wish to make a statement longer than that, there are other forums of the Senate which people have used other than that of a personal explanation to achieve that purpose. I have to say that if we had given leave for five minutes that would have been over by now and we would have been on to other business of the Senate, which I would prefer.

PARA.TAB: I share some of the concerns that have been expressed, but from our point of view, subject to an understanding of that time limit not being extended—and I accept that it is not an enforceable understanding, but I am prepared to take it on face value at this stage—we would be prepared to give leave, but I do not want to make light of the serious concerns which Senator Hill and Senator MacGibbon, in particular, raised. We do not want to have an open-ended new precedent established here. I think it is within, although at the outer limits of, the standing orders, and I would only be prepared to accept it on the basis of a working agreement of the time limit of the sort outlined—five minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, Madam Deputy President, according to Odgers this procedure is usually employed to respond to some misrepresentation of a senator. But, as appears from the literal interpretation of the wording in the standing order and as is the view of Odgers, certainly a senator may be given leave under this standing order to explain matters of a personal nature, but such matters may not be debated. If Senator Crichton-Browne is seeking leave, the leave will be given only in these terms; that is, to explain matters of a personal nature, for a period of five minutes. If he is prepared to acknowledge that is what he is seeking to do, then in the spirit that has been put to us by Senator McMullan, notwithstanding our reservations for obvious reasons, I would agree to that.

—Madam Deputy President, I will have to consider in the future how I deal with these things because it seems to me that for base political reasons the rights of individual senators now have been trampled upon to the point where they have been frustrated in conforming with the standing orders. I will speak within the parameters that Senator Hill outlines, because otherwise he is not going to give me leave. If I stray, perhaps he will jump to his feet.

PARA.TAB: It is not clear to me—and he and I had an exchange last time—what he interprets the standing orders to be or not, but in the spirit of good faith I am not going to accept leave from him and then trample on what I have given an undertaking to do. So, if I do trespass—and it will not be deliberate—I am sure he will get to his feet.

Perhaps we ought to have some consultation afterwards as to how these standing orders are allowed to be used in the way in which they are intended; otherwise I can refuse leave every time the opposition get to their feet. I think they have sought leave 10 times in the last two days, and I have ignored it. But, when I have sought leave quite legitimately, it has been denied. I wonder now whether I might proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, Senator, the condition was that it be a personal explanation taking not more than five minutes.
—When I say five minutes, it might be five minutes and 10 seconds—I do not know—as I do not want to have to speak as quickly as I did yesterday. I want to at least present a civilised explanation.
—Is leave granted for Senator Crichton-Browne to proceed?
—If I am allowed to give leave for five minutes.
—Senator Hill says leave will be granted for five minutes. Is that acceptable?
—It is not, but I have no choice, have I? I will make a note of this. Yesterday it happened to me, and it is not going to happen for the next three weeks.

PARA.TAB: In the West Australian yesterday, Mr Tony Barrass wrote a very unpleasant four-paragraph article about me. It was trashy garbage which any dolt could have scribbled. It was biased, prejudiced, ill-informed and factually incorrect. It refers to my address to the Senate yesterday. Mr Barrass refers to the fact that I used the guise of debating the money bills. It was Mr Barrass's first day in this building as a political reporter. I hope that his skills improve. He said to me that he does not report hard facts but impressions. He is certainly sticking with his brief on this document.
Mr Barrass refers to comments made by Senator Bolkus which tended to give the impression that Senator Bolkus was making an unpleasant reference to me. Senator Bolkus said:

SPEECH.PARA: For the next three weeks we will probably see a tag team match with the other side trying to stop Senator Crichton-Browne from putting his facts into the record. I do not think it serves a purpose for the opposition to do that. It is an unseemly sight from this side, watching this Punch and Judy show.
He went on to say:
The point of order is that there are frivolous points of order raised by the opposition in order to stop Senator Crichton-Browne.
That is quite a different interpretation to the one put by Mr Barrass.

PARA.TAB: The other matter I want to raise concerns an interview given by Senator Knowles on an ABC program on 11 September. In referring to a meeting of the Liberal Party at Marble Bar which we both attended, she said of me:

SPEECH.PARA: Well he was attacking us over the distribution of the information, what he called an alleged restraining order . . . I did not release that information, Eoin Cameron did not release that information—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Crichton-Browne said he was not seeking to argue that he had been misrepresented in something that was stated and that he was seeking to now put the record straight. He was standing to explain a matter of a personal nature. It seems to me that what he is now apparently seeking to do is what he said he would not seek to do, which is raise an issue out of an apparent statement of Senator Knowles.

PARA.TAB: He is straying exactly in the way that Odgers cautions him against, which is that matters may not under this standing order be debated. If he wants to explain a matter of a personal nature, he has been given leave to do so. Under that, he cannot enter into a debate on something that Senator Knowles may or may not have said. There are different times and processes for covering that. He has already indicated that he is not seeking to put the record straight. I cannot see that what he is saying at the moment is explaining a matter of a personal nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order: Senator Knowles described some comments of mine as lies. That is not true, and I am seeking to explain that it is not true.
—Why didn't you say you claim to be misrepresented?
—That is your interpretation of the standing order on which I am prevailing, or perhaps travailing.
—It is important to explain the extent to which you have been misrepresented and not debate the issue.

—I am. I am quoting the words of the transcript. I can do no more than that. Forgive me, but I am simply quoting what was misrepresented about my position. Senator Knowles claims that I attacked her at Marble Bar, when I did not mention her name. Senator Knowles says that I attacked her over the distribution of the information. She continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . he called an alleged restraining order. I did not release that information, Eoin Cameron did not release that information, why do you keep going around, branch after branch, constantly saying that we released that information.
Her name was not even mentioned at the meeting. I hope that is a personal explanation. She said about me on the same day on the 6PR program:

Senator Crichton-Browne continues to allege that I and a number of colleagues were instrumental in distributing the information about the restraining order . . . I simply pointed out at that meeting that people cannot get away with going on and telling simply, telling things that simply are not true about others.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not think this is in accordance with standing order 190. This is a debate on matters that were apparently stated by Senator Knowles in a radio broadcast. It is not within the terms of the standing order that gives the senator the right to explain matters of a personal nature. It is a political debate. For that debate to take place under the guise of this personal explanation is an abuse of the process. I put that to you for your consideration.

—On the point of order: Senator Knowles made certain allegations against me on 6PR. I am reading them. I am then going to say that I have been misrepresented, that that is not the case and that the case is as follows. I honestly do not know what Senator Hill's interpretation is of standing order 190. I can do no more. Senator Knowles called me a liar and said that I told untruths. I am quoting her. I am going to say that I have been misrepresented and that that is not the truth. If I cannot explain that, I think we should remove standing order 190 from the standing orders. Madam Deputy President, I await your ruling.
—Presumably, what you have just said is your explanation—that what has been alleged and you have read out is not true.
—I have not finished reading it. That is what I have tried to do.
—It needs to be a personal explanation—not a debate on a different set of facts.

—I am not debating. I am simply reading out the transcript, and then I will say I have been misrepresented by those words and that they are not correct. Then I will say why they are not correct. It will take me a couple of minutes. If I cannot read out where I have been misrepresented, what is the logic of standing order 190? All I am doing is reading out the transcript, Senator Hill. I am not arguing or debating it. Senator Knowles went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I simply pointed out at that meeting that people cannot get away with going on—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have said enough. Your time has expired anyway.
—Hang on. I had five minutes—not you.
—You were given leave for five minutes.
—I have not had five minutes.
—It is up. Isn't it up?
—The five minutes has expired, but there was a significant interruption, which normally is—
—What was your ruling on that point of order?
—I have asked Senator Crichton-Browne to be precise about explaining the extent to which he has been misrepresented.
—Under that ruling he could read a book. You say that it is legitimate for him to read as much as he wishes to read and then say at the end of it—
—Only within the time frame of about five minutes.
—It is a short excerpt—I have culled it—and it is totally relevant to my complaint. Senator Knowles said:

SPEECH.PARA: I simply pointed out at that meeting that people—
she is referring to me—

cannot get away with going on and telling simply, telling things that simply are not true about others . . . The fact of the matter is that there are an awful lot of people around Western Australia who would know exactly what I was talking about in terms of the onslaught that he—
meaning Senator Crichton-Browne—
gave Eoin Cameron and me, um, at that meeting because he's been doing it for over 12 months . . . I just figure well, no longer, I didn't have to sit back and wear these lies—
lies I am alleged to have made and about which I am making this personal explanation—
about me having released the information about the restraining order.

That is what Senator Knowles said about me. The truth of the matter is to be found elsewhere. They were not lies, and I do not tell lies. I am impeccable about my facts and my details, and the 129 pages of document will tell you.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that it has been reported in the Financial Review that Mr Cameron said he obtained the restraining order and distributed it in whatever bright colours you like. Senator Knowles also said to a political journalist with respect to herself and in relation to me that she did in fact receive a copy of the restraining order and that she went on to reproduce it. She drew the subtle distinction between releasing it, obtaining it and reproducing it.

To Senator Hill, Madam Deputy President and my fellow senators, I simply say this: there was also a dirt sheet in Mr Cameron's machine, according to Mr Cameron and according to the state police, which Mr Cameron said he did not distribute but he got from Mr Viner and Mr Viner gave it to nobody else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, this is clearly going beyond a personal explanation.
—In 20 seconds I will sit down. The facts of the matter are that the document—
—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The point of order is that he is now speaking beyond the relevant standing order.
—It is clearly now beyond the standing order of making a personal explanation, which you undertook to stick to, Senator.

—I shall not disagree with your ruling, much as in my heart I know you are wrong. I will have to look at that at another time. I conclude by saying that the facts of the matter are that, in respect of traducing my reputation and my good standing in the community, two federal members of parliament did in fact acquire the document and distribute it, to my detriment and that of my family, and faxed it, to their detriment and my detriment, to Senator Collins and to the President of the Senate from the machine of Mr Eoin Cameron MP, the member for Stirling in the state of Western Australia.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Freedom of Choice
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the Citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That we:
(1) Affirm the importance of quality education for all the children of this Commonwealth of Australia irrespective of their religion, nationality or sex;
(2) Support the rights of parents to have freedom of choice of the school for their child;
(3) Support the right of all non-government schools to maintain their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos;
(4) Support the freedom of choice in staffing of all Churches and religious organisations.
(5) Support freedom of religion and the right of all Churches and religious organisations to maintain their distinctive foundational ethos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate oppose any attempts to introduce legislation that would jeopardise these freedoms and rights and which would force Schools, Churches and religious institutions to compromise their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray:

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bourne (from 357 citizens), Senator Brownhill (from 394 citizens) and Senator Forshaw (from 226 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Coulter (from 1,767 citizens) and Senator Spindler (from 39 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned expresses the widespread community outrage throughout Australia at the decision of the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French Parliament in the strongest terms Australia's opposition to this decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Census
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the current practice of destroying the Census is denying future generations an invaluable and irreplaceable resource of data on medical, historical, social, scientific, and demographic factors.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

Request the Government to review its current policy of destroying the Census; and support a proposal to retain the census forms for release for specific research purposes in either 70 or 100 years time.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self-determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: This Petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:
There is a growing demand for urgent Federal Government intervention to protect all Australia's remaining forests.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to call on the Federal Government to:
immediately implement the moratorium clause in the National Forest Policy Statement;

permanently protect all remaining high conservation value forests throughout Australia, adequate to secure the biodiversity and natural and cultural heritage, by bringing them under the guardianship of indigenous peoples;

TAB.TAB: utilise our extensive plantation timber for industry needs;

create economic incentives for farm forestry employment on existing cleared lands in the propagation, establishment and management of sustainable permaculture style, mixed-species timber plantations, inter-grown with a variety of annual crops for fibre and food production;
encourage investment in the growing and marketing of indigenous, plantation based tree products such as wattle seed, eucalyptus and tea tree oils, and other medicinal and nutritional resources;
develop educational eco-tourism as a sensitively managed industry in appropriate forest areas, and with full respect for Aboriginal heritage and sacred sites;

PARA.TAB: and further support the above initiatives by the progressive transfer of military personnel and resources to assist rural communities to implement sustainable plantation forestry practices.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: Australia's old growth forest and wilderness areas are being diminished as a result of continued logging. The Federal Government has granted new woodchip export licences despite its agreement for a moratorium on logging in high conservation areas.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate should:
apply conditions retrospectively to woodchip licences in order to meet Commonwealth obligations, and
exclude from licenses, woodchip derived from old growth forests and wilderness areas.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.We request that the current short consultation phase for the development of a national child care accreditation scheme be extended in order to enable widespread genuine consultation to take place.
2.We request that the final document resulting from the consultation process and a proper impact assessment into the cost implications be undertaken and made available for public comment.
3.We object to a National Accreditation Scheme being linked to fee relief.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Coastline
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned, wish to lodge our protest, in the strongest possible terms, at the Federal Government's inaction to take legislative measures to protect our coast.

We the surfriders and TRACKS readers of Australia have watched our coastal treasures: the ecology, biodiversity and beauty of the Australian coast marred by urban development, poor planning and pollution, especially over the last 25 years.
The ALP has been in government for half that time and we've lost double our resources.
We (not so humbly) demand that you urge the Federal Government to act now to establish a national coastal agency with national powers to stop the destruction of our Australian coastline.
We also demand that the Federal Government recognise and include surfriders in the major decision making forums and call on you to contribute resources toward those who protect our surfing coast.
Finally, we demand that the environment be recognised in the Australian Constitution.
We are tired of waiting! You must act now. Please write to me and inform me of what you are going to do to save our surf.

That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill, which is a near duplicate of the private member's bill that was introduced into the House of Representatives by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. We are debating this bill simply because the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, introduced his bill into the House of Representatives. He introduced it because of the total mistrust of the people of Sydney in regard to the actions by this government that has resulted in the problems at Sydney airport.

PARA.TAB: The bill highlights the total disaster that is the government's Sydney airport policy. It did it all on its own. The government has ruined the lives of thousands of Sydney residents by closing the east-west runway and concentrating the noise generated by the airport north and south of Kingsford Smith airport. Since that time the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, has come up with a whole range of half thought through policy initiatives in an attempt to reduce the noise generated by the airport. I might say most of them were peripheral and some of them have been plain stupid.

One in particular was a proposal by the minister for the landing aircraft to have a six degree flight path coming in to land. This was totally rejected not only by the pilots, who refused to accept it on safety grounds, but also by his own Airservices Australia. The minister is so lacking in imagination that he has now resorted to plagiarising a bill drafted by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. Mr Brereton described Mr Howard's bill as a `stunt'—a brave word from a minister who was not prepared even to consider entrenching the curfew in legislation until he was trumped by the Liberal-National coalition.

The Sydney Airport Curfew Bill would ensure that the curfew could not be altered without adequate consultation and debate. It would also implement a number of minor alterations to the curfew. The Howard bill proposed to make a number of changes to the curfew system. The bill would have forced the Minister for Transport to consult widely before altering the curfew. The reason for this, as I mentioned earlier, is that the thousands and thousands of people of Sydney who have been badly affected do not trust this government any more. In addition, it would have required the minister to table in the parliament any exceptional circumstances dispensations that he or she made.

The government referred the bill to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for an advisory report. The whole aim of this, of course, was to take away the thrust of the fact that the bill had been initiated by Mr John Howard. The committee endorsed the bill but proposed a range of representations, some of which appear in this bill introduced by the government.

The bill is necessary because of the hundreds of thousands of Sydney residents who do not trust this government. They do not trust the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and they do not trust Mr Brereton. They know, claim and believe that they have been lied to and deceived.

The residents of Sydney were rightly concerned that the minister could alter the curfew regulations without consultation. They feared that the government might decide to alter the curfew arrangements. Who could blame them, when the best response the minister could give to the residents was that `they will have to learn to live with it'. That was his response to the complaints by those people to the north of Kingsford Smith airport. Who could blame them, given the government's sorry history of misleading and deceiving people about the effects that the construction of the third runway and the closure of the cross runway would have on their lives. It is no wonder the battlers of Australia are fed up with this uncaring and arrogant government which has clearly shown that it is out of touch with the vast majority of Australians.

The deceptions began in 1989 when the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and Mr Keating ducked, weaved and compromised to get the decision through cabinet. It is worth quoting from the autobiography of ex-Senator Graham Richardson, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Only a matter of days before the first Cabinet discussion, Hawke and Keating had given assurances that they were opposed to a third runway and we were entitled to believe them. When Gary Punch and I held a press conference to dispel rumours that the Government would consider building a third runway, we did so after seeking yet another assurance from Hawke. Keating was making the same noises, so we went into these Cabinet discussions feeling pretty confident. But a funny thing happened on the way to the forum, and to this day I have no idea what it was.

What happened is that somewhere along the way they all got mugged, and the leader of the group that did the mugging is the current Prime Minister. The Australian Financial Review, which was on the drip at the time, reported that Mr Keating came up with the idea of closing the east-west runway. His suggestion answered many of the political objections to the runway project, because it meant the noise impact on seats like Barton and St George would be reduced. Of course, it meant sacrificing the people who lived to the north of the airport, but they were dispensable.

PARA.TAB: The residents of Sydney were also misled about the runways that would be used once the parallel runway was opened and about the number of people who would be adversely affected by the noise. The environmental impact statement forecast that prevailing winds would mean that the aircraft could take off to the north only 12.8 per cent of the time. During the 11 months since the third runway was opened, it has become clear that the EIS forecast was a gross underestimate. In the first month of the runway's operations, 38.2 per cent of departures were to the north compared with the forecast figure of 12.8 per cent. The government initially blamed unusually strong summer winds, but it has become clear as the seasons have gone past that the 12.8 per cent figure was a gross underestimate. We now have more than double the number of planes taking off to the north than predicted.

The Labor government, because it is remote, arrogant and out of touch, has underestimated the effect of this disgraceful debacle. It claims over and over again that under the flawed system fewer people are seriously and moderately affected. It claims that this issue is about a handful of voters in Hunters Hill. That is typical of the sort of line being run.

The vast majority of people who are affected by aircraft noise is not a handful of people in Hunters Hill. It is the battlers who live in suburbs like Leichhardt, Marrickville, Drummoyne, Annandale, Haberfield and so on—the true believers; the Labor heartland. They are the vast majority of people who have been affected. Yet the minister says that the only reason the opposition is complaining is a handful of voters in Hunters Hill. Nothing could be further from the truth. A cursory look at today's crazy flight paths would soon dispel this notion. It is interesting to have a look at the flight paths. This page shows a typical flight path arrangement that now occurs at Sydney airport.

In recent days I have noticed that a new group has set itself up in parts of Sydney. It has looked at those sorts of figures and has said that they are disturbed that, with the new flight paths that have been introduced by the government, instead of aeroplanes flying over the least populated areas—whether it be to the south or the east—they are now going over some 60 kilometres of suburbs—60 kilometres of built-up Sydney are now being traversed by aircraft noise in Sydney.

Airservices Australia argues that about 75,000 people are affected by aircraft noise. That figure dramatically underestimates the number of people who are affected. It does not take into account many other areas that are affected by noise, such as Kuring-gai. There are serious flaws in the way that figure was calculated. In fact, no-one who was outside what they call the 20 ANEF contour zone was included. That is where the government has made a major mistake. Evidence put to our committee from the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital suggests that there may well be somewhere between 300,000 and 400,000 people seriously and moderately affected by this situation.

I will be moving an amendment in the committee stage of the bill to require the government to reopen the east-west runway. The reason for that is that reopening the east-west runway would give Airservices Australia the flexibility to strike an appropriate balance between the competing ends of noise, safety and capacity.

The government has continued along this path of deceiving the residents of Sydney by advancing three myths about the east-west runway. The first myth was that the runway was closed on safety grounds. Prior to November 1994 there were two active runways at Sydney: a main north-south runway and a crossing east-west runway. The latter was built in 1954 as the original jet runway. Both were active runways. At that stage, while there were certainly complaints, there was not a major noise problem.

After 4 November 1994, there were three runways, but only one and seven-eighths were active: the main north-south runway and the new runway, but take-offs to the north were not permitted. The east-west runway was closed except for exceptional circumstances. This prompted incredible outrage, blockades and demonstrations—led, I might say, by leading Labor figures such as the Mayor of Marrickville, Mr Barry Cotter.

Senator Bob Collins, who represents Minister Brereton in this place, and I were on a Senate committee inquiry into the Sydney airport in 1988. He would know that the presentation made to that committee by the Federal Airports Corporation proposed a medium spaced parallel runway, but it was never envisaged that we would end up with fewer than two runways.

The reason for the proposal in 1988 was that the MANS committee back in 1982 or 1983 had recommended what is called a narrow spaced runway or a closed spaced runway. The reason why the FAC recommended the medium spaced runway was that the narrow spaced runway produced what is called wake turbulence. In other words, a big jet coming in could cause wake turbulence for a lighter plane coming in behind it. This can cause all sorts of problems, including turning the lighter plane on its side. Not so long ago, even without the east-west runway, an incident happened in the air because of wake turbulence. But the reason for the proposal by the FAC back in 1988 was that with a medium spaced runway we could have better capacity and we would not have the wake turbulence problem.

The decision to close the east-west runway was a political decision. I do not think anyone would dispute that. In fact, that has been confirmed over and over again. The CAA, the FAC and the air traffic controllers have all confirmed that the decision to close the runway was a decision by government and that safety was not a significant issue. Last month, one of ex-Senator Graham Richardson's former advisers gave evidence. He confirmed that safety was not seriously considered to be an issue in any cabinet submission on the construction of the parallel runway.

I challenge the minister when he responds to produce a shred of evidence to show that safety was a significant consideration when that decision was made. Getting the public sector to come out with statements will not work, because they are doing exactly what they are supposed to do—they are supporting government policy. I do not criticise them for that; I just recognise the realism of it.

The airlines themselves have no option but to support government policy. It is not helped when the minister, who has a reputation for being one of the great kneecappers in politics in this country, is known to have said some weeks before the airlines came out with a joint press release, `I am going to get the airlines singing my tune.' So there is a lack of credibility in those sorts of things, and everyone is aware of it.

The second myth the government is putting about is that it would be unsafe—although it tends to have gone soft on this in recent times because the original policy decision did not refer to that. The Prime Minister demonstrated his lamentable ignorance of the issue by asserting, `If we seek to try to have traffic on the east-west runway across two parallel runways the result will be a dramatic collision.'

We have had cross-runways operating at Sydney airport for 40 years. Minister Collins came in here in about 1991, I believe, saying that it was perfectly safe. Suddenly, it is unsafe. The other thing is that the Prime Minister—perhaps he has been away too long from his home town of Sydney—did not realise that the cross-runway does not cross both the parallel runways, only the old north-south.

The airline pilots—domestic and international—do not believe there is a safety problem. In fact, the regional airlines claim that the current system where planes cross in the sky over north Sydney with 1,000 feet separation is less safe than crossing runways.

We even had the new chief executive-elect of Airservices Australia on a radio interview claiming that there was no particular problem with cross-runways, until of course he was nobbled. Then he had to change his tune. They got onto him pretty fast. It all happened within about 12 hours. I have had international pilots phone me in disgust, pointing out that because of what is happening at Sydney we are becoming the laughing stock of the world. To claim that the old configuration is dangerous is nothing short of ludicrous.

The third myth concerns the capacity implications of reopening the east-west runway. There is considerable argument about the peak capacity of Sydney airport. It depends on the configuration that is used and, of course, the weather. There are many permutations and combinations in using a runway system. The air traffic controllers at Sydney airport are now achieving rates of around 60 movements per hour, which is approximately the same rate they were able to achieve before the east-west runway was closed. The opening of the new control tower and the use of simultaneous approaches will increase the capacity to about 80 movements per hour.

The government has not been able to decide which line to take on the capacity implications of reopening the east-west runway. The Prime Minister has said that reopening the east-west runway would decrease the capacity of the airport by 35 per cent. One of his ministers said that it would increase the capacity of the airport. In fact, Minister Brereton said that if the sale of airports is delayed, there will be many more planes coming into Sydney. They cannot have it both ways. One of them has to be wrong.

The assertion that reopening the east-west runway would decrease the capacity of the airport by 35 per cent is clearly wrong. A 35 per cent decrease in the capacity of the airport would decrease the movement rate to 55 movements per hour, which would put it back below what it was when there were only two active runways. It is drawn from a hypothetical runway configuration that Airservices submitted simply to show the worst case scenario. The option is not the most efficient way that they put up of using three runways, as Airservices demonstrated later in answers to questions.

It has been argued that the use of all three runways will increase the capacity of the airport. So we have someone arguing that it will decrease and now they are going to argue that it will increase. Flight Transportation Associates from Massachusetts—they are world experts in the field—in their report on Sydney airport's capacity, estimated that the use of a three-runway configuration would increase the capacity to over 80 flights per hour.

The truth of the matter is that the minister cannot decide who he wants to frighten. He cannot decide whether he wants to frighten the users of the airport, by telling them that reopening the runway will decrease the capacity, or the people who live around the airport, by telling them that reopening the runway will increase the capacity of the airport. The minister will say whatever it takes.

The coalition's objective is simple. It is to give Airservices Australia the flexibility to use all three runways to achieve an appropriate balance between three competing objectives—the equitable distribution of noise, safety and the capacity of the airport.

The Sydney Airport Curfew Bill is a welcome piece of legislation. The government has had 12 1/2 years to do something about this matter. It was not an issue until the problems created by this government surfaced in Sydney. Then it became an issue because the people in those areas, particularly in the north and south of the airport at Kurnell, have got to the stage where they do not trust this government on anything it does in relation to Sydney. So the only way to do something was to put this regulation into legislation.

The only reason the government took any action at all was because the opposition leader, Mr Howard, introduced a private member's bill on the issue. He did that because the government is out of touch with the people, it is out of touch with the ideas of the people and it is out of touch with the aspirations of the people who have been so badly affected by the decision. It will soon be out of office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his concluding remarks Senator Parer claimed that the Sydney airport curfew only became an issue in recent times. I recall the obituary speeches for the late Fred Daly who, I remind the Senate, was the first member for the electorate of Grayndler. In his very early speeches in the early 1950s he drew the attention of the parliament to the problems of residents living in his and surrounding electorates who were affected by aircraft noise. For years and years Mr Daly and other members of the Labor Party—then in opposition—pleaded with the then conservative governments to do something about solving the problems with Sydney airport, but nothing was done.

PARA.TAB: What do we get today? We get opportunism, cynicism, and a total disregard of history from the opposition on this issue. We get desperate attempts by the opposition, through the medium of the private member's bill of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), to try and scrounge some credibility on this issue.

The Sydney Airport Curfew Bill 1995 is a watershed in the management of aircraft noise over Sydney. For the first time the curfew restrictions devised to improve conditions for Sydney residents will be enshrined in law. For the first time the restrictions will be progressively tightened, leading to further improvements over time. These changes will be institutionalised in the overall Sydney airport management system.

This government has done more to resolve the problems of Sydney airport, its congestion, and its noise, than the opposition has ever thought of doing. There is no doubt that the new third runway constructed at Sydney airport has brought problems with noise. The government does not run away from that. Senator Parer knows full well that during the deliberations of the inquiry of which he and I are members, I and other members of the government have not been afraid to address that issue head on.

Let no-one think that the opposition has clean hands on the issue of the devastating effect that aircraft noise can have on Sydney residents living under the flight path. Almost three years ago the opposition was in complete disarray over the issue of a curfew at Sydney airport. The member for Fadden (Mr Jull), the then shadow spokesperson on these matters, proposed that the curfew be lifted completely and that we have 24-hour operations at Sydney airport. The Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) agreed. This is all recorded and is well known to members of the opposition.

The then member for Lowe, now Senator Woods, disagreed. He threw his arms up in horror because he knew the impact that 24-hour operation of Sydney airport would have upon the electors of Lowe. The electors, of course, were sensible enough to turf him out of office at the last election. Throughout this period the opposition's position has been opportunistic and cynical in the extreme.

This government has a clear and comprehensive program for dealing with the airport problem in Sydney. Firstly, the new runway is relieving the problem of congestion. With the introduction of the new radar system that congestion will be even further alleviated. The parallel runway system now in operation at Mascot Airport is safer than the two old intersecting runways, namely the north-south and east-west runways. There is no doubt that it is a safer operation. All the experts agreed and testified to that effect.

The government is also fast-tracking construction of the Sydney West airport at Badgerys Creek. This government is tackling an issue that the coalition had neither the courage nor the vision to take up when it was in government for over 30 of 33 years from 1949 to 1983. It took a Labor government to finally grasp the nettle, bite the bullet, and commence construction of Sydney's second airport. It was long talked about, but nothing was ever done by the present opposition when it was in government.

The government has also devised a range of measures to ameliorate the problem of noise. The latest element in that very comprehensive program is this current bill, which will give teeth and strength to the regulatory curfew that has applied at Sydney now for some time. This stands in stark contrast to the grandstanding by the Leader of the Opposition, who sought in his own bill merely to take a system that had operated by regulation at Sydney airport and put it into an act. What a master stroke of cynicism that was.

There were no advances or no improvements, it was just a stunt. He thinks he can just take the existing law applied through regulation, change its name, make it an act, claim credit and hopefully convince the suffering electors in Bennelong that he has some credibility on this issue. There was nothing new, nothing stronger, nothing better, nothing original or brave and nothing genuine in the Leader of the Opposition's proposal.

This government has been the innovator in Australian policy in respect of the airport needs of Sydney and other cities. It has been prepared to tackle this difficult issue, as indeed it has tackled many other difficult issues. It has tackled issues that the opposition was too frightened to take on when it was in government.

With this Sydney Airport Curfew Bill, this government has taken an entirely different approach to that adopted by the Leader of the Opposition. Not only does this bill enshrine the curfew in legislation but also it makes it far stronger. The government has already introduced measures to further restrict movements by larger freight aircraft, to phase out movements by noisier aircraft and to tighten dispensations from the curfew. For instance, in the first six months of 1994 there were an average of around 25 dispensations a month. In 1995, there are now only three dispensations a month. With this bill, the government will be increasing the penalties for breaking the curfew to $25,000 for an individual and $100,000 for a corporation.

The bill also requires airlines to justify their use of the curfew. As it finds that the use is not being justified, it will wind back the airline's entitlements. The bill takes a starting point for jet movements in the first and last hours of the curfew not at the current entitlements that exist under the regulations but rather at the current rate of usage. Instead of the permitted 42 movements in these hours per week with no more than eight on any one day, the bill will restrict those movements to 35 per week with a maximum of seven per day.

The bill also includes measures that will protect the residents of Sydney against freight operators who might seek to circumvent the curfew by using much bigger, noisier, prop driven aircraft than we have had in the past. The bill will therefore ensure that aircraft over a certain weight, over 34 tonnes, will not be allowed during curfew hours. This means, for example, that we will not have clever freight operators running Hercules aircraft in and out of Sydney throughout the night, which I understand has actually been floated as one way of getting around the curfew and producing a situation of noisier aircraft operating into and out of Mascot. That will be outlawed.

The bill also includes a wide range of other measures which add up to genuine improvements in protection from aircraft noise for the people of Sydney. The justification that airlines will be required to give when they seek dispensations from the curfew will be subject to more rigorous examination by the department. There will be wider community input into the guidelines for assessing applications for dispensations from the curfew. On weekends, shoulder curfew operations—that is, between 5 a.m. and 6 a.m. and 11 p.m. and midnight—must be over Botany Bay, weather and traffic density permitting. That will take them away from the populous areas of the current flight paths. Also, all departures after 10.45 p.m. must be over Botany Bay.

All of those measures contained in this bill are a significant improvement on the current long-standing operations of the curfew, which this government has progressively tightened and which will now be enshrined in law. They stand in stark contrast to the proposal originally floated by Mr Howard, the Leader of the Opposition, which was nothing more than a political stunt. If Senator Parer wants to talk about political stunts, that goes down as the daddy of them all.

I would like to turn to the amendment that has been proposed by the opposition. This amendment effectively seeks to direct the minister to reopen the east-west runway, notwithstanding the best available advice from the experts and the authorities charged with the responsibility on these issues. This has to be one of the most deceitful propositions brought forward by the opposition. It is a proposition based on political expediency, not on sound policy or good advice. As I said, the amendment seeks to direct the minister to reopen the east-west runway without any regard to safety implications, without any prior consideration of advice from the recognised safety agencies and authorities, such as Air Services Australia, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation and the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. It is a political stunt designed simply to appease the residents of Bennelong, Mr Howard's own electorate, to get him off the hook for supporting the third runway so vociferously in the first place.

Senator Parer gave us a bit of history today. If you look at that history and the constant support given by the opposition, firstly, to the expansion of Mascot airport and the third runway construction, you see how breathtaking the hypocrisy is on their part. This is an opposition that, along with their state government colleagues, at the time led by Mr Greiner, enthusiastically supported the construction of the third runway. There was very little, if any, mention of environmental considerations or possible noise impacts upon the residents of Sydney. It was a case of `get it built; get it built as quickly as you can'.

They said that we needed to build this third runway at Sydney airport because it would increase capacity and reduce congestion. They also said at the time, and it is on record, that it would drastically reduce the number of residents affected by aircraft noise and that it would be safer.

You do not have to take just my word for it. Let us first of all take the words of Senator Parer himself. He mentioned that he was on a Senate committee back in 1988. In a dissenting report, Senator Warwick Parer, Senator Chapman and Senator Boswell said a number of things in support of the construction of the third runway. Firstly, at 1.45 they said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no-one who disagrees that runway congestion at Sydney airport is the major and immediate problem.

The major problem is congestion! You do not find too much mention in here by the opposition about problems of aircraft noise. It was the Labor members of parliament that raised those issues in their majority report and called for the construction of a second airport. Further on in the minority report Senator Parer states:
The most important justification for a parallel runway is the dramatic improvement it would provide in bad weather. It would also halve the number of noise affected residents.
Those are your own words, Senator Parer; that is your prediction. You go on to say:

From the evidence gathered from representatives of the aviation industry and views expressed by key personnel, we believe a third runway must be commenced without delay and that time be the essence of the contract.
In other words, get it built as quickly as possible. They said:
The option which solves the problem in the shortest time span and with least inconvenience to travellers now and in the future is the one which quite clearly must be taken, that is, build the runway.

The inconvenience to travellers was uppermost in the opposition's mind then, not the inconvenience to Sydney residents who may be affected by aircraft noise. It was not just Senator Parer who was saying that, it was none other than John Howard, the now Leader of the Opposition. He was making those comments as well. What did John Howard say? On 8 February 1989 he said:

In the interests of safety, airport facilities should be upgraded immediately including the construction of the third runway. The current congestion at the airport is causing increased noise pollution and becoming a serious threat both to travellers and to local residents. The Government is playing carelessly with a situation that could too easily result in a major tragedy. The risk must be averted.
In December 1988 John Sharp said:

The Government's indecision on the runway has put at risk the health of our flourishing tourist industry, the thousands of jobs it can provide, and the lives of both domestic and overseas travellers. The Government is ignoring the safety hazard the present chaotic conditions are presenting.
On 13 August 1991, a day after a near disaster at Sydney airport, Tim Fischer said:
Any further delay in deciding on the third runway for Mascot could mean loss of life as well as economic insanity.

John Howard and other members of the opposition knew that when the final decision was made to construct the third runway—quite clearly a decision not popular with many members of the Labor government at the time but nevertheless made—that decision also involved the downgrading of the east-west runway. It was clear. It was in black and white in the statements made by the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the then Minister for Transport, Ralph Willis. Opposition members knew that was to be the case. They knew that once the third runway was in operation the system of intersecting runways, with or without Simops, would effectively be abandoned in favour of the safer and quicker operation of parallel runways. John Howard acknowledged that in evidence to the Senate committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney. He did that on 25 July.

PARA.TAB: When members of the opposition come in here and say that safety was not an issue they are speaking with forked tongues because they are on record as recognising the safety problems associated with the congestion at Sydney airport and the use of the two intersecting runways. Whilst one can argue about semantics—whether it is safe or unsafe—there is no doubt that the current operation in Sydney, with parallel runways, is safer than it was before.

If you drive from Sydney to Canberra, as I do quite regularly, when you are driving on the divided road it is much safer than when you are driving on the undivided road. The risk of collisions at intersections or head-on collisions is reduced. It is the same principle. By removing that intersecting runway operation you make it safer.

What are members of the opposition trying to do? They are trying to pander, in a rather hypocritical and cynical way, to residents of Sydney who are clearly affected by this problem, who are reaching out for solutions and who, in some cases, are suggesting the reopening of the east-west runway. The opposition's amendment ignores the recognised safety advice from the agencies. Senator Parer has heard their evidence. The opposition is ignoring all of that and is saying, `Let's reopen the east-west runway. Let's direct the minister to do it,' even in situations where it is contrary to independent expert advice. That is why the amendment should be rejected.
Finally, this amendment seeks to nobble the committee which Senator Parer chairs and on which I, Senator Bourne and others have served, and basically makes it a waste of time. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It will probably come as no surprise to anyone that the Australian Democrats are supporting the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill 1995. It particularly will not come as a surprise to those people who read my airport curfew bill in March this year when I introduced it, which is remarkably similar to this one. It probably will not come as a surprise to anyone who heard my reaction to Mr Howard's bill, which he introduced after mine and before this one, which was along extremely similar lines. It should not come as a surprise to anyone that all of us will probably be supporting the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill 1995.

PARA.TAB: As has already been noted in the debate today, the purpose of this bill is to provide that the curfew on air operations at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport be incorporated into legislation and to prevent any amendments to the legislation unless prior consultation has been entered into.
