The Democrats welcome these proposed changes, although it is somewhat of a disappointment that the government has taken so long in getting around to introducing these measures at all. These changes are, in fact, a long time overdue. It has been clear for some time now that the new third runway at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport has resulted in quite intolerable levels of noise and general distress to thousands of residents of Sydney whose homes are in noise affected suburbs. The fact that the government has taken this long to respond with this type of legislation does not reflect well on its ability to respond to community concerns. It is no wonder that the suggestion has been made that the motivation behind this legislation has much more to do with the forthcoming federal election and the government's belief that it could well suffer an electoral backlash unless legislation such as this is passed.

This bill represents a reluctant response on the part of the government finally conceding the necessity for curfew legislation, following on from the massive public outcry over aircraft noise from Sydney's Kingsford Smith. The reality is that, despite the passage of this bill, the public outcry will continue to grow in Sydney because the root causes of the distress and the disruption to ordinary living—which the new north-south runway and, in particular, the concentrated air paths have caused—have not gone away and they have not been dealt with adequately. The people living under the approaches know this because they live with intolerable levels of aircraft noise every day of their lives.

Understandably, these people feel betrayed. People are not stupid and, regrettably, we have to share some of their cynicism. This is against a background where for years now successive Labor and coalition governments at both federal and state level in New South Wales have sought to appease the airline industry at Sydney's Kingsford Smith. In the opposition's case, as we have already heard from Senator Forshaw, this at one time even included consideration of abolishing this curfew altogether. I congratulate them on their present position on this matter. I assume it comes from listening to the hundreds of witnesses and reading the thousands of submissions to the aircraft noise committee, which I also serve on.

The Democrats have a record of consistently drawing attention to the long-term economic, social and environmental effects of continuing to expand Kingsford Smith without due attention being given to the proper environmental impact and the cost-benefit analyses that are essential to go with such processes. The sorry mess that now surrounds air operations at Sydney airport results when proper processes are disregarded or corners are cut in an attempt to achieve some unrealistic electoral commitment.

In previous debates on the airport issue that have taken place in here, Labor and the coalition both blocked our amendments which were designed to have the third runway comply with existing environmental standards. The government's attempts, supported by the coalition, to exempt the third runway from EIS requirements represent a real low point in this whole affair. The people of Sydney know about it. No doubt a great many of them will express their dissatisfaction with both major parties at the next federal election because of that.

Even now the government has still not provided an adequate justification of the reasons it considered necessary to exempt the FAC, the Federal Airports Corporation, from complying with the New South Wales Environmental Protection Act. Every private citizen and corporation in New South Wales is bound by the Environmental Protection Act, but when it comes to building new runways at Sydney such decisions are above the law. If the proper processes had taken place, then some of the current problems at Sydney airport could well have been prevented. Instead, we witnessed a complete disregard for community concerns in the building of the third runway—concerns which were largely ignored by a government which then proceeded to gloat about the fact that the third runway had been finished ahead of schedule.

It is now glaringly obvious that the EIS was inadequate in a number of key areas. The Senate should be aware of the tragic stories which are now unfolding in the worst noise affected suburbs of Sydney. What about Sydenham, where people are being forced to leave their homes and the neighbourhoods that they have lived in for many years?

In many ways what has happened to Sydney is an environmental disaster of major proportions, and it is still going on. As a member of the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney, I have heard first hand—as have Senator Parer, Senator Forshaw and several other senators sitting here in the chamber today—from witnesses appearing before the committee of the absolute destruction and the havoc that has been wreaked on their lives as a result of current air operations. It is not an understatement to suggest that in some cases people believe that their lives have been destroyed.

Already, millions of dollars have been spent on attempting to ameliorate the effects of aircraft noise. The costs of the amelioration package now in place are blowing out from initial estimates, especially when you include the cost of purchasing those homes listed for demolition and the costs of soundproofing. In the case of the latter, the costs can only increase over time as more and more people inevitably, with an increase in air traffic, become eligible for soundproofing.

All those affected residents in Sydney who have been following the KSA aircraft noise debate and the background to this bill have every reason, given the history of this issue, to doubt whether the situation around the airport will ever improve substantially. In fact, if there is one issue which has caused the electorate to become totally cynical about major party politics, this is certainly it.

This bill, which is only belated recognition by the government of the problem of air noise in Sydney, does not go far enough in guaranteeing the residents of Sydney an improvement in the overall noise situation. Admittedly, the bill does improve the situation in the so-called shoulder periods surrounding the curfew and also goes some way in tightening the current exemption provisions but, unfortunately, much more could have been achieved by the government with this bill.

One aspect of the current bill as it stands which the Democrats wholeheartedly welcome is for the first time in this policy area the provision of information to the public. This at least establishes a framework within which public consultation can take place, and I am sure that many people living in Sydney will want to avail themselves of this opportunity.

The way in which people seeking really basic information about the airport have been treated is totally unacceptable. In some cases, people appear to have been deliberately misled as to the effects on them of the air operations resulting from the new runway. The Democrats hope that the amendments contained in the bill to provide information and to allow a process of public consultation to take place represent a fresh start in aviation policy making.

The reality is however that despite this bill, Sydney airport will continue to be a huge problem for any future government to deal with for many years to come. It is doubtful that measures contained in this bill will make very much difference to residents currently affected by aircraft noise.

The reality is that the airport needs of a city the size of Sydney are not being met and nor will they be met even when Badgerys Creek or Sydney West airport becomes operational. The evidence already presented to the Senate select committee gives rise to the worrying conclusion that the airport capacity problems in Sydney will continue to be around for a very long time.

In addition, the evidence suggests that there are many disadvantages in having dual airports in one city. The major airlines are already resisting any suggestion that they move their operations from Kingsford-Smith to the Sydney West site, and the people in the vicinity of Badgerys Creek are already concerned about what the airport will mean for them.

In many ways the mistakes which successive governments have made in relation to Kingsford Smith are being made now in relation to Badgerys Creek. There is no guarantee that the people of Sydney West will not suffer in the future in the same way which the people affected by operations at Kingsford Smith are currently suffering. Indeed, if the experience of people affected by the third runway is anything to go by, there is a danger that the needs of people in Sydney's west will be overlooked when planning and building of Sydney West takes shape.

Ultimately, the Democrats believe that the answer may lie in finding a site for a new airport completely outside any future Sydney residential areas if we are to break this vicious cycle of disastrous airport planning that appears likely to be repeated at Badgerys Creek. Surely it is about time that this federal government, indeed all federal and New South Wales governments, did some serious and comprehensive planning for the future airport needs of Sydney and then acted immediately on the results of that planning. This is the time for sensible and rational planning to take place.

The current situation has gone on far too long. People living under or even near the concentrated flight paths feel betrayed and abandoned. That sounds melodramatic but it is true. Those are the words they use and they are absolutely in ernest when they use them. The curfew was put in place when the noise was identified as a problem in 1963—a long time ago. The problem has only got worse since then. This bill will help but it is by no means a solution to the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wheelwright Sen T.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Being a senator from New South Wales, I am keenly interested in Sydney Airport. One has to say that, as a political issue, very few things have created so much heat and perhaps so little light in recent times.

PARA.TAB: But it is a problem that faces not only New South Wales and Sydney; it faces airports around the world. It does not matter whether you go to Hong Kong where a new airport is being planned there or to New York where some of the manifest problems that have occurred there can be seen. It is the same pattern. Airports are built at times when they are convenient to cities. But as time goes on, the population growth in those cities means that those airports are no longer conveniently located. They have become a constant source of stress and difficulty for residents living in their vicinity.

Kingsford Smith airport is no different. It is nobody's fault that this has happened. It is an inevitable part of what happens whenever there is population growth that outstrips the available infrastructure. But one thing is certainly true: this really only became an issue, as far as the senators opposite are concerned, once it started to impact upon their party's electoral fortunes and, in particular, those of their leader. Once the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) found that he had an electoral margin of 3.2 per cent in Bennelong and that planes were predominantly flying over that electorate, it suddenly became an issue for those opposite.

We have to emphasise that on this side of the chamber because all sorts of red herrings are being drawn in about capacity, the number of planes that can land, safety issues, and so on. But let us not forget that this is the major reason why this became prominent; this is the major reason why the Leader of the Opposition decided to make such an issue of it and, indeed, change his plan. However, what is remarkable about the coalition's response on this issue is how they went about it.

This is a problem which has been a vexatious one for air safety authorities around the world. But the opposition were able to come up with a completely new method of looking at it, a completely new ingredient in all of this debate. They pulled out the electoral map. When everybody else was looking at issues of safety and issues of efficiency, they pulled out the electoral map. And what did they find? They found on the electoral map that Bennelong was threatened and that Lowe was a seat in which they thought they had some fortune. So they decided that they had better put the planes somewhere else.

So what did they do? They had a look at either side of the airport and saw that, on the east-west runway, the planes only went over Labor electorates. How convenient! I do not know whether that would be very helpful in Hong Kong or New York, but it was certainly very helpful to members opposite.

The opposition simply referred to the electoral map. But, of course, in doing so, they brought into question the whole issue of safety, the whole issue of efficiency and the role of proper government policy. They wanted to reopen the east-west runway—that was the answer—to spread the planes more evenly over Labor electorates and try to give themselves a hope that Senator Woods might be able to vindicate himself, having lost the seat of Lowe.

Despite that cynicism, the experts in this regard were virtually unanimous in condemning the east-west runway as a means of solving this particular problem. I will go through the list—and it has been gone through before, but I am happy to go through it again—and look at all those who were concerned. Both airlines, Qantas and Ansett, on 18 September endorsed the operational efficiency of parallel runways. In a joint statement they said that the safety considerations really prohibited any prospect of the east-west runway being reopened on a full-time basis.

It should be remembered that the government has never proposed to entirely close the east-west runway; it is only a matter of using it in simultaneous operations. There are times when the east-west runway has to be used because of the way in which the prevailing winds are blowing and what is the best result for a safety outcome. Nevertheless, here you have both airlines coming out in support of the parallel runway as the only way to go. You also have that of every other safety authority in Australia.
Airservices Australia, on 14 August, said exactly the same thing:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . international acceptance that parallel runway operations are inherently safer than any arrangement involving intersecting runways . . .
and on they went. If you have a look at what the Civil Aviation Safety Authority says, they make exactly the same point:
The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) is of the view that the restoration of SIMOPS—
that is, simultaneous operations on intersecting runways—
procedures at Sydney Airport, while parallel runways are available, would be less safe than the current parallel runway system in operation.

Even the Civil Air Operations Officers Association of Australia said exactly the same thing—and they said it directly to Senator Parer. When he asked them the question, `Are you suggesting that cross-runway operations are not safe or just less safe?' the reply was:
They are less safe. They rely more heavily upon the skill of the aerodrome controller in judging the point of conflict . . .
and on they went.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, any reasonable person can see as a matter of absolute logic that intersecting runways are inherently a safety risk in any airport operation. Faced with this sort of embarrassing support for the government and attacks on the basis of the opposition's policy, the Leader of the Opposition immediately clutches at whatever fig leaf of support he can possibly get. He has found this recently in the Flight Transport Associates report, which he has made so much of. He now declares that this means that his option of re-opening the east-west runway is safe. Let us look at what that report was based on. The report was prepared in 1989. It was a theoretical computer model exercise of capacity options at the airport. It did not represent a detailed analysis of operational safety issues. The report said:

SPEECH.PARA: The capacity of the airport under existing conditions and under a number of hypothetical—
I stress `hypothetical'—

future alternatives has to be estimated. It should be emphasised that the examination of a hypothetical alternative does not imply that this scenario has been deemed feasible with respect to engineering, economic, environmental, statutory and other aspects.

So even there you can find that there is no real support for the proposition that the other side are putting up. So where do we go with this? What is the real result if you are going to bring back the east-west runway to full operation? The first thing you will have to do is reduce capacity. It is impossible to land the same number of planes at the airport as is currently available under two parallel runways. If you are going to reduce capacity, who will be the first to suffer? It will be the residents of regional New South Wales. The only way you would possibly be able to do it would be to consolidate the flights going into Kingsford Smith on a hub and spoke basis.

PARA.TAB: Let me give some sort of indication of the ramifications which would be the inevitable consequence of opening up the east-west runway. If you, for instance, were in Dubbo and you wanted to fly direct to Sydney it would take you about 55 minutes and the current cost would be about $338. However, if you had to hub through Orange to consolidate the number of passengers going in, the flight time would go up to an hour and 55 minutes and the total cost would be $436. Another example would be Albury. If you fly direct from Albury to Sydney it currently takes about an hour and 10 minutes and costs $432. If you were hubbed through Canberra to consolidate the number of passengers into bigger planes you would be looking at two hours and 15 minutes and a cost of $528. I could give other examples.

So if people in regional Australia imagine that there is absolutely any benefit for them in the current proposal by the opposition, let them think seriously about the fact that it is going to take them longer to get to Sydney and is going to cost them more at the current prevailing rates of airfares in New South Wales.

I have a personal interest in all of this because I lived under the flight path. When I was growing up I went to school in Kingsgrove. I came home and did my homework to the sound of jets roaring over my head. Prior to my marriage I lived in Kogarah. I had exactly the same experience that millions of other people in Sydney have—certainly hundreds of thousands. You come home at the end of the day and you want to relax in front of the television. You do that to the sound of aircraft roaring overhead. It is entirely unpleasant. Those people have every good reason to complain, every good reason to find this a severe curtailment of the enjoyment of their lives, particularly their leisure hours. This government is entirely sympathetic to them.

The fundamental question that has to be asked every time you look at an alternative is: are you compromising fundamental aspects of safety? That is where re-opening the east-west runway founders—on the safety question. If I were doing my homework back in Kingsgrove in the 1960s there are quite a few things I would have hoped the then government would have done to alleviate the situation. These are the sorts of things which are incorporated in this bill.

Senator Forshaw mentioned these things in great detail earlier but I might mention them again in summary because they bear restating: a reduction in current quotas for international passenger movements during the curfew shoulders and the setting up of procedures that will allow a progressive reduction in the number of these movements; on weekends, new arrangements that will minimise aircraft overflying suburbs between 10 p.m. and 11 p.m. and between 6 a.m. and 7 a.m.; the bringing forward to 10.45 p.m. of the time at which the last flights at night can take off over these suburbs; amendments to stop operators getting around the curfew by using large, propeller-driven aircraft; and increases in the penalties for curfew breaches from the maximum of $25,000 to $100,000.

These are the sorts of changes that are going to make a difference to people. There is absolutely no question that these are the sorts of measures that will alleviate the sort of misery that is inevitable whenever you live near an airport. These are in addition to the other measures which the government has brought forward over the last year or so.

It also has to be remembered that it is Badgerys Creek which at the end of the day is the only real alternative to Kingsford Smith. That is the only thing that will really address the question of aircraft noise. Over $1 billion has been committed to a transport package for Sydney west airport. Only recently, in the last year or so, the government has already committed itself to $480 million to improve the road links to that airport. Fast tracking Badgerys Creek, which the government is entirely committed to, is the only answer.

So what do we have? Where does this proposal, this amendment, to reopen the east-west runway on a full-time basis stand? It stands in exactly the same way as just about everything the coalition has done this year and in the last term. Ever since John Howard became leader those opposite have taken the low road. This is the party which believes in opportunism, cynicism and calumny. Those opposite think that is clever. They think deceit is smart. They think that by going the low road, by doing the cynical thing, by doing the opportunistic thing, somehow that is going to improve their electoral fortunes.

There is a pattern to it. Eventually people will see there is a pattern to it. We have already heard from Senator Forshaw how Mr Howard has done a 180 degree turnaround on his view on the third runway. But it is exactly the same thinking that has left everybody in Australia in no doubt that the Easton royal commission was a cynical attempt to get Carmen Lawrence and nothing else. It is the same pattern of thinking which has meant that there is absolutely no policy detail coming from the opposition because it is absolutely afraid of anybody looking at its plans.

Let us not forget John Hewson has warned those opposite that people will not stand this any longer. John Hewson has told them that they have to have policy detail, that they have to be honest with people, that they cannot go for cynical alternatives. Nick Greiner has told them exactly the same thing. But I think it is salutary that on this issue, about which they are prepared to be cynical, about which they are prepared to trade-off whatever they can for a few votes in Bennelong and in the hope that they might take Lowe, the lie will finally be nailed.
The Australian Financial Review headline on September 28 this year finally says it: `Howard's crash-landing'. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Howard the policy man is clearly subservient to Howard the political animal in this third runway gambit . . . [He] has always been a pragmatist, and in the run-up to the election he will do whatever it takes to try to win office.

I say to the Senate: what would happen if we had an accident? How would people justify themselves? How would anybody say that we did the right thing, that we came up with the best policy? The answer on this side of the chamber is: we went as far as we possibly could to ensure the safety of the people who were using the airport. I do not believe senators opposite can say the same thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many important issues to be discussed in connection with the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill, including, in particular, the growing social health and environmental problems which arise from the noise issues in particular of Sydney airport. Then there are the economic and safety problems caused by the increasing level of air traffic and the pressures on airport capacity which lead to delays in arrivals and departures.

PARA.TAB: They are already, I might say, having a serious effect upon business and tourism. They must be rectified in the period leading up to the 2000 Olympics because that will place massive demands upon Sydney and its airport facilities. We also have to consider fundamental elements such as fairness and equity in sharing the burden of airport noise through the whole community, rather than just targeting a few suburbs as the unlucky few who must endure all of the noise.

Before I look at those issues and touch upon some of the somewhat obscure and irrelevant arguments raised by senators opposite, I want to target the real reason why we are debating this legislation today. It has nothing to do with operational needs or resources; it is a political exercise in cynicism. It is run by none other than our Artful Dodger Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who is an anonymous puppet master, pulling the strings behind the scenes, who seems to want to hide from public view when the moves fall apart, as they have done in terms of Sydney airport.

The Prime Minister has not yet been given the full extent of the blame that he, personally, should carry in the enormous problems that people living around Sydney airport face. It is pretty unlikely that he will now step forward to take a bow for his efforts. I think even he would realise he would risk being lynched for his efforts by the thousands of Sydneysiders who are suffering horrendous levels of aircraft noise because the PM wanted to do two things—to protect his special coterie of Labor mates in near airport electorates and to punish voters on the lower north shore for not electing Labor candidates.

The Prime Minister will, no doubt, dodge, weave and duck to try to avoid being held to account for what he did. But we have all seen him attempt these tricks so often that their effectiveness is obviously diminished. When he wants to seek credit he is very up-front, pushing his way to the TV cameras and leaving nobody in any doubt about his supposed role in whatever it is he thinks might be helpful to his image.

Where has P.J. Keating been on the airport noise issue? I guess a fair description would be `No appearance, your Worship'. Why is this so? Obviously he has a lot to hide, and that means a lot to lose. The then Treasurer, the man who frequently told the media how he had to push his Labor colleagues into adopting those policy decisions, stampeded his cabinet colleagues in 1989—and we have heard from Senator Forshaw exactly how that happened—into approving the third runway and reversing plans to direct most take-offs and landings over water. That plan had initially been intended to substantially reduce the problem of airport noise for many thousands of people in suburbs all around the airport and its approaches.

Why did the Prime Minister decide to head in this direction? The usual reason he does everything is to look after his special coterie of Labor mates, such as: the Minister for Transport; his sister, Deidre Grusovin; and—isn't it ironic in 1995?—Bob Carr. Each of these mates hold seats, state or federal, which had been affected by noise from the east-west runway and, what a surprise, suffered no adverse reaction from their constituents when that noise was suddenly removed to other areas north and south of the airport.

Mr Keating's calculated plans enabled him effectively to punish residents on the lower north shore for shunning ALP candidates—showing that impeccable judgment which we rely on from those people—by channelling all of the airport noise in their direction. He puts the political interest of a few of his personal allies ahead of tens of thousands of Sydneysiders who now suffer absolutely intolerable levels of noise hour by hour, day by day. The petty interests of those grateful mates obviously took precedence over the needs of the people of Sydney—and that is an indication of the misplaced priorities that we face from this government.

The Prime Minister cannot claim innocence in this matter. His personal involvement in the relevant cabinet decisions was put on the public record last year by Laurie Oakes, I believe, in his column in the Bulletin. It is indeed poetic that Laurie Brereton, the Minister for Transport—one of the major beneficiaries of the senseless and irresponsible policy reversal—is now saddled with the massive task of appeasing the many people hurt by that decision.

We have heard over and over again, and again here today, that one of the tactics for trying to justify the closure of the east-west runway is a constant refrain of `safety concerns'. He says it is impossible to operate safely the east-west runway in conjunction with the north-south parallel runways. This is drivel. Numbers of leading airports around the world happily operate intersecting runways without any problem whatsoever. There is, of course, a theoretical risk of collisions with crossovers. But it clearly can be very easily managed if effective operational measures are put in place and has been managed for something like 40 years.

It should be noted that the EIS for the third runway project never even considered the issue of cross-runway safety, which is a good guide to the government's concerns about safety at that time. I might point out that neither Qantas nor Ansett referred to the matter in their written submissions to the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney of which I am a member. Again, a reliable guide that the government's recent claims are based on political, and not genuine, safety concerns. Expert witness after expert witness before the Senate inquiry, including: the Australian International Pilots Association; the regional airlines; the air traffic controllers union, the Civil Air Operations Officers Association; and numerous pilots, who must know what they are talking about, say there are no grounds for concern if the east-west runway is reopened.

In the most recent issue of Australian Aviation—I think people would agree the most prestigious journal on aviation in Australia—an article written by Jim Thorn, one of the most highly regarded people in aviation today, addressed some of this issue under the heading `This madness must stop'. The madness is the closure of the east-west runway. Let me quote a few things that Jim Thorn, a highly regarded expert on this issue, says:

On a technical basis there is absolutely no reason why all three runways cannot be fully utilised to their original design limits at KSA. It is not unsafe to use intersecting runways as Brereton and Co keep telling us. Sure, parallel runways are slightly safer but the real world difference is so small that it is hardly worth mentioning. After all, KSA operated for more than half a century with crossing runways without any real dramas just as Tullamarine does today, tomorrow and probably forever. Does Laurie really think we are that stupid?

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: Even parallel runways have their problems. Since the third runway opened there have been several incidence of aircraft taking off with one vectoring the wrong way, and towards the aircraft abeam of it. This happened recently when an Air France 747 turned left instead of right, as directed by ATC, into the path of a domestic jet.

SPEECH.PARA: Parallel runways do have their own problems. These have been highlighted by Jim Thorn.

PARA.TAB: Mentioned before was Bill Pollard, the new head of Airservices Australia, who had made comments in favour of parallel runways. Let me quote what Jim Thorn said about that: Even Bill Pollard, the new head of Airservices Australia, the body that oversees our airspace, stated (before being quickly gagged) that cross runways were not unsafe, were common at airports throughout the world.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the very source that those on the other side of the chamber quoted from. Jim Thorn goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: So what do you do to end this absurd mess?
Simple. You reopen the east-west runway and turn KSA into what it should have been a year ago—a modern three runway airport.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, what we have now is not a three-runway airport but a two-runway airport; we have just changed the direction of the second runway. Indeed, as Senator Parer pointed out earlier, we do not even have two runways. We have one and probably seven-eighths of a runway. The last paragraph of this editorial from Jim Thorn says:

PARA.TAB: Until this logic prevails though hundreds of thousands of Sydney residents are held hostage to one man's agenda. And therein resides the real stupidity of the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Jim Thorn and I might disagree on exactly who that one man is. He might say that it is the Minister for Transport; I would say that it is the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: The regional airlines have also pointed out that crossing the sky with a separation of 1,000 feet is very dangerous in itself. So there is an element of risk. But there is an element of risk in flying, full stop. If you want to have a completely safe airline system, you would basically never take off. We are talking about minor differences in safety. It is clear by any criteria that cross runways can be used in a safe manner.

Sadly for the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport, the truth about the safe operation of intersecting runways was revealed by the transport minister of 1991, Senator Bob Collins, when he told the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are that simultaneous operations are in operation at many major airports around the world. There is absolutely no reason why simultaneous operations, if conducted efficiently and professionally, cannot be used—as they are in Adelaide as well as Sydney—with perfect safety.

We do not often trust Senator Collins's judgment on all things, but in this regard he is spot on. It would be remarkable if the situation had changed as dramatically since 1991 as the Minister for Transport would now have the people of Sydney believe.

PARA.TAB: The more plausible explanation is that the minister is trying to protect the unearned bonus he received from the PM—the removal of the aircraft noise problem from his electorate, indeed for his own residents. The member for Lowe (Mrs Easson) must be feeling a bit isolated and a bit vulnerable by these events because parts of her seat are now subject to extra noise directly because of the Prime Minister's arrangements in the Labor government. That is the price you pay—even in the ALP—if you are not one of the very special mates.

Maybe it was the pressure of needing to come up with something—anything—to toss to her constituents which led to the Member for Lowe's amazing $5 billion plan to demolish the Kurnell Oil Refinery, to demolish 1,000 local homes and to get rid of Kurnell as a community, to build a new east-west runway on that site—which is on the other side of Botany Bay from where the existing airport is—and to presumably have ferries and what have you to take people back to the main airport. She seemed to be serious. She included this lunacy in a formal submission to the select committee and later had the gall to tell the media that she had consulted numerous experts on the concept. We could not find them at the time, of course. But, happily, nothing has been heard of it since.

No matter what nonsense the member for Lowe proposed to the inquiry, the sad truth is that she voted with the government in blocking John Howard's proposed amendment to this bill. She is on the record as having supported more aircraft noise over the residents of Lowe. That amendment would have resulted in a reopening of the east-west runway and thereby spared the people of Lowe from much of the intolerable noise burden they currently endure. I am sure the constituents of Lowe will not be amused to learn how Mrs Easson, the member for Lowe, voted. I can assure her that we will not be keeping that betrayal a secret.

What the Labor government has said to the people of Lowe is that they are dispensable in terms of this issue. They expected something like 12 per cent of take-offs to go to the north over Lowe. It has now turned out to be 38 per cent—initially, supposedly, because of the high incidence of unusual wind patterns in the summer of 1994-95. Those wind patterns seem to be going on for a long time. The fact is that the environmental impact statement was flawed.

The important question we need to ask now is: why is this bill here now? Why is it that for 12 years the Labor government has ignored the needs of thousands of people and has suddenly become concerned about their welfare? Could it be that the legislation is a belated attempt by the government to claim the credit for John Howard's moves to enshrine in a private member's bill the need for a curfew? Who is pushing it forward? Chief mate, the Minister for Transport, running behind the play as usual.

This is a special case. Normally we would be forgiven for immediately rejecting any legislative proposal, but he has proposed something worth while, something which has basically been stolen from John Howard, in the interests of the people of Sydney. Of course, he had to tamper with the package a bit to make it look as though it were not stolen straight off John Howard's desk, but the overall concept is John Howard's—proper protection of the interests of people affected by breaches of the existing curfew. It is long overdue.

As we heard previously from Senator Forshaw, in the first six months of 1994 there were 25 breaches a month. That is how useless the curfew was. It is only exposure of the issue by John Howard which has raised an awareness which has led to a fall in that number of breaches. The fact is that more and more airlines were flouting the system. The government's response was to endorse more and more breaches of the rules. It has taken the opposition to force the government into taking this much belated action to enshrine the curfew into legislation, and we are happy to take the credit for that. Hopefully, this is just the first step towards fixing the overall airport noise problem.

Senator Wheelwright said that this was nobody's fault. That was his introductory line, if I remember rightly. Let me point out that he is absolutely wrong. This is the Labor Party's fault. We can argue about whether it is the Prime Minister or the Minister for Transport, but there is no doubt at all that this is somebody's fault. It is the Labor Party which has to take the blame for this.

Of course, Senator Wheelwright is condemned out of his own mouth. He said that we, the Liberal Party, had taken out the electoral map when we decided to reopen the east-west runway and that we would again spread the noise over Labor electorates. Excuse me, but doesn't that mean that, when you closed the east-west runway, you took the noise away from Labor electorates? Haven't you just confessed to the motivation behind closing the east-west runway—that this is a purely political issue; that there are no safety concerns here at all? There is no question at all about this.

Fortunately, Senator Forshaw was right. He said this is a watershed, the first time in law that this has happened. I agree with him; it is a watershed. I say, `Thank heavens that John Howard raised this issue and ensured this was going to be enshrined in law,' because, if he hadn't, we would still be having 25 planes a month breaking the curfew.

This is something which is supported, contrary to what Senator Wheelwright said, by regional airlines, by almost every regional council and by every regional body. Contrary to his rather obscure and vague theory about hub and spoke airlines and his trying to imply that to fly from Dubbo to Sydney would take longer and cost more—what that has to do with the curfew, I am not quite sure—the reopening of the east-west runway is something that the regional airlines and all the regional bodies will quite happily support us raising in the context of this curfew bill.

He mentioned the 1989 report from the Flight Transportation Associates. He forgot to mention that that body, one of the most prestigious in the world, have more recently as a result of a Senate inquiry come out and repeated their evidence. They have reported that it is safe, that it can be operated safely, that it can be used to a higher capacity and that it can, therefore, meet the requirements we set out: that there should be a safe operation of the airport, that the capacity of the operations of the airport should be maximised within the bounds of environmental impacts and that such environmental impacts as noise in particular should be evenly spread throughout the community.

That is something which the evidence from Flight Transportation Associates of Massachusetts confirmed. We have got all the experts in the world supporting the position that the east-west runway should be reopened. Contrary to what Senator Wheelwright said, the government has no plans whatsoever for reopening it and indeed, as I understand it, there are plans that they might even build on the end of the runway. As there are a few buildings on the end of the runway, it is a slightly difficult runway to use, unless you have a helicopter or a Harrier jet and I do not think we are going to start operating those out of Sydney airport.

I endorse the initial private member's bill introduced by the member for Bennelong. I am pleased to see that the government has taken up some of the issues here, having been forced into it, and I support entirely the amendment moved by Senator Parer which will immediately ensure the reopening of the east-west runway and relieve the noise pressure of many of the residents, particularly north of Sydney airport and over the Kurnell peninsula, and spread it fairly around the other people of Sydney. This is what we are looking at—a fair, safe and efficient use of the airport. This is the heart of the coalition approach to the matter and will continue to be so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal Sen B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill. It is important, when considering the bill, to look at the recent history of the matter and in particular the coalition's position in relation to the operation of the airport. The airport operated adequately and met demands without a large amount of conflict with the surrounding area up until the 1960s. In the 1970s, the concept of the construction of a third runway was hatched. It was given considerable momentum by the Major Airport Needs of Sydney Committee—otherwise known as the MANS committee—which resulted in a joint study which was conducted by the Commonwealth and New South Wales governments in 1977. This process went a bit astray and as a result a final report was never tabled, but a dissenting Commonwealth report was produced and tabled by members of the Fraser government in 1979. The report said:

SPEECH.PARA: The construction of a close-space parallel runway and associated facilities east of the existing north-south runway is required.

In October 1982, the coalition Minister for Aviation, Wal Fife, announced the construction of the new runway. Unfortunately for the minister, in the following March he and all his fellow ministers were removed from their portfolios, having lost the election.

PARA.TAB: In 1988, a joint Commonwealth-New South Wales task force on the airport needs of the Sydney basin found that a need existed for a third runway at Sydney airport and also a second airport at Badgerys Creek. The task force found that both these were required to accommodate Sydney's growing air traffic. In 1988, the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure also considered the future construction of the third runway. Senator Warwick Parer, the current chair of the airport noise inquiry, said that the construction of a third runway should have started immediately. He issued a minority report to support his view and said:

SPEECH.PARA: The only decision which can be made is for an immediate start on a parallel runway.

In the following year, 1989, the government decided to construct a third runway together with the commencement of the second airport at Badgerys Creek. This decision received considerable support from the then Premier, Nick Greiner, who has since been swept from his position. He said:
The New South Wales government believes there should be a third runway and there should be an additional airport at Badgerys Creek.

In 1991, Mr Greiner went on to say, in reference to the third runway, that it was the single most important project in Australia. The now Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, in 1989, when commenting on the third runway, said:
I think the case for it on general interest grounds is overwhelming. Our policy is to build it. That's been our policy for the past 6 1/2 years.

On 4 November 1994, the runway was completed six months ahead of schedule and $30 million under budget. For a considerable number of years the curfew has existed at Sydney airport preventing take-offs and landings between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. each night. This is aimed at reducing the noise effects on the surrounding residents during the time that they are generally resting. It was a result of the awareness and sensitivity of the government to the adverse effect that airport noise can have on the surrounding community and an attempt to limit the effect.

PARA.TAB: By the late 1980s, Kingsford-Smith was having difficulty meeting the demands placed on it, particularly as it was still limited by the use of intercepting runways. In 1988, shoulder periods were introduced to the curfew. The shoulder periods allowed for a limited amount of international aircraft movements between the hours of 11 p.m. and midnight and 5 a.m. and 6 a.m.

It was to meet the overwhelming demand on the use of the airport by both international flights and domestic and country movements. About 17 million passengers were passing through Kingsford-Smith airport each year and the airport just could not cope. In fact, the log jams were getting so bad that, according to the industry at the time, delays and flight cancellations were costing an estimated $40 million. The shoulder periods were trying to cope with this problem by slightly increasing the capacity of the airport. It is these shoulder periods that this bill largely deals with.

This bill sets in place safeguards necessary to ensure that the curfew periods and the shoulder periods of an hour on each side are not abused by the airlines which have flights coming in at the time. The purpose of the bill is to control, as far as possible, aircraft operations during that period. It does so in several ways. International take-offs and landings—generally the loudest—between 5.00 a.m. and 6.00 a.m. have been reduced from the 42 per week presently operating to 35. International take-offs and landings between 11.00 p.m. and midnight will be held at their present level of 14 per week and no increase will be allowed.

In keeping with the Morris committee's proposed phase-out of curfew flights, the bill allows the following lower operations to be introduced. Operations of British Aerospace flight services will be set at 65 per week until the week ending 5 May 1996. After this date, operations increase to 74 per week but will be offset by a decrease in the operations of DC9 aircraft. Certain propeller driven aircraft and jet aircraft under 34,000 kilograms will be permitted to operate during curfew hours provided that they meet strict international noise standards. In fact, the level of noise that they will be producing will be equivalent to that of a family car.

Reverse thrust restrictions will be placed on the operators of aircraft, requiring them not to plan to land at Sydney airport during the curfew period if greater than idle thrust will be required. Between 10.45 p.m. and 11.00 p.m. aircraft taking off from Sydney airport must operate over Botany Bay and thus will not be flying over any homes.

These measures will go a long way towards reducing noise during the curfew operations at Sydney airport, even in the shoulder period. The bill also provides a platform wherein operations can be reduced in the future. Such freight service movements as are allowed can be phased out under this legislation. The bill further provides for accountability for operators during the curfew period to both the parliament and the public at large.

I would like to deal with the amendments proposed by Senator Parer on behalf of the coalition and Senator Bourne on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The amendment proposed by the opposition calls on the minister to increase the use of the east-west runway. I want to emphasise a couple of things in relation to that. The east-west runway is not completely closed, as I am sure most of the people in the chamber appreciate. I realise that many members of the general public would not appreciate this fact. The runway is still used when conditions make it unsafe to use the parallel runways.
I would like to refer to some comments made by Mr Howard when he moved a like amendment in the other place. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is all about the fair sharing of a burden. One of the great Australian traditions is that Australians will always support the fair sharing of a burden.

I wonder if the Leader of the Opposition believes that this applies to the devastating and extraordinary burden that this amendment will place on the rural people of Australia. Airservices Australia is responsible for the management of air movements and has indicated that the normal use of the east-west runway for full jet operations will reduce airport capacity by 35 per cent. This would require a reduction in aircraft operations at Sydney airport. It will have much the same effect as the amendment proposed by Senator Bourne.

PARA.TAB: What will be the effect of this serious decrease in the capacity of the airport? There will be a disproportionate effect on country services. The smaller airlines, the smaller planes and the less profitable routes will be squeezed out.

As a consequence, a number of country commuter services will be forced to be reduced. Larger planes will be leaving fewer centres less often and will cost more and take longer. If I were a member of the National Party I would be very concerned about this matter. Services from small centres that now fly conveniently and more cheaply directly to Sydney will have to fly to larger regional centres, change planes and then fly on to Sydney, or possibly even on to some bigger centre and then again change planes and go on to Sydney.

The process which I said had been misunderstood in the earlier Senate debate is known as hubbing. This hubbing will provide rural and regional commuters with an inadequate and expensive service. For example, at the moment to travel directly from Port Macquarie to Sydney takes 55 minutes and costs $348; hubbing through Newcastle on, say, Eastern Airlines for the same trip would take one hour and 50 minutes and would cost $470. At the moment to travel directly from Albury to Sydney takes 70 minutes and costs $432; hubbing through Canberra on Kendall Airlines would take two hours and 15 minutes and would cost $528. The opposition's complete reopening of the east-west runway would place a tremendous burden on the country people of New South Wales.

The other major problem with the increased usage of the east-west runway, which has been referred to by previous speakers in the government, is the safety risk it poses to air passengers and surrounding residents of the airport who may be affected by fallout from a collision. BASI, which was charged with the auditing of air safety, said at a hearing of the aircraft noise committee held last week that `parallel runways are inherently safer than intersecting runways'. It is blatantly obvious to Australians that operations which have planes taking off and landing crossing the paths of other planes taking off and landing are less safe than operations involving planes that take off and land parallel to one another.

There has been some argument that planes operating on parallel runways cross paths when in the air. This may be true in a purely token sense but, as was pointed out by Airservices, there is virtually a 1,000-metre division between those planes. There is a general argument that crossing runways are less safe. Even Senator Parer's coalition partners know it. The Leader of the National Party, Mr Fischer, said on 13 August 1991:

SPEECH.PARA: Any further delay in deciding on the third runway for Mascot could mean loss of life as well as economic insanity with Mascot now operating at near maximum capacity and air traffic controllers bending over backwards to extract maximum efficiency of the present archaic runway set up.

He was referring to the crossing runway, of which I am sure everyone is aware. The risk is further highlighted by giving consideration to the number of times crossings would occur if the east-west runway was further utilised. In a recent brief to the minister, Rob Brattner from the Civil Aviation Authority said:

A large number of aircraft would need to cross the east-west runway to position for take-off on the parallel runway or in taxiing to the terminals after landing. It is estimated that aircraft would be expected to cross the east-west runway every 45 seconds or less.
He goes on to say:
With the intersecting east-west runway, the required safety corridors to accommodate aircraft carrying out miss approaches could not readily be accommodated.

Any way you strike it in terms of throughput or in terms of safety, the parallel runway is the way to go. In 1981 an accident almost occurred on the intersecting runways. We have to be grateful that it did not. If it was not for the quick thinking of the pilot of an Ansett jet, who pulled up before colliding with a Thai airline plane, there would have been potentially 1,000 deaths arising from that accident. That is not a risk I am prepared to take, and I do not think the majority of the Australian community is prepared to take it either. I urge the Senate to reject the amendments of both Senator Parer and Senator Bourne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to start my speech on the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill by completely rebutting Senator Neal's assertion that regional New South Wales would be adversely affected by the reopening of the east-west runway. I think the Regional Airlines Association would know a little bit more about the proposal than she does. By media statement on 25 September 1995, it said:

SPEECH.PARA: The two largest independent regional airlines operating in New South Wales, Hazelton and Tamair, today called on the Federal Government to reopen the east west runway and implement long overdue changes to air traffic management procedures . . .
I do not think they are terrible concerned about the possibility that the reopening of the east-west runway might in fact prejudice their operations.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill 1995 today. Rarely has an issue been so badly handled by a government. Kingsford-Smith airport, the international gateway to this country, is the centre of a political shambles that we are all very well aware of. It is a shambles because of gross political bungling by the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton. Labor has cost Australian business millions of dollars in delays and will cost taxpayers at least $260 million in noise remediation works and cost thousands of residents their quality of life. The Sydney Airport Curfew Bill is a genuine attempt to minimise the noise for up to 300,000 Sydneysiders who are affected in one way or another.

The reason we are debating this bill today is solely because the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, recently introduced it as a private member's bill in the parliament. We believe this bill will reduce the suffering of Sydney residents, but I reiterate that it would not be here but for Mr Howard's actions.

The government's apathy and appalling inaction have been the main cause of the problem over Sydney airport. The government's failure to tell the truth about the consequences of the third runway is the principal cause of the problems that thousands of Sydney residents are now facing. These problems have been manifested in ordinary citizens protesting in the streets, suburbs being blockaded, even the birth of a new political party, and Labor mayors left, right and centre have turned their backs on New South Wales Labor. Every one of these actions has been aimed at getting the government to listen to their concerns and getting Mr Brereton and Mr Keating to tell the truth.

Members of the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney have heard story after story of disrupted lives, stress and health problems. More than 5,000 people and organisations have made submissions to our committee, and that figure speaks for itself. I am not sure, but I would doubt that in the history of Senate inquiries and committees there would have been more submissions to a committee of the Senate.

The message we are getting is to reopen the third runway and thereby share the noise over Sydney. Despite what Mr Keating and Mr Brereton say, expert after expert has backed the coalition's balanced position that it is safe to reopen the east-west runway to share this load.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Bob Collins, who is in the chamber, just interjected. Of course, Senator Bob Collins is on the record of 13 August 1991 as having said:

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are that simultaneous operations are in operation at many, many major airports around the world. There is absolutely no reason whatsoever why simultaneous operations, if conducted efficiently and professionally, cannot be used—as they are used in Adelaide, as well as Sydney—with perfect safety.

I remind the minister that simultaneous operations operate in a lot of international airports, including O'Hare in Chicago, Los Angeles International, La Guardia in New York and Logan International in Boston.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, a number of other leading experts have said that it is perfectly safe. For instance, the Australian International Pilots Association said in its submission to the Senate select committee:

SPEECH.PARA: Provided that a model for the correct use of the airspace concerned was satisfactorily tested to levels accepted by air traffic controllers, pilots, the airlines, the CAA and the community, that would permit simultaneous use of all 3 runways, then such operations should be permitted and encouraged.
Of course, Flight Transportation Associates, a leading US consultancy, said in November 1994:

. . . we can say that internationally accepted standards exist for the simultaneous operation of crossing/intersecting runways and, as such, these standards should allow for the safe and efficient operation of Kingsford Smith International Airport as has been the case in the past.

A number of other people support this view. I want to put on record a comment by the CEO designate of Airservices Australia on the AM program on 29 September 1995. He made these comments before he was nobbled by the government. Mr Pollard said:

. . . throughout the world and in my past experience, there are many airports that have intersecting runways and they're used quite safely. In fact, many airports do not have parallel runways, but usually have one north-south and one east-west and many times they are intersecting, and it's done safely.

In 1989, when the third runway at Kingsford Smith airport was being talked about, it had two runways—one north-south, and one east-west. The Labor government spent $250 million of taxpayers' money, and we have ended up with 1 1/2 runways. You cannot take off to the north on the new, second parallel runway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want aircraft to take off to the north?
—The assumption is it is not safe.
—Pardon? What has it got to do with safety? It has a lot to do with noise.

—We were promised three runways and we finished up with 1 1/2 runways. It seems to be a bit of Labor inflation in reverse. We have not increased the capacity of Sydney airport. In the process we have spent $250 million of taxpayers' money, with much more to be spent on noise amelioration.

PARA.TAB: The government's incompetence over the whole affair is made clear by its haste to open the third runway. It was opened before the close ground separation radar was working. It was opened before the new control tower was opened. The new control tower is not open yet. At the end of the day, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) engineered the crisis that we are facing today. In the Bulletin of December last year Laurie Oakes wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The original proposal was supposed to be that aircraft should take off only to the south and land from the south so that they flew over water rather than houses. Clever Keating changed that and sent them roaring over suburbia. The east-west runway was supposed to continue operating, but it was Keating that killed that idea, too, and ensured that all planes operated on the north-south axis.

I take this opportunity to say something about the noise assessment process, of which there has been much criticism. The noise impact assessment in the EIS was done by using the Australian standard known as the Australian noise enforcement forecast. It is commonly called the ANEF. Airservices Australia, formerly the CAA, says that the forecast on noise contours is accurate. However, many more people feel affected than was expected. It seems to me that is a flawed method of assessment.

PARA.TAB: It appears that the ANEF is designed as a land use planning tool. Up to 20 ANEF is regarded as standard urban noise. Many people who are subject to 20 ANEF feel that it is much more than standard urban noise. Many Sydney residents felt that as they were outside the 20 ANEF contour they would be all right.

The original EIS said that there would be only 82,000 residents inside the 15 ANEF. In other words, it was calculated that with the virtual closure of the east-west runway the number affected would be reduced from 130,000 to 82,000. However, 300,000 people believe they are affected, many seriously, and were, therefore, misinformed.

I acknowledge the difficulty of estimating the impact of noise. Even at an ANEF of 10, 20 per cent of residents would be affected, and 25 per cent of those would feel seriously affected. It is the constancy of noise along the flight paths, not just the lack of veracity in the assessment process, that has caused the outcry. As I said, 5,000 submissions cannot all be wrong.

Airservices Australia, which is now responsible for monitoring noise, never said there would be no noise, but people in the 20 ANEF contour are getting readings of up to 90 decibels. It must be remembered that about 65 decibels interferes with normal conversation.

I just bring to your notice, Mr Acting Deputy President, that only those houses in the 30-plus ANEF contour are being soundproofed; the 40-plus are being purchased by the government. Schools in the 25-plus are being soundproofed, but the 4,200 houses that are being soundproofed will cost the travelling public about $260 million.

There are some lessons and solutions from this shambles. We must, as a community, find better ways of consulting within the community on these sorts of major decisions. For the development of Sydney south-west airport we must develop additional information on noise or history will be repeated. I acknowledge that when Sydney south-west airport is open we will have quieter aircraft, but the problem of noise is not going to go away, especially with people who quite legitimately expect to have a cleaner and better environment in which to live.

As I have mentioned, there is an enormous difference in this whole disappointing episode between what people were told and how many feel that they are affected by noise. Overall, there is this requirement that the east-west runway be reopened to spread the noise burden, and I support Senator Parer's amendment in this regard.

We support the noise curfew bill with the amendment to reopen the east-west runway. We believe that Airservices Australia should be given the ability to reopen the third runway for normal operations, bearing in mind safety, capacity and noise. I think that if those three requirements of safety, capacity and noise are met, there is no reason—this is supported by the experts that I called on earlier—why the east-west runway should not be reopened. Airservices Australia in their evidence to us agree that they operate to government instruction—and one would not expect them to do anything else, as that is obviously the role that they have—but I believe that the government policy should be changed without prejudicing safety, and it should be done to share the noise load.

I would just like to finish by pointing out the obvious—the importance of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport in its unique position for a major airport in a major city and as a gateway to Australia; what an important part aviation has played in the development of this very vast continent; and what an important part KSA has played in that. I think that that should remain.

I would also like to make the point that it is absolutely vital for regional airlines and country people doing business in Sydney to have access to KSA because, if they were forced to go anywhere else—to Sydney south-west, for instance—the cost of coming down for a day's business would be made much greater by the necessity probably to stay overnight. That is something that regional New South Wales does not need—now or at any stage. I just make the point that the question is: why can't aircraft operate east of the airport during the middle of the day when there are very few traffic movements? Regional airlines use propjet aircraft, which are much quieter anyway.

I think it needs to be said that there are obvious advantages of KSA. When we were talking about the Olympic bid, it was pointed out that Kingsford Smith was a very convenient airport for overseas visitors, and it is. The final thing I would like to say is that, if Australia is to be a hub in Asia, we need an airport that can grow in addition to our new Sydney south-west airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Greens (WA), I would like to place on the record some concerns and some ideas on the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill. We agree with the bill in terms of being able to vote for it; in fact, it puts current regulation in a regulatory framework. However, the timing of it is perhaps either unfortunate or opportune. The timing is unfortunate because there is still a committee dealing with the noise issues at Sydney airport and some of the amendments that we are being asked to consider on this bill are outcomes or responses to the committee's deliberations. It would be extremely useful for us to have those deliberations as a basis for making decisions.

PARA.TAB: The fact that there will be no huge changes as a result of the bill, because it largely establishes a regulatory framework anyway—it simply confirms the status quo—would not necessarily make much difference to the way things are now operating at Sydney. Perhaps we could call this the Sydney Airport Election Bill.

What we are seeing now, long after the fact, is the result of a knee-jerk reaction to demand projection, and that tends to be focused on dollars. Perhaps when the original plans were being made the actual social, environmental and other considerations were not put high enough on the agenda to be carefully considered.

I am reminded of the process in Perth when city feeder roads got jammed at peak times. The response from a series of governments has been to widen the roads to enable those roads to take more traffic and faster. Another response has been to provide more parking space. The only response, of course, to that has been to increase road traffic and to end up with another traffic jam. Perth has the highest per capita parking space of any major city in Australia. So in that sense, people increased demand instead of thinking more laterally about alternatives to road transport.

Here we have seen a similar situation with air transport: an increased demand in the use of Sydney airport caused partly by airline decisions to duplicate schedules and by a lack of viable, attractive alternatives. Some of those alternatives could be a properly planned, very fast train from Sydney to major points where Sydney traffic is in demand, and a much greater concentration and availability of video conferencing for all those kinds of one-day trips from Sydney to Canberra or from Sydney to Melbourne.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you thought of video conferencing for the Senate? We could vote from our electorate offices.
—Already a revolution is occurring in the Senate. What could never be done before, that is, the ability of committees to meet through video conferencing, is now being considered—and about time too!
—Hear, hear!
—Hear, hear! Maybe in the future we will be able to hold Senate meetings through video conferencing—not right away.
—Don't hold your breath.

—I am not holding my breath—there is a lot of tradition, obviously. However, the reality for many kinds of business meetings is that the necessity to be physically in the same spot does not necessarily exist any more. The technology is improving all the time. More and more people are operating from home, especially in combining family and work commitments, which also has lots of benefits in allowing people to share various concerns.

PARA.TAB: There is also the situation where, in reality, while travelling by air, we do not necessarily calculate the time it takes to commute from the airport to the city centre. Often if there were a well-planned train system perhaps linking up to light rail in many cases—which a lot of people certainly would like to see in Perth—perhaps we could have a much more sensible way of getting conveniently to the places we want to go to, whether for business or pleasure. The ability to get to those places and not divide out our cities is extremely important.

I suppose the most important issue for me, which occurred to me when I was considering the whole approach to this bill, is: are we really planning for the future? The original future demand assumptions on Sydney airport may have been invalid.

There was a recently published paper from Murdoch University by Mr Brian Fleays which talked about the world's demand for and supply of petroleum. There is a growing consensus that in a relatively short time, the world will be reaching the halfway point of the world's petroleum resources. You might think, `Oh, this is great. We have been using petroleum for years and years.' Yes, but we are using it at a much greater rate now than we were doing 10 or 20 years ago.

The point is that industry, of course, have used the cheapest and most easily available sources of petroleum quickest. From the halfway point, any economist will tell you that the marginal cost of producing that petroleum will go through the roof. What we have had in the last few years, with the breaking up of the OPEC cartel, is an artificially low price for petroleum.

When that crunch hits, which it will, the more dependent we are on petroleum—which argument we have used in the international fora as to why we should not be taking actions on greenhouse gas reductions—and the less we have responded to the necessity of reducing our dependence on petroleum, the more we will find ourselves in deep trouble with the actual hitting of increased prices. The crunch might not come straightaway, but it is not going to be too far down the track in terms of generations.

The response to greenhouse may also eventually hit Australia as being something real—not only as something to which we are contributing in a per capita way at a very high level but also as something that is actually going to affect and is affecting Australia already. We may have to find alternatives. If we are not thinking about alternative strategies to transport now, then we will have a big problem in the future.

I will be listening very carefully to the debate in relation to amendments in the committee stage. I will be looking at the rationale for the amendments. I will be looking at whether or not the impact will be to enable Sydney to handle or reduce its demand and the ability for alternatives to be found, or perhaps whether or not amendments are aimed at a cynical exercise in order to gain the impression that something is being done at this stage. I will be looking to see whether or not there is any real desire to address the situation of the transport problem in Australia. Therefore, we will be reserving our decision as to the various amendments, until we have heard the full arguments from either side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In terms of the debate that has just concluded, perhaps I will briefly address first some of the remarks that Senator Margetts has made. Then I will turn to some of the other contributions through which there ran a general theme.

PARA.TAB: I would concur with the reference made by Senator Margetts to the technology available nowadays that can assist in reducing unnecessary travel. It is technology that I personally use at every opportunity. I might just say to Senator Margetts that I have found from my own experience that telephone conferencing, when dealing with people who in the main you know, is as effective a tool as video conferencing. With the high fidelity equipment that is available now for telephone conferencing, I have found that the vision, being able to see the person concerned, does not add anything to it—and in the case of someone like myself, in fact, positively improves the aesthetics.

Technology such as this and fast rail should be used at every opportunity. I can also relate to what Senator Margetts said about taking into consideration the full extent of the journey. It is certainly something I do, Senator Margetts. That is the reason why when I go to Newcastle from Sydney I routinely travel by train. Why waste time going to the airport to sit around at the terminal, get onto the taxiway and finally get to wherever you are going when you have the option of an extremely pleasant short train journey—and it is still one of the more pleasant train journeys in Australia? It is line ball and people should do that. I wish to concur with those suggestions.

Senator Margetts would agree that is something that will, I hope, happen to an increasing extent in the future to attempt to ameliorate, to some extent, the frequency of flights. But flying, without a doubt, is an extremely safe form of travel. It is the most effective and efficient form of travel in a country as large as ours. It is being used, as we know, with increasing frequency. That is likely to be the reality, despite those technological advancements, for some time in the future.

Turning to the general theme of the opposition's contribution to the debate, it traversed over a very well-worn path. I guess the thing that irritates me just a tad is the extraordinary case of collective amnesia which the opposition is suffering from. Senator Bourne, I might add, had the awfully bad taste to point that out to those opposite in her contribution. But, as the person who was aviation minister of this country for I think some three years and having received directly the non-stop lobbying of coalition members and senators for the construction of the third runway, as originally predicated, even with the cynicism that does afflict politics from time to time, this is a piece of breathtaking opportunism that really is in a class of its own.

The false impression that has been deliberately created by coalition members and senators on this issue in Sydney by forgetting completely about their full-blooded support—support is too mild a word—their full-blooded attacks on the government for not hurrying up the runway, the constant questions I got both inside and outside parliament about when it is going to be open, totally ignores the basis upon which that runway was going to operate from day one.

I forgive senators like Senator Sandy Macdonald, who has come late to this debate and of course has never picked up the weighty volumes of the EIS. I came into the ministry after the decision was taken to construct the third runway, but the particular job I got was to oversight the completion of the environmental impact process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you take responsibility for that?

—Senator, the decision was taken the year before I became a minister. But the job I got immediately given to me by the then Minister for Transport, Kim Beazley, was to have the carriage of the EIS process. After having had 100 briefings and meetings with Ken Hills and transparencies and overhead projections to burn, I am very familiar with the fact that the coalition would now like to forget that the entire operation was predicated on a lessened use of the east-west runway and the full use of the two parallel runways at Sydney airport leading to an increase, a change in the noise patterns, around the north and south of Sydney airport and a reduction in the noise experienced by those to the east and the west.

PARA.TAB: The whole atmosphere that has now been created by the opposition—and here it is in front of us in terms of reopening the east-west runway, which I might add has never been closed and is not closed as we speak; and I will talk about that in a minute—is that somehow or other this was an unforeseen consequence when in fact the whole thing was predicated from day one on traffic to the north and south and less traffic to the east and west. That was always going to be the case. Now the opposition, on the road to Damascus and with a sniff of polling day in front of it, wants to more equitably share the distribution of the noise around Sydney airport.

I will not go over in detail what has been said in the past; it is all here on the public record, and it condemns the opposition with every single line. The Leader of the Opposition has been much quoted in terms of the full-blooded support he gave for the construction of the third runway. I will not go over all those quotes again, and the absolutely dismissive position that he took on concerns about noise. That is an accurate description of all the comments he made. I will not read them out again; it is all there on the public record. I can add to that, and I want to add to that, the non-stop representations I received as the minister who was oversighting the progress of the EIS and the actual construction from opposition senators and members for the construction of this runway as soon as possible.

I can go one step further than that. I do not know whether it has been canvassed in the debate. I followed as closely as I could all the speakers but I missed out bits and pieces. I recall Senator Margetts very well, and not only the full-blooded support for the opening of the east-west runway but the active consideration on a number of occasions by the opposition of the removal of the curfew at Sydney airport. That is how far they wanted to go.
