The reason I recall it is that I had to, not on one and not on two occasions, but on half a dozen occasions, make categorical statements as aviation minister that we would not do that.

So we have now got a bunch of political opportunists—and that is what they are—making hay, as they think, while the sun shines in Sydney, and saying `Oh, isn't it terrible, the noise', and `Here is the solution to it', in what is one of the most irresponsible pieces of legislation that has ever come into this parliament. I will explain why in a minute. They are saying: `Let us forget about the days when we supported the construction of the third runway and let us forget about the days when we were lobbying the government for the removal of the curfew at Sydney airport and for 24-hour-a-day operations at Sydney'—not just the conservatives here in the federal parliament but their colleagues in the state parliament of New South Wales.

As aviation minister I can pull these statements out, but I do not need to because, as those senators who have been involved in this debate for some time know, I had to on behalf of the government on a number of occasions assert very strongly that we would not give any consideration to such a proposition to remove the curfew from Sydney airport.

Having disposed of that little piece of history, let us turn to how tissue-thin the opposition's case is on what I said when it was mooted—and I say it now in this debate—is one of the most irresponsible legislative propositions in a real sense that has ever been brought into a parliament. I was not joking, Senator Parer, when I said that I had constructed in my mind the potential royal commission that might be held into the first major accident at Sydney airport for whatever reason. The nature of hindsight and royal commissions is that it would not matter what the circumstances were about that accident if that accident occurred, for any reason, as a result of simultaneous operations at Sydney airport. I was the minister when this much talked about incident occurred at Sydney airport and I have never forgotten that day. In 1991 there weren't parallel runways at Sydney airport.

If you want to rewrite history when that statement was made, what I have said consistently is, `Yes, you can operate intersecting runways safely but parallel runways are inherently safer.' I have always said that. The reason I have said it is on the basis of advice that I received then and have received now—it is consistent advice—from people who know far more about it than I do, the people in charge of actual air safety and air regulation at Sydney airport and air traffic control and the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, an organisation for whose professionalism and expertise I have very high regard.

I have to tell you this, Senator Margetts, in terms of the outrageous proposition that this Senate, this parliament, is going to run air traffic control at Sydney airport against the advice of the regulatory authority that actually runs it at Sydney airport and against the direct advice provided to this committee that Senator Macdonald has talked about from Dr Lee. Have a look at it. I will tell what you BASI said to me consistently about simultaneous operations. Dr Rob Lee said consistently: `Yes, you can operate intersecting runways safely, but in order to do it safely you would have to reduce the actual frequencies at the airport.'

This is what he and others in BASI have said to me, and I have never forgotten it, `Well, if you're going to operate simultaneous operations on intersecting runways with frequencies of up to 80 an hour, good luck.' That is what they said. This is what the opposition has said. Have a listen, Senator Macdonald; you have not read the report, and I know it. I was astonished to see a press statement put out by John Howard, grabbing at this particular straw that went floating past, by saying that the US consultants Flight Transportation Associates report advocated the use of the three runways. I immediately got on to the Department of Transport and said, `Surely, this couldn't be the same report that was done in 1989. There must be another one,' but they said, `No, it's the same report.'

Let me tell you how tissue thin the opposition's position on safety grounds is, and Senator Parer knows this. I know that he will be grateful, that Senator Macdonald will be grateful and that every single frequent user, particularly of Sydney airport, will be grateful that simultaneous operations are not being reintroduced to Sydney airport with those crossing runways, even though you say that is your political position.

Here is the real situation with that report. The report was prepared in 1989—this is what John Howard is relying on—as a theoretical computer modelling exercise of capacity options at the airport. It does not represent a detailed analysis of operational or safety issues. The introduction to this report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The capacity of the airport under existing conditions and under a number of number of hypothetical future alternatives has been estimated. It should be emphasised that examination of a hypothetical alternative does not imply that this scenario has been deemed feasible with respect to engineering, economic, environmental, statutory or other aspects.

The report itself clearly states that it does not address the safety and operational issues involved in the use of the intersecting runways at Sydney airport. Additionally, to achieve the high movement rates comparable to what can be achieved under a parallel runway system, the computer modelling assumes—and that is what it is—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are all computer models.
—But have a listen to the assumption, Senator Parer. You are making it obvious that you have not bothered to read this report.
—Of course I have read it and I have got another one that you have not seen.
—Do you realise that it is modelled on the terminals actually sitting physically between the parallel runways?
—No, not the latest one.
—Well, let us see the latest one, Senator.
—It was given to the committee just last week.

—This is fascinating. I did not know there was a later one. I will have a look at that. Additionally, to achieve the high movement rates comparable to what can be achieved under a parallel runway system the modelling assumes that the terminal location at Sydney airport is actually between the two parallel runways—which, of course, it is not—and south of the east-west runway. It also envisages rapid exit taxiways off the east-west runway giving direct access to the terminal apron. This is necessary to enable all three runways to operate at the same time. Clearly, this is impractical.

PARA.TAB: All of the scenarios modelled in the report involved the use of cross runways that rely on simultaneous operations. I might add one thing that this report does do, as you know, Senator Parer. In respect of capacity at the airport, the FTA report agrees with all of the experts the coalition has chosen to ignore, such as Airservices Australia, CASA, BASI, Department of Transport, Qantas and Ansett, that all of the crossing runway scenarios developed deliver less capacity than the independent use of the parallel runway system—all except the proposal that the airlines want to pursue of propeller aircraft off the eastern stub.

In fact the report indicates that operations as currently being undertaken at Sydney airport provide significantly greater capacity than any cross-runway configuration. Importantly, this capacity can be achieved without the less safe operation of cross runways. I have not got time now but I will take this much further in the committee stage.

I want to conclude by responding to the invitation I heard Senator Parer issue to me on the monitor that I should come in here and provide some evidence as to why the parallel runway system should continue to be used. I do not have to go further than BASI. Senator Parer, I am just astonished that you could be irresponsible enough—even though your leader is—just to ignore the advice of the Director of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation.

After all, it is the organisation that gets to clean up the mess afterwards. It was the organisation that advised me about what it thought about simultaneous operations the day that collision almost occurred on that intersection at Sydney airport. We were about three seconds away from collision. Of course, we were only saved from it by the professionalism of that Ansett pilot that aborted his landing. This is what Dr Lee told the committee on this issue, in response to questions from Senator Forshaw:

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that crossing runways tend to be the norm at most of the older airports is that they date back from the days when aircraft had to take off into wind directly. As aircraft performance has improved, they are able to tolerate a greater cross-wind component, so the need for that very specific directional element of the airports is no longer there.

PARA.TAB: If you look at the more modern airports—

SPEECH.PARA: and have a look at them, Senator Macdonald—

which have been designed in recent years, they have virtually all gone for parallel runway configurations, the reason being that it removes the necessity for aircraft to either approach each other on converging or intersecting runways. There are not only runways which intersect but converging runways which, if you extend them, will meet further on at a point of intersection, which again provides an element of risk if two aircraft have to go around at once . . .

That is one of the things that the air traffic controllers have pointed out. The president of the air traffic controllers association put out a statement saying that we should not return to intersecting runways and simultaneous operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—No? I will table the press statement from the president of the air traffic controllers association.
—He said that with political will it can be done.

—So Qantas, Ansett, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, CASA and the union that represents air traffic controllers have all crumbled to pressure, have they? Fair crack of the whip! I did not notice the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation do anything other than operate strictly independently of both the government and the CAA in the time that I was aviation minister. To continue with BASI's evidence to Senator Parer's committee, all of which will be ignored—
—Read the lot.
—I will read the lot:

PARA.TAB: One of the problems with the crossing runways is that . . . once you have got the aircraft off the ground, you then have a more complex problem with the flight paths in terms of aircraft that take off to the east and to the south having to turn to the right and set course, and so on; so there is another problem there. The evidence is that, world-wide, where you can do it, parallel runways are the best option.

SPEECH.PARA: That is BASI's evidence to the committee. As I said—and I was not joking—this is a very brave piece of legislation you are asking us to put our names to. I have said before that I think this is the single piece of legislation that indicates that the whole of you lot are utterly unfit to govern this country. If you expect this parliament and this Senate to go against formal advice on the record from the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation in Australia that we should not go back to these intersecting runways and simultaneous operations, then you are really sticking your necks right out the window if you put yourselves in place of the air traffic control regime at Sydney airport and the investigatory body that advises it and the government on the most safe procedures to operate at Sydney airport. Its advice to me on Simops was always consistent.

PARA.TAB: Sure you can operate it safely at a lower frequency, but that is not so if you are going to operate it at 80 movements an hour with intersecting runways. The real problem—and go and talk to them, Senator Macdonald—occurs if something goes wrong. If aircraft have to abort landings, and they do from time to time, those intersecting paths in the air as well as on the ground make it far more difficult—this has been given in evidence to your committee, Senator Parer—for the pilots and the air traffic controllers. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advance to the Minister for Finance and Supporting Applications—August 1995

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Calvert) proposed:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some items in relation to the Advances to the Minister for Finance for the month of August 1995 which I find quite extraordinary and of considerable concern. They are matters that the Senate ought to look at in great detail, and I am sure they will on another occasion, but I want to draw it to the attention of the Senate at the moment.

PARA.TAB: The first matter I draw attention to is the application by the Attorney-General's Department for a payment to meet an act of grace payment for the legal costs incurred by the former Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Mr Alan Griffiths, in respect of the inquiry into the so-called sandwich affair. You might remember that he owned a sandwich shop and difficulties arose with that. He resigned as a minister and there was then an inquiry conducted by Mr Michael Codd.

That was not a judicial inquiry—it was not seeking evidence for the bringing of criminal charges or anything like that—it was an inquiry into the conduct of the minister. Despite that fact and despite the fact that the minister had already resigned, there were, I understand, something like $540,000 in legal costs incurred, which the government is going to get the taxpayers to foot the bill for. I think I am correct in saying that that $540,000 is included in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1995-96, which is presently before the parliament.

The application here from the Advance to the Minister for Finance was to make an interim payment of $150,000 to the solicitors Michael Brereton and Co., who were acting on behalf of Mr Griffiths. That $150,000 was required as an interim payment while they were sorting out how much was really going to be involved in the long run in all of this. We are told now that that figure is $540,000.

I find the circumstances of that quite extraordinary. Why the Australian taxpayer should be required to meet costs of that nature is a question that most Australian taxpayers would be asking very seriously. I am sure we are going to hear more about that as time goes on, particularly as the consideration of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) takes place in the days and weeks ahead.

The other item that I draw attention to is an application for funds for the Department of Defence to meet an operating subsidy for those parts of Aerospace Technologies of Australia which were not sold to Rockwell Systems Australia, RSA, when that company bought out ASTA earlier this year. There were certain parts they did not want. I think they got what they did get virtually for nothing because they said they would take them only on a debt-free basis. But there were certain operating activities that continued in the government's hands and they are requiring extraordinarily large government subsidies just to keep them afloat.

The August Advance to the Minister for Finance statement detailed two separate payments—one of about $1 1/2 million and the other in the order of $2 million—and that is going to go on and on. We will find that in the September and subsequent applications as well. This is a classic example of a government not being able to get its act together in the operation of businesses. More importantly, what it has done has been to get rid of some assets for free and to leave the others at great operating cost to the taxpayer.
I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advance to the Minister for Finance and Supporting Applications—September 1995

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Calvert) proposed:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take too much of the Senate's time, but I want to continue my remarks in relation to the continuing operating subsidy for Aerospace Technologies of Australia Aircraft Services Pty Ltd because there are further payments in the September Advances to the Minister for Finance which flow on from the remarks I have made about the August payments.

PARA.TAB: Let me point out again to the Senate that on 18 August, and again on 1 September, the delegate of the Minister for Finance approved Advances from the Minister for Finance—firstly, an amount of $1.56 million and, secondly, an amount of $1.1 million—to cover the operating costs of this business for four weeks, for just two fortnights ending 4 and 19 September respectively. Since then, the company has advised that, based on fortnightly cash flow projections, there were insufficient funds to meet operating expenses for the next fortnightly period—that is, the one ending 3 October—and on that basis there was a requirement for additional funding of another $1.5 million. It goes on to say in the accompanying documentation:

SPEECH.PARA: Additional applications will be made as required based on fortnightly cash flow up to 31 October 1995 to meet ongoing operating costs comprising payments to creditors, group tax and salary payments.

Beyond 31 October it is not certain by any means that there will not be an ongoing requirement. In other words, an extraordinarily large amount of taxpayers' funds is required to meet these operating subsidies. As I said, an amount of something like $2 1/2 million or more each month is required for this process. I do not know how much attention has been given to that by the parliament. It was something that was announced by the government after the 1995-96 budget was released. The decision to do this was made in July. To my knowledge, it has escaped any detailed scrutiny by the parliament. I hope that the estimates processes that we are going through at the moment will allow at least some consideration of this. It is yet another example of how this government can take decisions outside the normal processes of government which lead to a very expensive use of taxpayers' money often without the sufficient scrutiny that the taxpayers of Australia and the electors of Australia would expect this parliament to undertake.

PARA.TAB: I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a report by the Australian Taxation Office on taxation statistics. The report contains a very significant table relating to sales tax for the financial year 1994-95. It is a significant table because we all remember at the last election that the Labor Party was not going to have a bar of consumption taxes. The Labor Party did not have a bar of it then, but it is shown in this table to have collected over $11 billion in consumption taxes. The public of Australia would probably be intrigued to note the items on which the government is collecting consumption tax—particularly in view of the government's totally dishonest campaign against consumption taxes at the last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is something like a 50 per cent increase over the last three or four years.

—As Senator Short properly says, it is a 50 per cent increase in rip-offs over the last three years since the government promised at the last election that it would oppose consumption taxes. For example, on household appliances, parts and accessories $1 billion in sales tax was collected by this government in the year to the end of June. What hypocrisy!
—That is taking it from the workers.

—Yes, the workers and the battlers who are struggling to set up their new homes. Those people are being hit by this consumption tax which this government promised to oppose. Even when we buy household hardware—crockery, glassware, cutlery, brooms and mops—we pay consumption tax. Last year Australian consumers had to pay the government $137 million in consumption tax for these items. For household drapery, soft furnishings, manchester, blinds, curtain tracks and fittings and floor coverings the Australian consumer had to pay the Keating government $201 million in consumption tax last year.

PARA.TAB: We have things like building materials and hand tools. People build their own homes or have contractors build homes for them. These people paid $284 million in consumption tax. There would have been another couple of hundred million dollars if the Senate had not blocked an attempt by the government to increase and spread further the Keating consumption tax—the KST—on building materials.

We come to aerated waters and cordials. Every time you buy a bottle of Coke or whatever it is that you drink you are contributing to the Keating government. I am not suggesting that you do not drink so that you do not contribute, but the fact is that $331 million in consumption tax was taken by this government on aerated waters and cordials. For spirits, beer and wine the government collected $1.1 billion in consumption tax. One would not think that the government would tax soaps, detergents, disinfectants, toiletries and beauty preparations. But, oh yes, the government did. To keep themselves clean Australians have had to pay about $300 million in consumption tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —There wouldn't be a tax on toilet paper, would there?

—There is a tax on toilet paper, Senator Calvert, because paper, stationery, paper products, cardboard containers and so on, including toilet paper and recycled paper, cost Australian consumers $216 million in consumption tax to the Keating government. For the kids: toys, games, novelties, fireworks, pens, pencils, drawing materials et cetera attracted $205 million in consumption tax last year.

PARA.TAB: Sales tax on sporting equipment and so on was $132 million. This is not a bad effort from a government that is opposed to consumption taxes. In the latest year the sales tax on motor vehicles, parts and commercial vehicles, and this particularly hits the rural area where there is no other means of transport, was $3,000 million. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very glad to follow my colleague Senator Michael Baume on this matter of sales tax because I believe the Australian taxpayer ought to know how much they are paying for the excesses of the Labor government. This is all about the excesses and dishonesty of the Labor Party that are being brought to book in these statistics today.
—Oh, dear!

—Senator Crowley says, `Oh, dear!' A lot of Australians say, `Oh, dear' because they find the price of goods exceedingly dear because of the sales tax, the consumption tax, they are made to pay by a government who manned the polling booths at the last election with people handing out their how-to-vote signs saying, `No GST'.

PARA.TAB: They were giving out those how-to-vote papers saying, `No GST, no consumption tax,' but of course they did not tell the people they already had a consumption tax. Nobody in the Labor Party in the last election—not one single senator or member, not one candidate for the Labor Party—had the honesty or the integrity to say that Australia already had a consumption tax. Instead, we had one of the most disgraceful efforts at misleading the Australian public that has ever occurred in the history of Australian politics. Here are the statistics. The amount of tax paid by Australians is quite simply astronomical.

TALK.START.PARA: —And more with a GST.

—I am glad Senator Jacinta Collins interjected. Of course the fact is that there would be less tax on motor vehicles if we had a GST because prior to the last election our beloved Prime Minister (Mr Keating) gave the Australian community an undertaking that the tax on cars would be permanently reduced. Tears were almost welling in his eyes when he said it would be permanently reduced to 15 per cent from 20 per cent. Of course, that rate was permanent until the election had transpired and then the rate of tax was increased to 20 per cent and 21 per cent. Now the rate of sales tax that is paid on cars is 22 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Senator Jacinta Collins ignorantly interjects that there would be less tax paid than if we had a GST. Senator Jacinta Collins is quite clearly wrong—wrong on each count and wrong to try to mislead the Australian people in that way. The amount of tax that is paid is quite simply scandalous. For example, Australians pay $63 million a year in sales tax on manufactured pet foods.

Here is one example that would interest Senator Gareth Evans, and I am sure other honourable senators will find this interesting: we pay $59 million a year in sales tax on suitcases, handbags, purses, wallets and baskets. Of course, this is the government that said, `We're not going to give you a GST; we're going to help you pay for your kids' Christmas.' That was one of their election pledges.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sales tax on suitcases is higher than it would have been under the coalition.

—Of course it is. You are absolutely correct that the sales tax on suitcases, handbags, purses, wallets and baskets is indeed higher than it would have been under the coalition. But what I love is the fact that this is the government who sits over there and campaigns that it would make Christmas more affordable by not having a GST on toys. The sales tax on toys, games, novelties, fireworks, pens, pencils and drawing materials, as Senator Baume says, is 22 per cent and accounts for $205 million of taxpayers' money a year.

PARA.TAB: I do not understand how any one of these people on the other side can look the Australian public in the eye and say that they are interested in the ordinary Australian battler. Not one of them can do that because they are the heirs, the inheritors, the benefactors, of the most massive lie in Australian politics, which was to trust the Labor Party and it would look after the battlers. In fact, the Labor Party is the biggest taxing party, the biggest taking party, that has ever ruled the Australian nation, and that is something that I think the Australian public will want to rectify at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to make a brief contribution to the discussion on the Australian Taxation Office report that is currently before us. The situation is that under Labor the people of Australia now pay more in indirect taxes over the whole gamut than they would have under the then John Hewson GST.
—And without the major income tax cuts.

—Yes, without the benefit of all the income tax decreases. Of course those taxes apply to food and a whole lot of essentials. The tax on petrol has increased. Under us it would have substantially decreased. They would have had lower income tax.

PARA.TAB: The reason that I am contributing to this debate is to highlight yet again the absolute deception that was perpetrated on the Australian people during the last election campaign with a promise that there would be no GST. But a rose by any other name smells just as sweet and, similarly, a consumption tax, be it called a GST or a consumption tax, still taxes the people.

What has occurred is that Paul Keating—or the Prime Minister, Mr Keating—promised to the people no GST, yet has gone about collecting a consumption tax from the people and is now raising more in indirect taxes than the people of Australia would have needed to pay had the GST been introduced. The scale of the sales taxes paid in returns shown on pages 408 and 409 of the document we are discussing highlights the huge amount of taxes that are being collected by a whole number of businesses, from motor vehicles to tyres and recaps, boats, household appliances, household hardware, domestic furniture, household drapery, blinds, curtains, floor coverings, even bicycles. Chances are not many rich people would get around on bicycles, other than Mr McLeay, of course, other than the then Speaker, who got an extra $70,000. That is part of the Labor Party's commitment to equity and social justice, that the rich Speaker of the House of Representatives could get another $70,000 for falling off a bike that he should not have been on in the first place. But I have sidetracked myself.

It once again highlights the hypocrisy of Labor's taxation policies—on aerated waters and cordials, insecticides, confectionary, soaps and detergents. Indeed, Senator Calvert interjected that surely it would not apply to toilet paper. Yes, it does. No matter what, if you buy it, Labor want to tax it. Under us the essentials of food would not have been taxed, but under Labor they are still being taxed.

The reason I make this contribution is that places such as New Zealand that have introduced a proper regime of indirect taxation are now reaping the rewards. They have an unemployment rate lower than ours. Their economy is burgeoning, is growing, is providing jobs and is paying off their international debt. At the end of this year they will be in credit as a nation.

I then look at our record. It is a shameful record. The point that needs to be stressed is that under Labor's sales tax regime and indirect tax regime they are collecting more money—I stress `more money'—than a GST would have collected. That shows the hypocrisy of Labor. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have seen in the last couple of months what everybody knows to have been a phoney election campaign, because the government worked itself up into a frenzy—
—You did.

—Senator Sherry, I was perfectly relaxed. You, however, worked yourself into a frenzy because you could see that you were never going to make that high ministerial office that you seek, because Labor is going to lose the next election. Indeed, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was undoubtedly of the same view, which is why he did not make that short drive out to Yarralumla and seek to have an election called and to put the matter of his stewardship, and the Labor Party's stewardship, of the Australian economy to the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: There are some matters that are deserving of comment on the conduct of the so-called phoney election campaign and, more importantly, on the conduct of the Labor Party generally. I want to take this opportunity to record my absolute and utter abhorrence of some of the statements that have been made by the Prime Minister in relation to the ethnic community in this country. Honourable senators know that I only infrequently rise in this place to deal with matters to do with ethnic Australians, not because I do not have any regard for them but rather because I believe that the best interests of the community are served by serving the community as a whole. However, there are times when it is important that there is a voice for the ethnic community in this parliament, and on those occasions I have never shirked from my responsibility to represent the ethnic communities of this country.

I want to make it very clear here in this chamber tonight that the most disgusting comments of the Prime Minister in relation to the Chinese community have been treated by most of the ethnic Chinese population of this country as an insult to their intellect. For the Prime Minister of this country dishonestly to say that Chinese Australians know that John Howard will put them on a boat back to wherever they came from if he wins the election was the most outrageous, shameful, disgraceful and overblown piece of paranoid propaganda that I have heard in this parliament for a long time.

I note that my friend Senator Panizza has come into the chamber. He has a long association with the ethnic Italian community of this country and he, I am sure, would be just as shocked if the Prime Minister said that a coalition victory would mean that all the ethnic Italians in this country would be put on a boat and sent back. My friend Senator Abetz would be just as shocked, and the ethnic German community would be just as shocked, if the Prime Minister said, `Oh, well, the coalition under Mr Howard would put all the Germans on a boat back to the country from which they came.'

Of course, the funny thing is that many ethnic Chinese like me did not come here in a boat. We did not come here in a plane. We did not come here in any way other than the most normal of deliveries: we were born in this country. They cannot send us back. There is nowhere we can go to. Of course, this shows the Prime Minister's ignorance of the ethnic diversity of this nation. An enormous number of the people that he likes to classify as `ethnic Chinese'—which he is going to scare with some dreadful tale about Mr Howard chopping them up or eating their children or whatever the paranoid delusion happens to be this week—are, of course, people who were born in this country. Where does the Prime Minister suppose that I am going to be sent? Where does the Prime Minister suppose my brother and my sister are going to be sent? This is the most ridiculous paranoia that I have heard, but this is the extent to which the Prime Minister is willing to go to divide the Australian community.

This was not the first attempt to kick the race can—and they are not my words, they are the Prime Minister's words—this was not even the second attempt; it was the third attempt in less than two months to `kick the race can', as the Prime Minister put it—not too eloquently, I may add, but that is his way.

I should say that, if the Prime Minister wants to kick the race can, he should first start by kicking the bigotry out of the Australian Labor Party. There is a member in the other place who sat with me on a plane, on a fairly long flight I am afraid to say, from one Australian city to another during which period of time he asked me what I was doing in this country. My response was quite simple: I was born in this country.

But if members of the Labor Party in the House of Representatives are to be allowed to ask every ethnic Chinese or every ethnic Italian what they are doing in this country, then I do not think it sends out a very good signal as to the sort of tolerance that one can expect from the Labor Party. I think it sends out a signal that says that the Labor Party is only interested in the ethnic communities so long as they get their vote. They are not interested in respect. They are not interested in valuing those people for themselves or for the contribution they make.

You get asked, `How long have you been in the country?' The funny thing is, of course, that my family has been in this country since at least 1888 on my father's side and probably earlier—my grandmother was born in this country in 1888. Of course, my family has been in this country longer than that of the member in the other place who had asked me the question. That is the ironic thing.

Then we had Senator McKiernan who said on radio in Perth that there was a conspiracy between the coalition, the National Civic Council, the lawyers and the refugee organisations to populate northern Australia with Asians. This is the same senator who said that we were about to be deluged by hundreds of thousands of boat people from China and other Asian countries. In the eight months that have elapsed since then, Australia has not been deluged by hundreds of thousands of boat people. It is another Labor paranoid delusion, but it was whipped up to create a fear of one section of the community by another section of the community.

If the Prime Minister wants to play the race card, he is welcome to play the race card. But, first of all, if he wants any credibility, he has to publicly—publicly—chastise and reprimand the people in his own party who have been the major causes of intolerance in ethnic affairs in this country in the time that I have been in parliament. There is only one source of bigotry in parliament on these issues and it is the Labor Party, and that has been demonstrated by the facts, demonstrated by their public utterances.

The Prime Minister wants to pretend he is some sort of great saviour. He is not. He is just fanning the fires. I think the ethnic communities of this country should know that, whilst the Prime Minister says one thing to them, the members of his party are out saying another thing to the bigots in this community, to the vested interest groups that they want to prop up. That is the way the Labor Party treats the ethnic communities of this country and I think it is disgusting.

As I said in starting, Madam Deputy President, I rarely get up and talk about issues to do with ethnicity or race or whatever because I believe that Australia is one of the most tolerant countries in the world and it is a place where race is rarely an issue. It has become an issue and is becoming an issue because of the thoroughly unacceptable behaviour of the Prime Minister. I believe it is time that decent people stood up to him and said, `Enough is enough. Stop this nonsense. Stop trying to divide Australians against Australians. It won't work.' More importantly, all the wonderful progress that has been made in this country is set back 10 years, 20 years, 30 years, probably 100 years. I just cannot understand why anybody would want to do it, except to say that this is typical of the behaviour of the Prime Minister. I believe that everybody in this country, and especially the people up in the press gallery, ought to be aware of these things the next time he opens his mouth and carries on like this. It is thoroughly unacceptable, and it is time it stopped.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to expand upon some comments I made this afternoon, following question time, regarding the issue of the actions of CRA. It will be recalled that in that debate I referred to the operations of the Peak Hill Gold mining company, a fully owned subsidiary of CRA. I also recall, following my remarks, Senator O'Chee rising to his feet and, after his usual personal attack upon anybody on this side of the chamber associated with the trade union movement, talking about so-called facts.

PARA.TAB: I would like to illustrate some facts to the Senate tonight—and I am sure that Senator O'Chee should listen because, if he does, he will learn what the facts are. What I am about to quote gives a very good illustration of what the CRA Group of Companies is engaged in with the present industrial dispute at the Weipa mine.

Back in 1990, when I was the Assistant General Secretary of the Australian Workers Union, the union was approached by a company called the Peak Hill Gold mining company. That company was represented by the Australian Mines and Metals Association, the major employer association representing mining companies in this country. It approached the union to seek negotiations for the establishment of a new goldmine in New South Wales, near Cobar. That mine was to be operated by a company known as Peak Hill Gold which was, as I said, a fully owned subsidiary of CRA.

This was a very important project not only to the company but to the nation. As was clearly spelt out in evidence given to the Industrial Relations Commission, this was to be the largest goldmine in New South Wales. In the course of the negotiations that commenced with the union, the company was seeking to establish a greenfield site with single union coverage. It wanted all of the benefits that it could seek through the enterprise bargaining process to make this a model site.

The company was looking for things like the operation of 12-hour shifts underground—usually unheard of in Australian mining industry. It was looking for aggregate salaries. It was looking for new ways of approaching employee relations on site for solving problems, for identifying work practices which may have been an impediment to activity and ensuring that they would not occur. This was, from the ground up—and from the ground down, I suppose I should say—a new approach.

I will quote what was put to Commissioner Lawson when subsequently this agreement, that was ultimately reached, was put to the commission for approval. The company at the time was represented by Mr Graham Watson, who has some degree of fame in industrial relations circles as representing employers, namely CRA. This is a person with whom I have on many occasions argued across the table. The transcript states:

SPEECH.PARA: MR WATSON:. . . And perhaps I could start by explaining briefly what we propose to do today, and give a—a broad overview of the situation. Mr Commissioner, the Peak Gold Mine when completed will be the largest gold mine in New South Wales, and is one of the few major new resource developments taking place at the current time.

The proposed award agreed between the parties, is quite short and simple, but it encompasses a number of very important innovations derived from extensive negotiations between the parties, and extensive input from a range of persons, including a practical understanding of mining operations, and the application of modern human resource techniques.

Obviously, at a Greenfield site there are opportunities to plan and implement important innovations, and the parties have put in a tremendous amount of work into the development of a human resource philosophy, and the integration of the technology; the work organisation; the mining techniques; and the general approach to human resources.
We intend to demonstrate to the commission that the result is—is a credit to those involved, and in our submission fully deserves the support of the commission.

The parties being the union and the company. It was right at the initial stages of the development. There were very few employees employed at the time. As they were progressively employed they were given the opportunity and ultimately approved the agreement negotiated between the company and the union. They also called evidence in those proceedings from a Mr Hannigan, the manager of the mine, who said this:

Peak has to sell its product on world markets. It doesn't compete within Australia, it competes overseas, and therefore that's where we have to be focused. After visiting Canada and the United States, all those mines were basically single union and were very effective in their man management, and I think we need to learn a little bit about what happens in countries such as Canada, because they are our major competitor as far as minerals are concerned with Australia. But that took us down to single unions, and after a lot of investigation it did become obvious that the AWU, who we ended up doing quite extensive negotiations with over a period of nine months, were really the only union . . . that we could see that had the constitutional coverage to undertake all the things that we were trying do. And, in fact, we found them quite responsive in their discussions, and the consequence is that we had this agreement which we would like to put in place.

This agreement was duly ratified by the commission and throughout the transcript of those proceedings praise was given by the company to the processes involved in negotiating this agreement with the union. It was approved in early 1991 and broke new ground in the mining industry. But what happened? About two years later the union suddenly received a bundle of resignation notices, all in the same form, quite unannounced. They just arrived. What did we discover? We discovered that the company had gone around and coerced the employees into signing up on individual contracts—individual contracts which took away many of their basic rights and which were the same for every single employee at the mine. These individual contracts that the opposition is so supportive of are all exactly the same. There is no individuality about them at all. The individual contract had a provision in it such as this:
The employee agrees to abide by and adhere to the CRA group code of business conduct during the period of this contract of employment.

If you want full details of the code of conduct you find them in the employee handbook. What was one of the requirements in the employee handbook? If an employee joined an association whose objectives may somehow differ with those of the company then they were required to tell the company supervisor about it. That was a requirement in the individual contract. In other words, they were required to go and tell the company if they joined the union, even though the union was not allowed to represent them. The contract also said this:
The company encourages the employee to participate in community affairs, provided that such participation does not interfere with the employee's personal effectiveness at work.
How generous of the company! They then had in their contract of employment clause of this individual contract:

This contract of employment is the result of direct discussions between the employee and representative of the company and supersedes all previous contracts and arrangements entered into between the parties.

On that occasion, having gone to the commission and having negotiated a consent agreement, having praised that agreement as being at the forefront of industrial relations in this country, having achieved the very things that would make that mine site productive, what did the company do? They tore it up and walked away from it and coerced the employees into individual contracts. That company is a fully owned subsidiary of CRA. They deceived the Industrial Relations Commission to the point where they used the processes to establish an award, then they walked away from it for no reason whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: You say that the people have to abide by the laws of this country. The CRA company in that case totally flouted the Industrial Relations Commission award. We now have in Weipa a continuation of that long pursuit by the CRA to de-unionise its operations, to drive the union movement out of its sites—something that I have said is totally undemocratic and foreign to our way of life.

"There are a very bitter group of people who will do almost anything to attack Noel Crichton-Browne.

SPEECH.PARA: "Much of it is personal; individuals who have a deep hatred of Crichton-Browne will use any pretext to attack him and don't care if they drag the Party down to its knees in the meantime.
.The matter is covered by parliamentary privilege and cannot be used as a ground for discipline.
I go to the next item in respect of this matter. It refers to comments about party leaders and the complaint is this:
2. COMMENTS ABOUT PARTY LEADERS
2.1In the Federal Parliament on 26 June 1995 in the course of a Personal Explanation you stated:-
"No leader ever tells me when I have to go. My history is that I have had to tell a few leaders when they have had to go." (Hansard 26 June 1995 page 4)
2.2That statement by you was the subject of widespread adverse and embarrassing publicity to the Party in the media across in Australia.
2.3By reason of your standing in the Party and public profile through the media the remarks made by you were imprudent and reflected adversely on the Party.

Again this ground is covered by privilege as it refers to a quote made by me in the Senate and may not be subject to scrutiny or consideration by State Council. It cannot be a ground of the expulsion motion. However, for the purpose of presenting the facts I set out the details as follow.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The statement was made in jest with tongue in cheek as those present know.

SPEECH.PARA: The speech I made in which this quote is to be found and which the State President seeks to make much for the sake of concocting these spurious grounds for expulsion was made under Senate Standing Order 190—
which we have discussed today—
which provides that a Senator can claim to be misrepresented and to correct the misrepresentations—
something I have since learned you cannot.

The article complained of was one written by Glen Milne in The Australian. It was a particularly savage article factually incorrect in almost every material way, but which was the result of a misinformed briefing either by Mr Howard's staff or that of one of my colleagues.

The article in part read, "The truth of this appeared to be borne out during the tough negotiations in Perth during which Howard initially told Crichton-Browne he had to go." It was at that point that I injected my phrase.

The article continued, "Crichton-Browne's wife Esther was present for some of these negotiations. She made tea for Howard and, given the nature of the discussion, must have maximised the Liberal Leader's discomfort."
I again injected in jest that, "I find this kind of quaint—can you imagine any leader discomforted because my wife was making him a cup of tea?"
Senator Gareth Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate then interjected—"Depends what she put in it."
I responded, "She put a strong dose of courage in it. I am not referring to courage for him but courage for decision making." Hardly treasonable blasphemy which demands burning at the stake."
The only people at the meeting from which this distorted account was leaked and reported in The Australian, were John Howard, Geoff Prosser, Esther and myself.
By any measure it is a trivial matter, a nonsense ground and did not attract attention across Australia. By contrast it most certainly does not compare with public statements—
which I refer to on pages 121, 122, 123 and 124 of this document—

made by other Western Australian Federal Members of Parliament attacking the leader which are outlined below, not the least being those made by Senator Knowles, who in her public statements implied that Mr Downer had bought votes by promises of positions, and Mr Cameron who launched a vitriolic attack on Mr Downer. Mr Cameron also publicly criticised the Premier Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the same point of order in relation to this passage. It is imputing an improper motive on a member of this place.

—It certainly seemed to me at that particular point that you were imputing motives into another person that ought not to be included.
—I suggest that I continue to read so that you can make a judgment over the next paragraph, with your indulgence.

—It is not for me to tell you, Madam Deputy President. But, quite frankly, every page of this document that is relevant has been read by the clerk because I did not want to breach standing order 193. I do not want to waste my time right now. He said there was nothing in it that he had read which contravened 193.
—It certainly was my view that at that point you were imputing improper motives and conduct to a member and that you ought to delete that portion.
—I am not deleting anything. You can ask me to withdraw. But I am not deleting it; it is in the Hansard, end of story.
—I ask you to withdraw it.
—I withdraw it. I continue to read:

SPEECH.PARA: For example : "West Australian back bencher, Mr Eoin Cameron said he was "appalled" and "outraged" by the sacking (of Dr Hewson from the front bench)—
no motive implied—
"He (Mr Downer) was called a sook in the parliament and I don't know whether its an over-reaction to that or not,—-

SPEECH.PARA: No motive imputed, Senator Reid. It continues:

While I do not claim to have all coverage of the matter, my extensive inquiries show my quote about the leader as running to a total of 6.5cm or 2(1/2 )column inches in all Australian newspapers. So much for claims of widespread adverse and embarrassing publicity to the Party in the media across Australia.—The press treated it for what it was.
Neither Sue Knowles or Eoin Cameron were ever censured for their comments about the leader which received heavy national media attention and which were said in a very critical context.
One gets the feeling that not only are these grounds contrived and concocted, but that they were made up on the spot without even a minimum of research, or a pretence of seriousness.

The last ground—that claiming I called for the expulsion of unspecified members was added at the State Executive meeting without any evidence being presented. "One may say it seemed a good idea at the time", that is why it is absolutely without substance. However, more than anything, it shows the sloppy and irresponsible way in which these four grounds were made up.
SUMMARY
.The comments have been taken out of context and were tongue in cheek.
.They were in response to an untrue newspaper article.
.The comments certainly did not embarrass the Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to deal with problems that have emerged from a leaked Telstra internal memorandum, which I raised at question time today. There is no doubt that the savage spending cuts—I am not arguing whether they are justified or not—that have emerged from a changed view by Telstra of its revenues, its earnings before interest and tax and its cash flow, have some clear consequences, particularly for rural Australia and for all those Australians who are awaiting the upgrading of their telephone services to the digital operation that has been promised.

PARA.TAB: In the latest annual report, for example, Telstra says that it aims to have 100 per cent digital cover by the year 2000. At the moment, about 62 per cent of the network has been digitised. When in question time today I said that this posed serious problems and a serious threat to the upgrading of the system which was required and which had been progressing at a rate which may well not be able to be sustained, for some extraordinary reason the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) pretended that this was some kind of attack on the diligence of the employees of Telstra.

I assert now that this leaked Telstra memorandum has effectively ended prospects of the Australian telephone system being upgraded to a 100 per cent digital system by the year 2000, particularly in rural areas. The memo from the Chief Executive of Telstra, Frank Blount, revealed that Telstra would sack most contractors, stop recruitment of new staff, withdraw existing job offers and cut or postpone major projects. What we want to find out is whether the major project to upgrade the system to a 100 per cent digital network is at risk under these cuts. We got no indication from the government.

I asked Senator McMullan twice whether he would give an unequivocal guarantee that this upgrading program would not be cut, and he chose instead to suggest that I was somehow attacking Telstra employees. The only Telstra employees being attacked at the moment are those who are going to lose their jobs and the contractors who are going to be sacked as a result of these proposed arrangements. It is this government—not the opposition—that looks like getting stuck into Telstra workers.

At the moment, rural areas are falling behind the cities in this upgrading of the service to digital. The digital system is an enormous improvement and provides a far greater service than do the existing arrangements. It is a matter of some concern that there is an apparent threat to this program. Particularly in recent Senate estimates committees where Telstra has been dealt with, I have raised the question of whether or not Telstra's enormous expansion into non-core activities—particularly overseas and into various other enormously expensive activities in cable television and so on—was diminishing the funds available to upgrade the Australian telephone service, which, after all, is Telstra's main duty.

I was also concerned, as many senators have been, that Telstra has been required to pay just under $1 billion in dividends—a far greater proportion than normal—to the government in the latest year to help the government's budgeting problems. The government has plenty of budgeting problems. All the assets that were supposed to be sold do not look like being sold. Here it is milking Telstra to the extent that now major projects are going to be cancelled, according to Telstra's internal memo. Some are to be cancelled; some are to be cut severely; we do not know which ones yet.

But there is no doubt that major projects will be cut or postponed, because that is what the chief executive, Mr Blount, has said in this leaked memo that came to me today. It is from him to members of his executive committee. The memo was sent out on Sunday after an executive committee meeting last Friday. I think it is a disgrace that the government is not prepared to give an assurance that these severe Telstra spending cuts would not delay the digital upgrading program.

There are plenty of other spending cuts listed by Mr Blount. They are in promotion and advertising. Sponsorship activities will also be severely curtailed. This will be a serious blow to many organisations in Australia who have depended on Telstra for sponsorship. Just to cheer them up, I will read what the leaked memorandum from Mr Blount actually says:

Sponsorship activities will be severely curtailed. Except for those activities in this regard which are already firmly committed, we will immediately cease discussions or considerations on any other or additional sponsorships. We will not automatically renew any existing sponsorships until or unless they are completely reviewed.

SPEECH.PARA: On promotion and advertising the memo says:

PARA.TAB: Promotion & Advertising expenditures will be targeted to be reduced to the level which was actually spent in the previous fiscal year.
Our Property Group will be instructed to see if there is any feasible way we can consider additional asset sales this year so as to bring about cash flow improvements.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope Telstra do their property sales better than the group of property sales they tried in Sydney recently where they were selling as subdivided lots land that had not had approval for subdivision and they were selling lots to the public that were contaminated. It was one of the greatest snafus that one could possibly expect. I hope that, if Telstra is going to go into the asset sale disposal business, it lifts its game. Mr Blount said in the memo:

PARA.TAB: We will, in addition to these priorities for cutting or postponing major projects . . . examine more fully every substantive project or program to either postpone, refocus, or cancel.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us face it: making the network totally digital by the year 2000 is a major project, a substantive project. Is it going to be postponed, refocused or cancelled? These problems, I think, are very serious, because there is no doubt in my mind that Australian telephone users are now going to have to suffer the consequences of Telstra being forced to pay this huge dividend of just under a billion dollars to help out the government's budget problems and for its diversion of multi millions of dollars into non-core activities, particularly overseas. The memo says about the employment consequences:

PARA.TAB: We will immediately move to much more stringently manage the intake of full time staff and of contractors . . . We will force the issue of reassignment of personnel within the Company as an absolute imperative and only in rare and exceptional cases will we be adding people to Telstra's payroll through recruitment from outside the Company. This means that any such endeavours must be immediately shut down (including university recruitment) . . .

SPEECH.PARA: So university graduates who are hoping they might have a role to play in Telstra can forget it. It continues:
Any pending offers to people outside the Company will have to be withdrawn . . .
It also says that people whose jobs have been declared redundant will be forced to accept other jobs within the organisation. It continues:

In the case of contractors being utilised effectively for major project work, decisions will be made to pare back or eliminate some projects on a priority basis with the expectation that the service of contractors assigned to the projects which are eliminated or deferred will be terminated.

So there we have the great contribution of Telstra to the unemployment problem in Australia. Whether or not there are excepted employees is another matter; I do not know. But these are the facts. (Time expired)
